titleStmt.title: A good souldier, maintaining his militia, and posturing himself, as the servants of the Lord, now and in all ages have postured the kingdomes; wherein the right-hand of the Lord with his servants directing their way, and blessing their worke; and all His ordinances, fasting, praying, preaching, &c. unto the nation; is declared as mightily, as it was by the resurrection from the dead, whether we respect a nation or a man only. Here is a register of Gods blessings and Satans curses; a record of the (megaleia,) the great and admiral salvations, which God has wrought for the (Righteous) nation, and the man there: And of the terrible things Hee has done against His adversaries these foure last yeares. Humbly presented to the House of Parliament and Assembly of Divines. With a discovery of the loyall convert, that he is quite turned from his God, his King and his kingdome: a most disloyall person to all three.

Here is a Regiſter of Gods bleſſings and Satans curſes; A Record of the ( 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ,) The great and admirable ſalvations, which God has wrought for the (Righteous) Nation, and the Man there: And of the terrible things Hee has done againſt His Adverſaries theſe foure laſt yeares. q.p: From all your filthineſſe, and from all your Idols will I cleanſe you.
I will also cauſ you to dwell in the Cities, and the waſts ſhall be builded.
I will yet for this be enquired of by the houſe of Iſrael, to doe it for them.

div.q: EZRA 7. 23.Whatſoever is commanded by th God of Heaven, let it be diligently done: For why ſhould there be wrath againſt the Realme.

q.p: The Lord made me have dominion over the mighty.
O my ſoule thou haſt trodden downe ſtrength.

div.head: TO THE HONOVRABLE MEN, AND THE COVNSELLOVRS; The Mighty Men, and the Men of Warre; The Iudge and the Prophet, and the Prudent, and the Antient in all three Kingdomes: Engaged now in the worke and ſervice of the LORD, To helpe the LORD againſt the Mighty.
div.p:
AS large and ſpreading a Dedication almoſt as was the Anchoran, An. 634. French-mans, who dedicated a Booke, not his own neither, to Prince Charles, then to all the Popes and Cardinalls, Archbiſhops and Biſhops: and to all the learned-men within and without all the Univerſities in all foure Kingdomes. Every man abounds in his own ſenſe, I in mine. But I conceive, and that I cannot be mistaken; That when you ſhall have read this ſhort Epiſtle throughout, you will ſay, There is infinite Reaſon why I ſhould dedicate theſe following leaves to you all, you
Princes, Nobles and Worthies; and to the good people too, in all three Kingdomes: But more ſpecially to you. You! The Lord has picked you out of Thouſands; You are His peculiars; His choſen ones; He has honoured you with his own Name, Saviours, Repairers of the breach, wide as the Sea; Reſtorers of the paths to dwell in; Builders of the waſts, Raiſers-up the deſolations, which a people of Gods curſe have made in your LORDS Kingdomes. A marvellous honour has the Lord put upon you! A glorious worke has He wrought for His Kingdomes by your hands! You are intreated now by the mercies of Chriſt to ſhew mercy to your owne ſoules, To work out your owne ſalvation, To doe the ſame worke for your owne ſoules, which you have done for the Nation: You are entreated to take the ſame way in poſturing your ſelves, which you have taken in poſturing the Kingdomes. A moſt juſt requeſt, It is granted. You will obſerve now what you have done for the Kingdomes.

1. You have plucked downe the high and lofty ones, proud Perſons, and vile Things, Idols of jealouſie before the eye. Pluck them downe in your heart too, or elſe you have done nothing for your ſoules.
2. You have commanded Prayer. Pray in prayer, pray ſervently, in your own houſe and cloſet: And if you cannot pray ſo, mourne that you cannot.

3. You have opened the priſon doores, and the mouthes of Ministers: you have ſent forth Angels (a more proper word then Biſhops) To preach the everlaſting Goſpell (as you read.) (Truly the Lord will doe Great Things for this Land, Truly He will.) That you may ſee it with your eyes, and rejoyce with His Inheritance, labour with all your might to bring your hearts to the rule, and under the power of the Goſpell.

4. You have vindicated the LORDS Day, a day ſo vilified, ſo reproached, ſo blaſphemed; never was day ſo dealt
with ſince the beginning of dayes; you have vindicated That Day; Let it appeare you have done it in Truth, for your LORDS Day is your delight, and you ſanctifie that day unto the Lord.

5. You would keepe-off common-hands from taking the Sacrament of the Body and Blood of the LORD: You will looke to your hands, that they be cleane: and your veſſels, that they be holy, wherein you have put that ſhew-Bread, thoſe Holy myſteries. You are conſulting about a Church way. You are reſolved, with Joſhua, To walke in it amidſt your owne houſe.

6. You would bring the three Kingdomes into covenant with their God; Bleſſed be you of the Lord. But you doe all this faithfully; you have lifted-up your hands, to the high God, to Reforme your ſelfe and yours. Now you muſt not ſtart aſide. The Covenant is as a large circumference, it fetcheth a wide circuit about three Kingdomes; If you love your ſoules, as you doe the Kingdomes, you muſt Center this Covenant, every man in his own heart; you must ſtand to it.
7. Active you are to quench the fier in the Kingdomes. You are as active to quench the fier in your owne-boſomes, which let alone there, may burne to the neithermoſt Hell, a place below the grave.

8. You would have the Lord purge-out the Rebells out of the Kingdomes: He muſt doe it, for it is his promiſe; But if you deſire it heartily, you are more active in ſubduing the rebellions in your owne heart. This is to love the Kingdomes in Truth; This is to walke in the Truth; This is to doe faithfully whatever you doe to the Bretheren and to ſtrangers: And why not, to your own ſoules? Goe on and proſper, as your ſoules proſper. Love the Kingdomes ſtill, and love your own ſoules ſtill; Poſture and ſtrengthen the Kingdomes with one hand,
your ſoules with the other. All this is done by the ſame means, in the ſame way. The LORD keepe your hearts cloſe to Him, and your hands to His worke, which ſhall turne to your ſalvation alſo, through your prayers, and the prayers of all the Churches for you, and the ſupply of the Spirit of the Lord Jeſus Chriſt. Amen and Amen.

div.head: A GOOD SOVLDIER.
The Reaſon and Vſe of this Treatiſe.

argument.p: Declaring the right hand of the Lord with His ſervants, in the way of working ſalvation for His Kingdomes: which way is ſo demonſtrated to every man, that he muſt ſee himſelfe ſtand charged in particular to worke for himſelfe in the ſame way, as be regards the ſalvation of his owne ſoule.

div.p:
I Muſt neceſſarily ſuppoſe, that no man, in the Chriſtian world, can be a ſtranger to the affairs of theſe times; what the condition of England (not to ſpeake of Ireland) is at this preſent time; what fraud has been uſed to under-mine the Church, the City of God there, theſe many years; what forcing againſt her theſe yeares by-paſt; what forcible waies have been taken to ſtorme it this laſt yeare, that it might be no more a Citie, or called by that name; This very thing, I ſay, how angry the Nations are; how thoſe, who ſhould be (as David ſpeakes of his adverſaries) the Churches guides and friends, how theſe have magnified themſelves againſt her, have conſulted and parlied together (for an Aſſembly of Robbers, is called a Parliament in Oxford) againſt Thy hidden ones, ſaying, Come let us cut them off from being a Pſal. 83. 4 • . Nation: that their name way be no more in remembrance: All this is well knowne to all, that are not willingly ignorant. So alſo, what waies have been taken by the friends of the LORD CHRIST (thoſe few that have appeared for Him) ſo defend His Church from the furious aſſaults of bloody men; and how wonderfull their LORD has appeared on their ſide; how He has taken • o Himſelfe
power, has diſcovered thoſe, that magnified themſelves againſt Him; has exalted His right Hand in all his peoples ſight, in delivering, reſcuing, protecting, MARVELLOƲSLY ſeperating betwixt His Friends, and His Adverſaries; ſo maintaining His cauſe and His ſervants ſtanding-up for His cauſe, againſt the power and policie of all oppoſers: All this alſo, is knowne in all the earth, Iſa. 12. 5. therefore ſing unto the LORD and exalt His name Jah:
• or, though the gates of hell ſtood all this while wide open upon Gods people, yet theſe gates prevailed not, All this violence, and wrong could not hinder the worke of the LORD, but promoted it rather in all the peoples ſight: Bleſſed be the LORD. Indeed it is the faireſt and moſt admired proſpect, that ever was ſeene, to ſtand ſtill, and behold the works of the LORD, and the operations of His Hand, reached forth to His ſervants out of the clouds; yet is His Hand made viſible now before all the Chriſtian world, carrying on and ſteering the hand and way of his people through ſeas of proud waters, ſtormes and tempests, mighty troubles, towards their promiſed land, a wealthy place. To leave the figure and to ſpeake properly; The Almighties Hand, ſteering and guiding His people-in and throughout this whole posturing worke, is cleared now to the eye of fleſh, and is wonderfull in our eyes. I ſhall ſpeake a little here, for it is but a little, which man can ſpeake in this, how wonderfully the Lord has appeared for His ſervants all along the way, they have gone, to advance His glorie; but I ſhall ſhew openly the way they have gone, to be the very ſame, wherein all the truely noble in the world have walked, when the Lord was pleaſed to uſe their hands for the ſtrengthening themſelves, and well-posturing His Kingdomes. This way is cleared to ſenſe and reaſon, and demonſtrable to every man by comparing a Body naturall, with a Body-politique, when there is no ſoundneſſe in the one, nor in the other, but wounds and bruiſes, and putrifying ſores Iſa. 1. 6.: comparing the one Bodie with the other, and earthly things with ſpirituall, every man may underſtand the way of poſturing a Kingdome, and himſelfe: for that is chiefly intended here, and of chiefe concernment, elſe the well poſturing of a Kingdom will be nothing unto him.

The whole Kingdome is but the great Body politique, whereof
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . M. Ant. Medit. B. 1. Sect. 15. p. 12. he himſelfe is not a part (for ſo the Philoſopher would not have him called, but) a member. Suppoſe now, that ſuch a Body, which
the naturall man is better acquainted with, a Naturall bodie, lyes here before us, in the ſame caſe, as we have read and ſeen this great Bodie of the Kingdome to be-in, languiſhing neare unto death, The whole head ſicke, and the whole heart faint; Suppoſe it ſo; and yet we need not make it a ſuppoſition, for ſo it was. We will not now goe to the Colledge of Phiſitians to aske them, what is to be done in this caſe? Whether ſomething muſt be put upon the body, or ſomething put into it? We will put ſomething into it ſure enough, ſo ſenſe and reaſon tels us, for we are not ſo forſaken of both, as to clap an head-peece upon this Bodie, then a Breaſt-plate, ſo other peeces of armour in order one after another, and then call to him, as once to Sampſon, up and quit thy ſelfe like a man, the Philiſtins are upon thee. Alas! The Bodie is weake, becauſe the humours within are ſo ſtrong, the ſpirits waſted and ſpent, becauſe of ſomething within, which muſt be purged forth firſt. If you put Armour upon him, it will but cumber him the more, and be a meanes to preſſe-out, that little ſpirit, which remaines. The Phyſitian for the Bodie knowes his worke here, ſo does the ſoule-phyſitian: If the LORD has intruſted them to diſcretion, they both worke together, and give their directions orderly; And the maine conſultation is about the caſting-out of the bad humours, the inabling the man to fight with his diſeaſe, and to overcome it: Here the Elders of the Church (ſoul-Phyſitians) ſee their worke, they muſt pray for him [for the body under ſuch diſtempers, the mind ſympathiſing with the body, cannot pray for it ſelfe; the elders muſt be called-in now, and that inſtructeth us not to put off the great work, making peace with God, to our ſick bed; we can doe nothing for our ſelves then, the Elders muſt doe all, they muſt pray for the ſick, and] as the caſe may be, and humours ſo ſtrong, faſt for him alſo: for ſome humours, as ſpirits, will not out by other meanes. Phyſitians will preſcribe a way how to inable the patient to fight with his diſeaſe; how he may recover his ſpirits, and fortifie them, make them quick and lively; Then they will preſcribe him a diet, how he may keep himſelfe ſtrong, by keeping cloſe to his preſcriptions, and to the GOD of his ſtrength, and from all that is hurtfull, may grieve the Spirit of his God, and ſo a worſe thing fall unto him. Now put Armour upon. this man • and ſpeake to him as to Sampſon, and he will doe as at other times, when GOD was wi ••
him, and he walked with God. It is juſt ſo in the poſturing of a Kingdome, in the ſetting that great Body in a poſture of Defence; It is as the diſeaſed Body we read of, but of this in due place.

I think it more pertinent to this place, to ſay this, That this is the very end the LORD does point at in all his ſore judgements upon Kingdomes, and in all the plagues, ſtroakes, ſickneſſes, ſorrowes, He inflicts on the children of men; This is the great end, That the plague of the heart may be diſcovered to every heart: Therefore 1 King. 8. 38. the earth is ſhaken terribly, that the blood-ſhed there may be diſcoverd; That the Idolls there may be utterly aboliſhed; The very end, why the Lord ariſeth now to ſhake the earth terribly: And He will not leave ſhaking till the Idolls be caſt-out to the moles and to the batts. In a word, Therefore the Lord has done, and does the evill of puniſhment, That He may diſcover to every man, the evill of his ſinne; And ſo I would deſcend from a generall to a particular; for when I have ſaid every man, I have, indeed, ſpoken to no man, for no man will think it ſpoken unto him: And indeed it is but a beating of the ayer alſo, loſt labour, to ſpeake unto 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , a certaine man, ſome-body, but I know not whom, who, when you have talked about Poſturing a Kingdome, the way how to ſet it in a good poſture of Defence, will not thinke himſelfe to be ſpoken unto, though he can thinke himſelfe wholy concerned therein: for this is an old ſaying, and very true; he that speakes to every body, ſpeakes to no body: and what is every bodies work is no bodies work, and ſo by all neglected; And though every-body would ſhare in the common bleſſing, yet no-body is ſo ready to ſhare in the duty; he would be ſafe, and have his cabbin and goods ſo to be, whatever become of the Ship, I meane the Common-wealth; not conſidering that he ſailes along upon the ſea of the world, in the ſame ſhip; and, where others are, there is his cabbin too, his intereſt is there, the publick welfare concernes himſelfe, and his owne ſafety. But this is not all, ſuppoſe that the ſhip, by the care and the wiſedome of the ſtecremen, come ſafe to land, yet this mans comfort ſhall be, but according to the proportion of his care, in ſeeking the preſervation of the ſhip; Nay more than this, and ſo I will ſpeake more plainely, for I intend the information of the ſimple; What if the Militia of the Kingdome were fully ſetled and maintained, what good were that, to that man, who, in the meane time, lyeth
quite naked, expoſed to all the malice of the Devill and his owne heart; what were it to him, that the Kingdome is ſet in a ſafe and good poſture, if in the meane time, he himſelf be, as a Towne without walls, or as a City whoſe walls are broken downe; who or what will may come-in, and goe-out, and make a prey there? Therefore I will point a few words directly to him, even that particular man, that lookes to have comfort, ſafety and peace in the Kingdomes ſafety. That is his hope, But there is an hope, which makes aſhamed, like waters dried-up in ſummer: Is it a true hope? Then the man has this ground, That all this time, while the Kingdome has been posturing, he has, with the good ſouldier, learned well to poſture himſelfe; he has not neglected to doe that every day, which omitted, will be the greateſt cut and grief to our hearts, on that day, the great day, when the ways and ſecrets of all hearts ſhall be opened, and all the prizes, the opportunities put-into our hands, let ſlip thence, and loſt there, ſhall be preſented to our knowledge: This will be the Hell indeed. Therefore, that this hope may not be a conceit only, but an Anchor, ſure and ſtedfaſt, to the ſoul, amidſt the great water-floods, It concernes this man to conſider as followes:

He has heard the Drumme beate every day theſe three yeares together; It was his Alarm; he was called upon to put himſelfe in a poſture of Defence; for when the houre of temptation and ſore agony comes upon him (it is come upon the world) and he be found naked, he muſt be left the more naked of excuſe, becauſe he was called-upon every day to maintaine his Militia, to quit himſelfe as a good ſouldier of Jeſus Chriſt: He muſt think alſo, if he thinks of himſelf, and common reaſon forſakes him not, (which muſt needs tell him,) That ſooner or later he ſhall meet with enemies enough to combate with, though none of thoſe deſtroyers, (ſo buſily employed now in working-out their own deſtruction, and againſt their intent, the ſalvation of Gods people) though none of theſe, he meet with, yet he muſt looke to meet with thoſe as bad to combate with, with the Prince ruling in the ayre, Principalities and powers, thoſe mighty adverſaries, might and power it ſelfe; Beſides, vehement winds, and a ſcorching ſeaſon, will beat upon the head of every man ſooner or later, and down he falls, he knowes not how low, unleſſe his ſtanding be ſure upon the Rock, in a good poſture of Defence; when a ſickneſſe unto death comes, then this will be,
even the ſenſe of all this, if the heart be not, at that time, as Naballs was, like a ſtone, dead and paſt feeling; Before the man dies; then, I ſay, the ſenſe of all this will be; The man may be now like a wild-Aſſe traverſing his way, but in that Moneth he ſhall be Jer. 2. 24. found.

But before this day comes, who knows what terrible things he may ſee! He may ſee the tearing-up of mountaines by the rootes, and hurling them into the midſt of the ſea, as the Prophet expreſſeth Pſal. 46. the terrible commotions, concuſſions, diſtractions, which have been, are and will be in poſturing times, troublous times ever, when the breaches in Jeruſalems wall are making-up; He may feele the earth trembling, Divells and men raging, garments rouled in blood; he may ſee Townes fired; Cities laid-waſt; all deſireable things taken from him, and what his ſoul loaths given into his hands, inſtead thereof. Then, if he hath maintained his Militia, if he be, as the good ſouldier, in a poſture of defence, happy is he. If otherwiſe, neither he nor I can expreſſe how miſerable his caſe will be; very miſerable and beyond expreſſion. Sinners in Zion, men profeſſing the truth, but not ſhewing forth the power thereof in their life, theſe ſhall be afraid, fearfullneſſe and trembling will come upon him, ſorrow will overwhelme him; The proud waters will goe over Pſal. 55. 5. his head; terrours ſhall make him afraid on every ſide; brimſtone ſhall be ſcattered upon his habitation. Job 18. 11.

There is one thing more in this, and commands our ſerious conſideration. Suppoſe this careleſſe perſon ſhould be inſtrumentall to the poſturing the Kingdome, in throwing out Perſons and Things, which have troubled the peace of the ſame; Suppoſe ſo, while yet he himſelfe is an unreformed perſon, his own Militia is quite neglected; Then this will follow, That all this he has done, though according to the command of God, is upon his ſcore, and he ſhall be reckoned with for it, even for the good, he hath done, becauſe after an ill manner. He (as was ſaid of old) rebuked pride with another pride; he has throwne-out Idoll-Perſons, and their Idoll ſervices, but is as Idolatrous as were they: They ſet-up Idolls before their eyes, he ſetts-them up in his heart: It was Jehues caſe, a moſt notable caſe; He deſtroyed Ahab and his houſe, and had a word for it, the command of God, But he did it for the glory of his own name; with a zeale burning-hot, but it was for his own houſe, and
was ſuch an Idolater, as Ahab was: Therefore ſaith the Lord (it is terrible) I will avengeth blood of Jezreel upon the houſe of Jehu. This Scripture is fully and uſefully cleared to me and thee, (for Mr Burrought upon Hoſea, c. i. v. 4. there is a deceit in Generalls) how dangerous a thing it is to profeſſe our ſelves teachers of others, and yet not teach our ſelves; A reformer of others, and yet our ſelves unreformed; An enemy to Idols ſtanding without the man, but a friend to Idols ſtanding-up in his own heart: This is to abhorre Idols, yet to commit ſacriledge. It is of great, of infinite concernment. Let me ſpeake this over once more to the Gallio of theſe times, I would ſingle him out though he is plurall; I meane them, whoſe hearts, and hands may be with the Parliament, but they regard the things that are done, no more than Gallio did the beating of Soſthenes; To this man I Acts 18. 17. would point theſe few words. 1. He can think it very fit that all that which exalts it ſelfe in a Kingdome, to the deſtruction of King and Kingdome, be taken downe; the Idols there throwne away, for they make a Kingdome naked; and he can be active this way; But he heares not himſelfe ſpeak all this while unto himſelfe, That it more concernes him to throw-out the Idols all, which exalt themſelves in his own heart againſt the Lord Christ, and his own peace. 2. He can, perhaps, command Prayer and Fasting alſo, think all this ſeaſonable in theſe troublous times; but regards not how ſlack and cold he is at that performance in his houſe and cloſſet. 3. So for the word of GOD, the power of GOD unto ſalvation, he can help to widen the doore, to give it a free paſſage, and yet ſhut his own heart againſt it, not ſubjecting himſelfe to the rule and power thereof. 4. So for the Lords day; he has perhaps helped to vindicate that day from its horrible pollutions, and yet the duties performed on that day, what a wearineſſe to him? 5. So for the Covenant, he can perſwade others to enter-into it, and yet not perſwaded in his own heart, to ſtand unto it, though he has lifted-up his hand to the high GOD, and ſubſcribed his name, that ſo he will doe. He complaines of the publick miſeries, but indeed they are the private, that trouble him
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Iſa. 1 • . The Ladies ſaith Homer, wept heartily with Briſei over the body of Patroclus, but it was becauſe their own Lords were ſlaine in the ſame ba •
tle.; he helps to quench the fier in the Kingdome with all ſpeed, for he feares the fier will take his dwelling place; he ſtands-up againſt the robbers and ſpoilers, leaſt they enter his own doores. I could tell him here a very apt and pertinent diſcourſe between Lypſius and Langius, touching
the troubles and miſeries of Belgia; But becauſe I ſuppoſe this man well skilled in the Latine tongue, as Gallio was, being a chiefe perſon, a Deputy, I will point only to this diſcourſe in the Lipſ. de Conſtant. l. 1. c. 8. Margin, and entreat him heartily to read it, That I may not delay the Reader any longer from taking a full view of the method, and well ordered way, the Nobles and Worthies have taken in this poſturing worke: then we ſhall ſee, That the Good Souldier has taken the very ſame way in the poſturing himſelfe: And ſo, by the good hand of God with him, he ſtands as a well poſtured Kingdom, more ſtable than are the everlaſting hills, and perpetuall mountaines; The blaſt of the terrible ones againſt him, mooves him no more, than does a blaſt of wind ſhake a wall of braſſe.

div.head: CHAP. I. The first worke in Poſturing a Kingdome, is,

argument.p: The caſting-out of Abominations thence, Perſons and Things The cheife Heads and Leaders only named; Whereto are added, Maſters of Schooles and Colledges. And to the Abominable things are added, blaſphemous Pictures, Divine names given to unhallowed places fignes and dayes. This work is firſt in deſigne, laſt in performance: It is doing, but never done, Much is done, and mighty Reaſons given, why there is no more done.

div.p:
I Muſt review the compariſon betwixt the Civill Body and the Naturall: In this, there were malignant humours as evill ſpirits; In that, there are malignant Perſons and Things. Malignant Perſons, I will but name the chiefe, ſpecially thoſe, who have Defiled the Land with blood; polluted it with Idolatries; leavened it with Atheiſme and prophaneneſſe; All theſe might be pointed at with the finger. 1. The murtherers firſt, men of bloods, mighty hunters before the LORD, who have ſlaine the bodies of men; ſpilt their pretious blood like water. God will require it; At the hand of every beast will GOD require it Gen. 9. 5, • . At the hands of theſe beastslike-men, much more, woe unto him and them, who have ſpilt this blood; They have defiled the land, and the land cannot be cleanſed of the blood, that is ſhed therein, but by the blood of him that
ſhed it Num. 35. 33.. 2. Thoſe, that have (what in them lay) ſpilt the blood of ſoules, for whom the LORD Chriſt has ſhed His moſt pretious blood: Woe unto them; a double woe upon Arch-biſhops and Biſhops, who have, by their abominable doctrines and practiſes, ſlaine the ſoules of men; ſo as the Church has complained bitterly, Woe is me now, for my ſoule is wearied becauſe of murtherers Jer. 4. 3 • .; murtherers in the higheſt degree Illud pernicioſum, quod in aternitate juguiabit, &c. Sal. ad Eccleſ. l. 2. • .: The Lord has lifted-up His hand againſt theſe; and by command from Gods mouth, man has liftedup his hand alſo, and ſubſcribed his name for the caſting of theſe forth: for they have leavened the land with Atheiſme and with Idolatry, and with horrible prophanations: It were endleſſe to reckonup ſingulars here, This Atheiſt and that Idolater, theſe prophane perſons, who ſwarme every where, this were an infinite work. Ile name but one ſingle perſon more, but he is plurall, many, if not a legion; He is the Catechiſer, a Maſter in the Schoole and Colledge; Men of infinite uſe to the places where they are, if they ſtudy to be uſefull; If good, then as were the figgs, very good: If bad, very bad Jer. 24. 3.: The Schoolemaſter, he diſtilleth, infuſeth, droppeth into children what pleaſeth them, and that is ever what is worſt, whereunto corrupt nature ſtands moſt bent and baiſed. Children are not as we commonly ſay, tanquam raſae tabula, As a cleane table, or paper, wherein nothing is written, but you may write therein what you pleaſe. There is ſome truth in it, and of excellent uſe: yet, I ſay, children are not as cleane paper; there is ſomething written in them before the father took them into his armes, which all the fingers in the world cannot take forth: The more care is to be had into whoſe fingers you commit your children; and under what droppings they are ſet. If the little veſſell be ill ſeaſoned at firſt, it is more then a doubt, it will never prove good for ſervice, or honourable uſe Childs pa •• . c. 1, 2. &c. 9.: Much might be ſaid here, and to very great purpoſe; Ile ſay but this, and this I will ſay, becauſe I have obſerved nothing done or ſaid againſt theſe men hitherto: Theſe Catechiſers if evill, are as evill as are the evill Prieſts; nay more corrupting, if more can be, than are thoſe brutiſh Paſtours; Take them together, they are altogether corruptours, All as lepers, peſts and plagues in a common-wealth. So much to Schoolemaſters, that there may bê eyes ſet upon them: So alſo upon Maſters of Colledges, and Tutours there; Theſe are as were the former, If bad,
very bad. Children are (ſo they are now adayes in yeares and underſtanding) tranſmitted too ſoone to the Colledge, (a ſlippery place and in a ſlippery Lubricus locus & lubrica aetas: & facilis eſt in eâ prolapſio, Cic. age: (The Maſters there, and the Tutours admit theſe children, take the Parents money, and returne home their children, Aſſes Accipimus pecuniam & remittimus Aſinos.,) which was the old complaint; Parents may complaine more bitterly now; Our children, good when we ſent them to the Colledge Aula tua recipit, non ſacit bonos. Childs patr. c. 9., have ſpent our money there, and a pretious ſtock of time there, and have gained nothing but what tends to their eternall loſſe, corruption in their judgement and manners: O the ſad complaints this way! They ſhall be heard now: The Schoole and the Colledge it ſhall be viſited; high time; for there are malignant perſons many, and things not a few, I muſt point to theſe next.

Theſe are, I know not how many, but I will gather them-up into as ſhort a ſumme as I can. 1. Idols, and Idoll ſervices, with their appurtenances, all things belonging thereunto; all theſe are no ſooner ſet-up, adorned and ſerved, but a kingdome is made naked, and caſt-downe. 2. With theſe I muſt ranke blaſphemous pictures, and repreſentations hung up for ſignes Holy Lambe, ſalutation, &c. in many places. 3. Sacred names St Saviours. St. Faiths. given to our meeting places, commonly called Churches: To The Providence. Ships alſo, and to dayes, which we call holy: So we ſhould not doe, for we have but one Holy-day, and that is the LORDS Day; Other dayes there are, good dayes Eſth. 9. 22. dayes of praiſe and thankſgiving: and dayes of attonement, Faſting dayes, ſoule afflicting dayes: As for holy dayes, we know not where to find them, unleſſe in Romes Calender: and if we have them thence, then ſure we muſt caſt them-out of ours: And greater reaſon yet, why it ſhould be ſo; Becauſe old Latimer ſaid long ſince, The Devill has more ſervice done him upon one holy day, then he has on ten working dayes. The ſtrongeſt plea for keeping in theſe dayes is, That children and ſervants muſt have dayes for recreation. Yes, but let them not be called holy dayes. There ſhall be fit times appointed, wherein children and ſervants, yea and maſters too, may take meet and fitting recreations; [I meane by meet, ſuch as are recreations indeed; truly ſo called, comely for Chriſtians, ſuch as will indeed make them fit for warre:] But when we have ſaid all, or enough touching this grant or allowance, for lawfull recreations, and fit times for them, yet holy dayes, as we ignorantly,
or wickedly call them, ſhall be caſt-out, when all is done. 4. Bookes next (for ſo ſome miſ-call them) thoſe accurſed things, ſo filled-up with blaſphemies, hereſies; ſuch in-lets to atheiſme and prophaneneſſe, making roomth for Rome, and bringing-in Sodome to Jerūſalem; Theſe ſhall be caſt-out. To name the laſt firſt, Bookes (as they call them) which deny, that the Law of GOD has any coercive, or binding power; Man is a lawleſſe creature now; let him doe what he has a will to doe, GOD ſees him not; Though it be ſaid every where, they did evill in GODS ſight, yet GOD ſees no ſinne in His children. What Booke ſhall we heare of next? We need not queſtion it; A Booke denying the immortality of the ſoule, or affirming, That the ſoul does ſleepe with the body: I could tell the Reader how an Heathens booke was ſerved, who had written but doubtfully touching ſuch a matter; It is high time, &c. but I know my place and ſtation.

I might be large here, and yet ſay little, becauſe vile, treacherous and prophane Perſons are ſo many; and Things, defiling and deſtructive to a Nation, are, as many; Therefore, if I ſhould ſay more, yet. I ſhould not ſay the halfe; The halfe! when we ſhall heare what the Good Souldier will ſay, who will give us the life and uſe of all this, and ſpeake all he knowes faithfully touching his own heart, the Malignant lords there, (for every luſt there, not crucified is a lord there:) And Things, yet he cannot ſpeake the halfe of that evill, or malignancy, he finds within himſelfe, his own heart; A great part whereof he never knew; A great part of it, and of the evill therein, is to him as the terra incognita to us, There is a ſpace left for it in our Maps: So is there a prayer put-up by this man every day, for pardon of that evill, which he diſcernes not, but he knowes it is there. Therefore ſith it will be upon confeſſion anon, That there is more evill in one mans heart, than he can poſſibly take notice of; I forbeare to name any more Perſons or Things, which are to be found in a Kingdome, That I may take the more time to ſatisfie the Reader touching this objection, What is done againſt all theſe malignants, that are knowne, and diſcovered, for the cutting them off, or caſting-them forth of the Kingdome, that our Kingdome may be the LORDS Kingdome; that He may come-in and delight amongſt us? thus now, the objections runs-on.

Ob. There are many malignants not pointed at, The Blasphemer,

• am (as they call it) to plot-cats. Idolaters prevaile very much and hope to prevaile-yet more; v • e and light Prophets, and b •• i • iſh Prieſts have ſpread themſelves throughout the Land, and leavened the ſame: Treacherous men, Hoth ••
the Father and the ſon. Walker and 〈◊〉 are not out-off no not theſe, when Clement Walker A Check to the checker, give us a clear underſtanding in this matter, & makes a full anſwer. who was never good for himſelfe (yet all for himſelfe his private wealth) and worſe for the publike, hun • ed the blood of the Righteous, hath pe •• ioned for h •• head, who •• worth a thouſand of ours as like the father as can be • an orpament to his Countrey, pretious in the eyes and heart • of all that are godly; to whom yet the ſurrender of Briſtoll is an grievous as it ought to be: But they ſee Gods hand in it making way for his wrath at preſent, and for a wonderfull ſalvation to His people in His own time, ſhortly: Thus for maligna •• Perſons. And for Things, Idols are held up in many places ſtill; Idoll ſervices maintained ſtill; Abominable Bookes are thruſt ou • here and there yet not thruſt into the fier: Dayes are called holy ſtill; Perſons and Things are as they were: That is the ſumme of the objection, I cannot fr • me a ſhort anſwer to all this; We are upon the prime and firſt worke, the foundation work, for a ſtable and glorious building, we muſt goe gradually on-ward and expect with patience while the mountaines and Hills are made Zach. 4 7. and the head-ſtone is brought forth with ſhootings, crying. grace, grace unto it. So I proceed and anſwer. Firſt,

I. That indeed the cutting-off theſe mighty oppoſers ſhould be the firſt worke in the well poſturing a Kingdome; if that were
done, we ſhould deale well enough with others. True it is, there is not a drunkard in the pariſh, but he is a plague there; So is a ſwearer, a blaſphemer, a Sabbath-breaker, theſe are malignances, very
•• ſts and plagues to the places where they liue; But it cannot be conceived now that all theſe can be cut off. If ſome one man, whom the Scripture calls a
• oaring Lyon, and an evening wolf • , ſome one chiefe troubler of Iſraels peace, be out off; If one head, that has contrived, and plotted the down-fall of Iſraell, he ſtruck-off, even this is a good beginning, and according to rule; for the ſtriking off this one head, has weakened all hands, that were for the ſervice, and at the back of this Head. Saul had killed many Philiſtines, Thouſands. David has killed but one, but that one was Go ••• h, a Chieftaine amongſt the Philiſtines, Now heare what the women ſay, comming forth to meet King Saul; Saul hath ſl ••• his thouſands; 1 Sam. 18. 5. and David his ten thouſands. Marke that; Ten thouſand ſlaine in one Goliah. that huge Philiſtine Captaine of the H • ſt, that blaſphemed the Living GOD. I cannot doubt to ſay thi • now and to affirme it, That, when Goliah was ſlaine. Ten thouſand •••• ies were ſlaine at that time: for all the hoſt of the Philiſtines, Gods enemies, were diſcomfited on that day May, 12. 1641. when this work was done A wonderfull worke; for He, who only does wonders did that, that is my firſt anſwer.

II. It may ſuffice for preſent, If ſome Acha •• , troublers of the common-wealth and peace of Iſraell, be caſt-downe, when they cannot be caſt-out, which is done, by taking away their dominion, ſoveraigne power, and Lord-ſhip: As King Aſa removed his mother from her regency, from being Queene. And that, is a kind of death, the caſting the vile perſon-out of his throne, taking from him his Biſhoprick or office; this work is done alſo. It is ſo alſo, in caſting the Rebels-out of the heart; theſe are never caſt-out, but theſe are caſt-downe, ſubdued they are, put from their regency, out of their throne, they ſhall have no dominion, no power there; And that is a kind of death, as good as a caſting-out, or better, the good God ſo ordering it, when rebels are kept ſo under, that they ſhall rather doe good than hurt, cleane contrary to their nature, poyſonous and hurtfull, yet they ſhall doe the man good. But I have preveated my ſelfe, I anſwer,

A. That the Adverſaries are no fools, they are ſpeedy in conſultation, and quick for action; and if they have a victory they follow it; And though God has indeed mingled a perverſe ſpirit, amongſt them, ſome are for the Spaniſh faction, others for the French, yet all drive-on furiouſly to the ſame end; as Herod and Pilate, all are made friends, that they may unite their forces, as they againſt the Lord Chriſt, ſo theſe miſcreants againſt His faithfull ſervants all the world over.

B. It is a truth, that theſe prophane and wicked ones are wiſer in their generation than are the children of the reſurrection; and yet notable fooles for all that; for when they ſay, as their Fathers before them, come let us deale wiſely, let us make the people of the Exod. 1. 10. land ſerve with rigour, and their lives bitter with hard bondage, yet in this the Lord does befoole the Adverſary wonderfully. For firſt, the hotter the furnace of the Adverſaries rage is, the nearer God is to His people in that fornace: The more deſolate the Land is, the more it mourneth to the LORD Jer. 12. 11. The Lord will heare the mournings of his people. 2. The Adverſary does doe now no more, then what the Egyptian Magicians or Sorcerers did once and againe; They did but adde to their own plagues; they muſt drinke of thoſe waters which themſelves had turned into blood: So doe theſe Adverſaries now; they doe but helpe-forward their own affliction; work out their own deſtruction; lay deſolate their own land; conſume, deſtroy their own bleſſings, poyſon their owne ſprings; adde to their own plagues; turne their own waters into blood; corrupt their own mercies. A miſerable imployment! A moſt deceitfull worke, to poiſon thoſe waters which, when they have all done, theſe Egyptians alſo muſt drinke: and then be made dunken with the blood they have couſed, ſpew and fall and riſe no more. And when theſe deſtroyers have done all the miſchiefe, in the power of their hands to doe, yet ſhall they not be able to hurt the ſervants of the Lord, not able to impoveriſh them; notwithſtanding
all the Adverſaries rage, BREAD ſhall be given theſe ſervants: Their WATERS ſhall be ſure b. The concluſion Iſa. 33. 16. q Ac ſi diceret puris & integris Dei cultoribus nihil defuturum: panis euim & aquae nomine ſignificantur omnia, Cal. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . is, That theſe Abaddons, Appollyons, Theſe deſtroyers, doe now with one hand work-out their own deſtruction; and with the other hand, ſalvation to the Churches; ſo God befooles His Adverſaries for the preſent. I anſwer.

IV. We muſt not conceive that a Kingdome is not Poſtured till all the malignant Perſons and Things be caſt-out; that will never be; this caſting out theſe, is a worke ſtill doing but never done. It is very obſerveable, that Davids triumphant ſong, which he ſang unto the LORD in the day the Lord had delivered him out of the hand of all his enemies, and out of the hand of Saul, (who perſecuted 2 Sam. 22. 1. him with with an open face, before all Iſraell and before the Sun; and was as openly puniſhed:) This triumphant ſong was but Davids breathing immediately before he breathed forth his laſt words; now theſe be the laſt words of David; Immediately before, 2 Sam. 23. 1. we have that triumphat Pſalme, and not before. We may note this by the way; That this Poſturing worke, whether it be of a Nation, or of a Man only, is a mighty worke, long a doing, for it is never done; I meane, not compleated, no not till a little before we are ſpeaking our laſt words; But I ſhall reſerve this for a full Chapter, that we may the more fully ſee, how we may be miſtaken in the Parliaments worke, and in our own alſo, for this may be added hereunto;

V. That this cutting-off and thruſting-out Malignants, is indeeds, as the end is, whereof the Logicians ſay, That it is the firſt in our intention, propoſition and deſigne; but it is the laſt in execution: It is firſt intended, though it be laſt, yea, though it be never attained. The purging-out of Rebels is the end, the reſult of all Conſultations, Acts and Ordinances, all theſe reſolve and empty themſelves in thither: all counſells and Acts have a tendency thereunto. It is true, we ought to be heaving at theſe Perſons and Things as we doe at ſome indigeſted bits, which clogg the ſtomack and oppreſſe nature, not ſtrong enough to caſt-them out: So in the Body politick. But there muſt be an endeavour to the utmoſt to caſt-out theſe oppreſſours. And yet the Lord may ſuffer theſe to be too hard for His people, for mighty reaſons; To exerciſe His ſervants graces in their war-fare, their Faith, their Humility, their Patience.

2. neſſe, their ſhame before all the Chriſtian world: Their judgement li • greth not: and their dam • ation ſlumbreth not 1. Pet. 2. 5. The •••
vants of the Lord can waite the Lords time, touching this matter, therefore I anſwer.

VI. Though the firſt work in the building-up and forſifying a kindgome, is ever to throw-downe to the ground all accurſed Things, Altare and Images, which, no ſooner made and ſet-up, but • Kingdome is made naked, ſet under foote, caſt-down and undone
• rod. •• . 23. 2 Ch • o. 18. 19.:Though this was the firſt worke, which the Pr • nee • . Prieſts and people of old, ſet their hands and hearts unto, even the breaking in pieces theſe accurſed Things, and throwing them down [For very notable it is, how they uſed theſe dunghill things, they never left hacking, and cutting, and hewing and deſtroying, and • utning, and drowning till they had utterly deſtroyed them all, Chro. 31. 1. I
Though I ſay, this was the firſt worke, yet we reade, The high places were not taken away, [that is, thoſe high places, where they ſerved The high places where the people ſacrificed to falſe gods were taken away. 2 Chro. 17. 6. The other were not taken away, 2 Chro. 20. 13. the true God after a falſe manner,] theſe were not taken away: And the reaſon is given, for as yet the people had not prepared their hearts unto the God of their fathers. It relates to us fully; Theſe high things, that doe offend the people of God are not taken away; and for the very ſame reaſon. Perhaps, nay paſt all queſtion, every thing, that exalts it ſelf, even in their own hearts, is not caſt-downe, therefore theſe high things are not taken away: I ſhould be large at this point, but I will proceed.

VII. In the next place this may be noted; that this is our duty, to vow and proteſt againſt all theſe accurſed Perſons and Things; to enter into a curſe for the caſting of them forth; And having done ſo, having entred into covenant, having lifted-up the hand, and ſubſcribed the name for the caſting forth all theſe, we muſt doe as our vowes are, uſe all meanes for the purging our ſelves and the Land: That is all we can doe, our duty, uſe the meanes earneſtly as men inflamed with zeale, let the Lord alone with the reſt: In the Neh. 3. 20. laſt place then,

VIII. We muſt not make haste; we muſt waite the Lords time: which is not yet: For 1, The Lord will, by the greatneſſe of His Exod. 15. 16. power, make His enemies as ſtill as a ſtone: But He will firſt ſilence the murmurings of His people; He will ſtill the ſurgings and riſings in his ſervants hearts firſt. 2. The Lord will not doe it till ſuch a time, when His people are ſo low, and their enemies ſo high, that the fetching-up of his people, and the caſting-down their enemies requires the putting-forth the Greatneſſe of GODS Power. 3. The Lord will not deliver His people till they be fit, and meet, and prepared for deliverance; not till then. When He takes off the yoake, He will make His people goe upright; He will not remove the plaiſter, till the wound be throughly healed; He is now ſearching and tenting our wounds to the bottome, which were putrified and very corrupt: The Lord will not give His people their Lands, Houſes, Liberties, &c. for their corruptions to feed-upon any more; or to feed their corruptions, to be fewell to luſts; He will kill His peoples luſts now, they ſhall raigne in them no more, Amen. 4. The Lord will purge-out the Rebels all; it is His promiſe Eze. 20. 38.; But he will purge the hearts of His ſervants firſt. The houſe of

Jacob ſhall be a fier, and the houſe of Joſeph a flame; and the houſe of Eſau for ſtubble, (i. e.) The Church of God ſhall devoure all Obad. 18. their enemies, There ſhall not be any remaining of the houſe of Eſau, for the Lord hath ſpoken it. But this ſhall not be till the ſons of Jacob be purified, till the Lord has purely purged away their droſſe, and taken away their tinne Iſai. 1. 25. The Lord is now upon His Refining worke, and for that great end, His fier is in Zion, and His fornace in Jeruſalem Iſa. 31. 9.. Theſe children of Belial, moſt abominable perſons, that have broken (all the yoakes) the Lawes of Heaven and Earth, have caſt-off Piety, and humanity altogether; men (if I may call them men) of no uſe, Deut. 13. 13. Men of Beliall, Homines nequiſſimi quaſi abſque • ugo, qui jugum legis Dei excuſſerunt: vel qui nullius frug is & utilitatis ſunt. Men of leſſe uſe then is their owne dung. B • xt. muſt yet do their Lord this ſervice, they muſt ſerve Him as ſcullions, to purge, to whiten Dan. 11. 35., and to purifie the veſſels appointed for honour; And when that work is done, the fier from Jacob, and the flame from Joſeph ſhall kindle upon theſe Adverſaries: and devoure them. The concluſion is, Idols and Idoll men, and Idoll ſervices ſhall be all caſt-out, when every thing, that exalts it ſelfe in His childrens hearts, ſhall be caſt-down, and ſubdued (according to the line of men.) This ſhall certainely be, but His people muſt waite, and they can waite and leave God to His own time, uſing the means, which are mighty (through God) to bring to paſſe all this. Theſe meanes ſhall be mentioned particularly and inſiſted upon. But now we muſt ſee how this good Souldier has quitted himſelfe at this high point, and acted his part againſt theſe Malignants, Perſons and Things within his own breaſt.

div.head: § I. The first worke in well Poſturing a mans ſelfe, is,

argument.p: The ſubduing Malignant ſelfe, and caſting-down Malignant Things. A wonderfull worke and glorious, for which the man admires God, and freegrace, I raiſes God while he has any being; and toward his brethren he is pittifull and uſefull as a faithfull ſteward of what he has received.

div.p:
NOw we will take a view of a well Poſtured Souldier. An ordinary ſight, you will ſay, an eaſie worke for one man to poſture himſelfe. Whether ſo or not, comes now to be conſidered: And after due conſideration, it will appeare, That it is an eaſier matter, to ſubdue Kingdomes, to conquer Nations, than it is, for this man to take them captives, whoſe captive he was: To rule
over his oppreſſors Iſa. 14. 2., (that is) to conquer his corruptions, the Malignants in his own heart; to ſubdue ſelfe there. Let us take notice, by the way, what this ſelfe is; A ſtubborne ſtiffe piece, like an iron ſinnew, it will rather break than bend: It will perſwade a man rather than ſtoope, to fall, though he is but to ſtoope to Law and Right Reaſon. To maintaine its will, it will hazard all its peace on earth, even a Kingdome there, yea and a Crowne in Heaven; ſuch a perverſe perſon is ſelfe. And yet, if he has ſet his eye upon ſelfe-righteouſneſſe, it will ſo glaze in his eyes, that he will thinke himſelfe ſome great one Acts 8. 9., rich and wanting nothing, when indeed, he is wretched, and miſerable, and poore, and blind and naked Rev. 3. 17.. This ſelfe is ſubdued and abhorred. By what meanes, in whoſe ſtrength, what a worke it is, and how long a doing, will be pointed at in due time. Now we will heare, what the man ſpeakes in his confeſſions, he is large there, and he cares not who heares him; His confeſſion is; That all this Malignancy in Perſon and in Things (we cannot reckon up particulars,) that all this, this Malignant perſon is himſelfe; and Malignant things are as himſelfe: He will confeſſe, That he is well acquainted with Malignant Lords ever ſince he knew himſelfe: and that Malignant things troubled him more, than all the Malignants in the Kingdome, for thoſe offended his God moſt of all. Certainely thus he ſayes, That there is a desperate wickedneſſe in his heart; and an J •• . 17. inconceiveable deceit there. And ſurely, if we conſider well on it, we ſhall ſay every man of himſelfe, as St Paul did, O wretched man that I am. Here is no inconſiſtency now in words, A good man, and yet ſelfe in him, for man is ſuppoſed in a Chriſtian: And where man is, there ſelfe is more or leſſe, and that is himſelfe, and Homo ſupponitur in Chriſtiano. much evill there is. If we ſee it not in the fruit, yet there it is in the ſeed and roote, as we ſhall clearely diſcerne preſently: for this is manifeſt to all, who have eyes to ſee, or an heart to underſtand themſelves, That all the malice we have been ſpeaking of, ſo mightily oppoſing the good of the great Body, all this is but a glaſſe, for every man to ſee himſelfe in; the very modell and repreſentation of every mans own heart See • ts treaſury opened, Mat. 15. 19. Mark. 7. 2 • .; he ſees his own heart there, and image as he ſees himſelfe in his child, or as he ſees a face in water anſwering a face; In a word, This man, beholding the whole world lying in wickedneſſe, does behold therein, as in a mirrour, a world of
wickedneſſe in himſelfe. This wickedneſſe, malignance we may call it, doth not breake-out and ſhew its ſelfe in all alike, but there this malice is in the roote and ſeed, and fomenting cauſe of all that, which we have taken notice of. And the very diſcerning hereof, that ſo it is, is the firſt ſtep and degree a man takes in the way and method of maintaining his Militia, the well poſturing himſelfe. For now he ſees, that the worke is of abſolute neceſſity, it muſt be done. 1. He firſt diſcovers an enmity, an oppoſition from nature within himſelfe, to the work of Reformation; his heart flies from it as from death, for indeed it is a kind of death; and nature, which is ſelfe, is as oppoſite to it, as that Iſraelite was who counted Reforming a killing Exod. 2. 14.. Nature not renewed will oppoſe this with all its might. And if the heart doe let the Bill paſſe for the compleating of it, it is becauſe it is over-powred; becauſe the thunder and haile, ſome ſtrong motions and feares are upon the ſpirits; when thoſe are blowne-over, ſelfe will be ſelfe ſtill; strong holds will ſtand up ſtill; ſtrong reaſonings to maintaine all the Idols, the abominable things there; All this will be till ſelfe be overpowred by an Almighty power, and ſpoken unto by a ſtrong hand Iſa. 8. 11.: Then ſelfe is maſtered, then there is a yeilding-up the ſtrong holds, there is no more Reaſonings
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . 2 Cor. 10. 5. with ſelfe for the maintaining of ſelfe that Malignant perſon: or Malignant things, Idols or Idoll ſervices. True it is, theſe Malignants are not caſt-forth all, no nor quite ſubdued all: Though the Body of ſin be mortified, yet the life thereof is prolonged, a and the power thereof is (as the Kingdome ſpoken of by Daniel) partly ſtrong and partly broken; Lord-like-luſts, or Dan. 7. 17. luſt-like-Lords will ſtorme his ſoul ſometimes, and force a reentry. And the Lord ſuffers it to be ſo, for mighty reaſons, which I muſt reſume, in part, as pertinent to this place as to the other: for as it is in the great Kingdome, ſo it is in the little kingdome within a mans own breaſt: The mans warfare muſt be maintained, he muſt be kept waking and watchfull; he muſt ſee how important a matter it is, and of what infinite concernment, That he keep cloſe to the God of his ſtrength, and his ſalvation, that is firſt. And

2. This wickedneſſe is in the heart but it is hated there; luſts are there, but not Lords there; they have no dominion there; Theſe are put downe from their Regency; he has prayed againſt them three times, and as often covenanted againſt them. Yea looke what
malice or evill there is, which the man cannot meete with nor caſt-out (all he cannot) that remainder, he has dealt with it as the Jewes of old did, the night before their great feaſt, with their leaven, they ſearched diligently for it into every corner and cranny of the houſe, as this man ſearcheth his heart; and what they could not find-out they did curſe and abominate, ſaying, never more ſowre our lumpe: So this man deales with ſelfe and its Idols, he makes diligent ſearch after them to throw-them-out; what he cannot caſt-out, not find-out (for ſelfe has many darke corners within its ſelfe, which mans eye could never peirce into) yet he pryeth into the bottome and root of all, and this he doth curſe and abominate, ſaying, never fruit grow thereon: And what fruit there will grow, he prayeth it may be as an untimely fruit, which never ſaw the ſunne. And ſo what he cannot overcome, he does hate and abhorre. And mighty reaſon why he ſhould ſo doe, abominate and accurſe that ſo fruitfull ſeed within him: for had not the LORD, according to His ſervants prayer, kept downe that Roote from putting forth its ſelfe, according to its activeneſſe; had He not reſtrained that corruption, not ſuſfering it to bring forth according to its fruitfulneſſe: Had the Lord ſuffered this cockatrice to broode-upon and hatch her eggs; had He left this ſinning ſinne, within the man, to bring forth its own curſed fruit, then had this man been as vile as the vileſt, as proud as the proudeſt Prelate; as Idolatrous as are he and ſhe, who lift-up their hearts to the moſt lying vanities; as cruell and as bloody as are the Tabernacles of Robbers; This man might have beene ſwearing, curſing, blaſpheming, tearing, piercing the Name of his God, amongſt the Iriſh rogues, and Engliſh monſters; This man might have beene in the Kings Army, a Prince there, (by nature he is no better then they) A child of wrath as others: Epheſ. 2. 3. If the Lord had not been gratious unto him, added more grace, made him to differ, 1. Cor. 4. 7. he had been as one of them, a mighty hunter before the LORD, as a roaring Lyon, or a ſhee Beare, or an evening Wolfe, ſuch an one he had been, if the Lord had not overpowred his corruption, made him to differ from another wrought gratiouſly in him, and for him, for which he admireth the Lord in His free-grace, and bleſſeth His holy Name. The Lord has wrought a mighty worke in him, faith, by which he has overcome the world, eſcaped the pollutions there, the luſts of the fleſh the
ſnares of the world, a world of wickedneſſe, (a Grace to be admired) by which he ſtood-out againſt the gates of Hell; overpowred power its ſelfe, principalities and powers; how admirable all this? This raiſeth the heart,firſt,

1. In admiration of free grace; And you, that were dead in trespaſſes and ſins; What more? that is all we find in the Originall; Epheſ. 2. 1. In our Engliſh we reade this more, hath He quickened: but in the Greeke only this, And you, that were dead in treſpaſſes and ſins: A mercy to be admired; has He quickened! That is ſwallowed-up with admiration; for it is more admirable then was the making of the world, or creating of light. There is more in this, HAS HE QUICKENED! Therefore ſwallowed-up with Job 6. 3. admiration, as Jobs words were with exceeding griefe: You has He quickened! dead as well as others, whom yet He left in the ſame death, to periſh in their ſins: You has He quickened. It is all one as if the Apoſtle had ſaid, And you has He juſtified, ungodly though you were; For you the Father has given His Son; and the Son has given Himſelfe to reconcile you, and to bring you neare, farre off once, and an enemy though you were: And you has He loved with an eternall love, becauſe He loved you (there is Deut. 7. no other reaſon of His love,) He ſet His heart upon you, and paſſed over others Thouſands, no worſe than your ſelfe! And you has He ſeene in your blood, and He ſaid at ſuch a time as that, to you, it is a time of love, live live: Twice repeated, as well to ſhew the greatneſſe of His power, as the riches of His mercy. O admirable! He has obſerved thy way, wherein thou wenteſt on frowardly, as others did, yet to thee He ſaid, I will heale thee; Ezek. 16. 8. ſo He forgave thy ſin and healed thee Iſa. • 7. 18. All this, ſo admired of this ſoule, is contained in this, HAS HE QUICKNED!

2. And now that God has dealt ſo with His ſervant, ſo viſited him in his low eſtate, quickned him, brought him from death to life; now his heart is filled with admiration, and ſo is his mouth filled with praiſe: All without him, all within him, are called upon to praiſe His Holy Name. For what? The man cannot expreſſe that, he is ſwallowed-up in an ocean of love, from everlaſting unto everlaſting; and now he will lengthen out his praiſe, wider than the Heavens, even to everlaſting. His Lord and his God has regarded him, has kept him; has held him by the hand in the moſt ſuppery ages and places; how many puddles might he have fallen into?
how many mires might he have wallowed-in? had not the Lord held him upright; O how does his ſoule meditate praiſes! how does he ſtudy Mictams, Hallelujahs; and holineſſe! O with what Selahs, with what exaltation of heart and voice, does he ſing the 103 Pſalme, Bleſſe the LORD, O my ſoul: you ſhall heare him out-anon, with what elevation of ſpirit will he ſing this, for it is his triumphant ſong, which he will ſing immediately before he is breathing forth his laſt words: Then and not till then, for all the time before he muſt be in a warfaring condition, as the Church is, and it is beſt for him and the Church both: Yet aſſured he is as all the faithfull are, that nothing ſhall doe him hurt now, every thing ſhall doe him good, even his worſt enemies, and he ſhall be more then conquerour at laſt; But not till immediately before his laſt words, then he will ſpeake to the Lord the words of this ſong, The Lord has delivered m • out of the hands of all mine enemies, and out of the hand of my ſelfe; His name be praiſed, exalted, magnified for ever and ever, Amen. The time of his 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is not yet, but yet he knowes the foundation ſtands ſure, he knowes to whom he has committed his ſoule; he has a ſure ſtanding, he is ſetled upon the Rock: he ſtands and ſhall ſtand like a wall of braſſe againſt the blaſt of the terrible ones, and laughs at their ſtorming; he is at peace with his God, and is not afraid of the beaſts of the earth; Job 5. The Lord is his portion, and his cup runneth-over; he is poore, perhaps, in eſteeme of others, but he is rich in faith; he is as a man that has nothing, and yet poſſeſſing all things. The Lord has ſatisfied him with the fatneſſe of His houſe, even with the richeſt mercies; He has enough indeed, for he has God, and with Him all things.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Gen. 33. 11. He is a contented man; and well he may be content, for he has the fountaine: If the ſtreames be cut-off, intercepted for a time, no matter, he is ſure of the I ountaine. The Sonne of Righteouſneſſe ſhines upon his tabernacle; then the night is day to him, for the Sun makes the day, though neither Moone nor Stars appeare, (i. e. that is) God is all to him without the creature: the creature nothing to him without God. God is his, therefore is His ſervants mouth wide open to His praiſe. But you will aske; Are there no ſtormes in his ſoule, no clouds over his ſpirit at any time? Yes ſure, many times, you may heare of that anon; Now,

3. Behold we how this ſervant of the Lord carrieth himſelfe toward
his fellow ſervants; he entreats them, he beſeecheth them by the mercies of Chriſt, and, knowing the terrours of the LORD, he perſwadeth with all meekneſſe, inſtructing thoſe, that oppeſe themſelves, 2 Tim. 2. 25, 26. if GOD, peradventure, will give them repentance. He is tender-hearted, forgiving another even as GOD for Chriſts ſake Eph. 4. 32. Coloſſ. 3. 13. hath forgiven him: He is a friend to his enemies, if they curſe him, he will bleſſe them: for there are three conſiderations very mighty to prevaile with him this way. 1. That God, for Chriſts-ſake, hath forgiven him much, he knowes not how much; ſhould not he forgive that little, thoſe few pence, (ſuch and ſo ſmall are mans offences againſt man in reference to thoſe againſt God.) 2. That the Lord juſtified the ungodly. 3. That the night before He was betrayed, Rom. 4. 5, 5, 6. He made a Feaſt for His enemies, even them who pierced Him: He gave His blood for thoſe, who had an hand in ſhedding •• blood. This is a melting conſideration, and engageth the heart ſtrongly, to give and forgive; to beare and forbeare with all long ſuffering and meekneſſe. We have enough touching this matter. I come now to conſider the meanes, whereby this Souldier has thus poſtured himſelfe, has attained to this height of ſpirit, which is obſerved in nothing more, than in his humble carriage, and Chriſtian fortitude. But we muſt obſerve it firſt in the proceedings of Parliament, the ſteps and wayes they went in well-Poſturing the Kingdome.

div.head: CHAP. II.

p.hi: The prime and chiefe meanes to Poſture a Kingdome, Prayer and Faſting;

argument.p: How prevailing Prayer is, It does all, it commands God, and God commands deliverance; Prayer and Pr • iſe goe together. The Churches falls and diſconifitures, particularly that at Newarke, matter • f • nfinite uſe to the Church, and of high pr • iſe.

div.p: VVE have heard what the Nobles and Worthies have done towards the compleating this great worke, the ſtrengthening or well Poſturing the Kingdomes: We proceed as they did not in their own ſtrength. It is not all created ſtrength, that can doe ſuch works as theſe; remove ſuch Perſons and ſuch Things;

They ſought forth and applied themſelves to ſuch meanes, whereby they might bring-in God to their helpe; They did after the old manner, which never failed the Church, they commanded the City firſt, then the whole Nation as Eſther the Jewes, faſt ye for us, we Eſt • r 4. 16. will faſt alſo: They knew, there is a kind of malignant ſpirit which will not be caſt-out by any other meanes: They tooke hold of the Almighties Arme; they wraſtled with Him for this thing; they prayed, they wept, and would not riſe from their knees without •
Hoſ. 12. 4. bleſſing; And ſo they prevailed for the caſting-out their dead, Idoll men and Idoll ſervices; ſo they ſhall root-out them, who have rooted-in themſelves ſo long: So have they throwne downe their Altars, and caſt-out thoſe abominable ſervices. They wept and they prayed, and ſo they became a prevailing people with their God upward to this day, and ſo they were delivered; So they have ſtricken-through many mighty men; So they have wounded •••
heads over many (Dioceſſes) Countries. Prayer [I name that only becauſe it is the principall and chiefe worke upon that ſolemne day: faſting does but helpe to make the prayer more ſpiritfull; It weakens the body, that it may ſtrengthen the ſpirit, and heighten it; Faſting is, as I may ſay, the emptying duty; It ſhewes a man, openly, a mortified man, leſſer then a crumb of bread, and drop of drinke: It makes him nothing-worth in himſelfe, yea worſe than nothing, an emptying duty: Prayer is a filling duty, it fills-up as faſt as the other has emptied, we ſhall ſee how efficacious prayer is.] Prayer gained the in-come and harveſt of all that ſpirituall ſeed, the ſervants of the Lord, now departed from us, were ſowing all their life long: now that harveſt comes-in. Time would faile me, to tell what the people of God have done by prayer. Prayer has done all, which has been done, for God forbid that we ſhould ſpeake of any thing, which the Lord hath not wrought for, and with His people; And nothing He has wrought, but He has been ſought unto, and enquired of for that thing. It is true the Lord hath given His people the greateſt mercies, which they prayed not for, ELECTION before Time; His SON in the fullneſſe of Time: All deliverances ſince are the fruit of the Churches prayers, though they have exceeded her prayers, and her hopes: Prayer obtained a Parliament, brought them together and their hearts-up to the worke; and prayer has kept them together, has ſifted them as
wheate in a ſeive, blew away the chaffe, and not a wheate-corne loſt; Prayer ſtrengthened the hearts and hands of the Worthies in throwing-downe the Biſhops; It ſtrengthened the Biſhops hands againſt themſelves, for the throwing themſelves out of the Lords Houſe, and into priſon; Prayer caſt forth the bruitiſh Paſtours, and ſervices like themſelves; And prayer will ſtrengthen the right hand of the Lord with His ſervants, that they ſhall doe more and more valiantly touching that matter. Prayer ſhall, as it has done, bring to paſſe great matters; But not in its own ſtrength (for This is more fully explained in an Anſwer to a blaſphemo • s Rime from Oxford. See Good newe •
from all quarters brought unto us upon the wing of prayer. in its ſelfe it has no more ſtrength than has an Oaten-ſtraw, but) as it cloſeth with a Promiſe in the hand of a Redeemer, Who is ſtrong This is more fully explained in an Anſwer to a blaſphemo • s Rime from Oxford. See Good newe •
from all quarters brought unto us upon the wing of prayer.; in That ſtrength the Worthies of the Lord have leaped over walls, and skipped over mountaines, theſe have been made plaines before them. I muſt paſſe-over here what Reſcues His people have had, what ſtrange deliverances! what diſcoveries the Lord has made of His right hand, with His people, and againſt His Adverſaries, confounding them in their pride and bloody deſignes; It is the Lords doing and marvellous in our eyes! But He was ſought unto for theſe things: And though we paſſe-over many things, we muſt not paſſe-over this; That Prayer made void a terrible and bloody Commiſſion, To cut and to ſlay all that had an hand with David (all the faithfull in the Land:) and to deſtroy a mother in Iſraell. Prayer turned all the contrary way, It brake the ſnare, diſappointing the hope of the Malignants; laid-open the pit, as deepe as Hell, and hurled ſome chiefe Actors thereinto; And this opened the mouth of the righteous yet wider, made their prayer more fervent, ſo that it quenched a fiery-flying-ſerpent, ſome called it a Proclamation, to cut off all ſuccours from the City of God; Theſe haile ſtones and coales of fier, prayer diſſolved, and quenched: The heate of the Adverſaries diſpleaſure was quite extinct by prayers fervency. Prayer did the like exploit at Gloceſter; It quenched all the Granadoes caſt into that City: ſo as theſe had no more power, notwithſtanding all their ſtorming a whole Moneth together, but to kill a Pigge: Nor had the Adverſary a Legion though he was, done ſo much, not killed that Pigge, but by order from Heaven. In Judah is God knowne, His name is great in Iſraell; His dwelling
• ſal. 76. place is in Zion. (Proceed,) There brake He the arrowes of the bow, the ſhield and the ſword, and the battle. There! Where? In His
Tabernacle in Zion, there dwelling and walking with His people, and they converſing with their God, in His ordinances. There and then He brake the arrowes and the bow; there and then He turned away the ſtorming Adverſary; then He raiſed the ſiege. When? On the ſeventh of September (it is written,) on that day, when the Inhabitants of Gloceſter were praying and (with
• ehoſhaphat) praiſing: when the Adverſary was ſtorming and ready to devoure, then were the inhabitants, as that good King, praying and praiſing; Praiſe the LORD, for His mercy endureth for ever; It followes;2 Chro. 20. 21. And when they began to ſing and to praiſe, the Lord, &c. So it followed then and now alſo, for when they were praying and praiſing, then the Lord brake the arrowes and the bow, then He plucked the bridle in the Adverſaries mouth, and away He turned him, and where is the fury of the oppreſſour? Praiſe ye the LORD for His mercy endureth for ever.

1. That our enquities, buſie and over-haſty thoughts, and deviding cares, about Reformation (the well Poſturing a Kingdome, The time when it will be) are moſt vaine, and diſquieting to no purpoſe. Let us doe our duty, our own work, be carefull about nothing but this, that we doe our worke: or, if we cannot worke, as we commonly call worke, if we have not heads for Counſell, nor hands for Action, yet, let us doe our duty; let us make our PRAYER to our GOD; that wheeles all about; that does the worke. And impoſſible it is, that a Reformation, a child of ſo many Prayers and Teares, (the Prayers of all the faithfull, that are or have been in the world,) That a child of ſo many Prayers (as was ſaid of Austin unto his mother) ſhould periſh; Periſh! No, nor ſtick at the birth a minute longer, than as the ſticking-there ſhall make for the exaltation of Gods arme, in the pulling-of it-forth: and the filling-top-full the hearts of His people, with comfort in its ſeaſon, after they have ſuffered a little, that is the firſt obſervation.

2. That their Excellencies, the chiefe Commanders by Land and Sea; All the Nobles and Worthies of both Kingdomes, (more deare unto us then the blood in our veines) doe march-on under the ſafeſt conduct, which is, the banner of the LORD spread over their heads by the unceſſant prayers of all the faithfull in the world: There is not a man, woman or child in the world, that can pray,
But they ſay, concerning this Hoſt of God: We wiſh you proſperity in the name of the Lord: All the bleſſings in the Booke of God, 1 Sam, 25. 29. fall downe upon you every man, as the dew upon the graſſe: And for their enemies, them, let the Angell of the Lord ſcatter and ſlingout as out of the middle of a ſling.

3. The ſervants of the Lord doe aſcribe all unto God; All is a Napthaly, a child of Prayer; ASKT OF GOD; and the gift of GOD; And that ſweetens, the mercy the deliverance; And, if it be a croſſe-blow, it ſweetens that too, it makes it a bleſſing, as it followes preſently. They write upon all their walls, Salvation, and upon their gates, their out-lets and in-lets, they write Praiſe, Iſa. • o. 18. (i. e.) they aſcribe all to God. The Adverſaries of the Lord not ſo; As Saul before them, they never get any Advantage againſt David, but by Treacheries, wiles, fine devices, curled policies, the depths of Satan: Therefore when David (the faithfull of the Land) are, the enemie thinks, delivered-up into his hands, then he does as Saul did, bleſſe the Ziphites, a vile, treacherous people, 1 Sam. 23. 21. whom GOD curſeth.

4. The ſervants of the Lord doe not truſt to an Hoaſt of men, though a thouſand thouſand for multitude; (ſuch an Hoſt Jehoſhaphat 2 Chro. 17. had) yet as he, ſo they doe truſt in God, give themſelves to prayer, that ſo they may bring Him down to their help: They ſet their eye as ſtedfaſtly Heaven-ward, as if they had no ſtrength upon earth, for they know, they are not delivered by ſuch a ſtrength Pſal. 33. 16.. They on the other ſide, the Adverſaries of the Lord, put all their truſt in multitudes, as if they were gods not men; ſpirit not fleſh. And if theſe faile, as faile they muſt, then their hearts faile, and ſhake within them, as a leafe ſhaken with the wind; And it muſt be ſo, not poſſible it ſhould be otherwiſe, for they cannot pray; An infinite diſadvantage if it were thought on! When the Adverſaries Army failes (that is all fleſh) all failes him; when the creature leaves him, all leaves him, for he cannot pray. But when the arme of fleſh failes the righteous, it is no more, but what they expected, and they cling the faſter to the arme of God, who ſtrengtheneth moſt when the arme of fleſh is leaſt in ſight: When all the creatures are gone, yet God is not gone, nay then he is neareſt, for then Prayer is Iſa. 6. 6. powred out unto him (but dropped forth before) and then they can lift-up their heads in expectation of a glorious
redemption at hand, for they can pray; An infinite advantage.

5. Gods ſervants praiſe God for their falls; for theſe tend to the compleating of their great and glorious victory at the laſt. In the meane time, they fall-low before their God, and riſe-high in Quando duplicantur la • er • s ven • t Moſes, Auget certamina quando liberab. t, Curyſolog. their faith, which aſſureth them, the lower they are, the nearer their exaltation is; and the higher their Adverſaries are, the deeper their fall will be; and ſo I come to that which the Malignants make their jeere and ſcorne now, The diſcomfiture the ſervants of the LORD had at NEW ARKE, 22d of March: They would have me put it downe in my Catalogue, and make it matter of praiſe. God forbid we ſhould forget it; It is a matter of excellent uſe, then ought it to be matter of high Praiſe. In every thing give Phil. 4. 6. 1 Theſ. 5. 15. thanks, much more for ſuch a mercy, which ſhall, through the Churches prayers, tend greatly to the fortifying and eſtabliſhing her people. Certainely the ſervants of the Lord, they that are praying on the mount, and they that are ſighting in the valley, all theſe ſhall receive more good from their diſcomfitures, eſpecially that at Newarke, than from all the victories they have had this laſt yeare. Therefore mighty reaſons there are, why the Church ſhould make it matter of high Praiſe. Firſt;

1. The Lord ſhewed much love towards His people in that diſcomfiture. Love! You will ſay it was a fruit of Gods Anger, and ſore diſpleaſure againſt His people. Indeed it was; But marke we, That which cauſeth GODS Anger toward His beloved ones is LOVE
Erga 〈◊〉 ſuos • oc 〈◊〉 bile eſt, ••• Divin • cauſa amor eſt. : This is wonderfull, but ſo it is, and that is one mighty reaſon why the Church ſhould render Praiſe: for,

2. It is a reſolved caſe, If the arme of fleſh be ſtrong, the ſervants of the Lord will-beare-up themſelves confidently upon it: Then the Lord knaps it aſunder as eaſily as you can breake burnt ſlaxe. The Lord muſt be praiſed for this, for this is pure love: He will have His ſervants leane upon their B • loved and none other; The Lord will breake them, and breake them, and breake them, till they ſay, Thou art our Rock, our ſtrong arme every morning, and our ſalvation every night; in whom we can boaſt all the day long. This is their prayer & matter of their praiſe; So the Lord will bringup the hearts of His people to Himſelf, no matter though He beats them downe, and layes them like wormes upon the earth: So He b • ings-up their hearts to cloſe with His arme, no matter, though the
Lord bring His people ſo low, even to whiſper out of the duſt.

3. Great matter of Praiſe for that discomfiture at Newarke: for the ſervants of the Lord (ſimple hearted men, as were Eliakim, and Shebnah, and Joah 2 King. 18. 26., theſe expected a favour from Rabſhakeh: So theſe) treated (the Malignants ſay and ile take their ſaying) for their lives, liberties, eaſe of tender conſciences, with the Prince of Robbers, Prince Robert, a prophane and wicked man, A price of clay mingled with blood
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ., as was ſaid of Nero, who had caſt off humanity; Mighty only to doe miſchiefe, and to ſatisfie his own luſts, (as was ſaid of another Criſpinu • monſtrum null • virtute redemptu • , Aviiijs aeger ſoldque libidine fortis, Juv. Sat. 4 • .) The ſervants of the Lord (as Malignants doe report) treated with this Prince, and his murtherers, the vileſt and moſt abominable perſons, moſt notorious all over the Chriſtian world for their faithleſſe, treacherous, horrid and horrible-butcheries, The friends of God expected mercy from the enemies of God! Now the ſervants of the Lord will for ever walke more humbly with their God, and humbly ſeeke His face: for He is mercifull. They will underſtand now, That the mercies of the wicked are cruell, that is, none at all Pro. 10. 12. Plane nullae. , Ah Lord! Will the Lord ſuffer His ſervants to lye proſtrate at the foote of Rabſhekah, to begge a favour at his hands: Yes; That they may underſtand at the length, how vaine their expectation is from man, but never vaine from God; Praiſed be His Name.

4. Great matter of praiſe as of prayer; We pray that the Lord would make His ſervants meete for deliverance, and His enemies fit for deſtruction. This is the only way, which the Lord takes, this caſting-downe fits the ſervants of the Lord for their riſing-up, which ſhall be the higher, the lower their fall was: And this rage of the Adverſary fills-up their meaſures, heightens their deſtruction, for in proportion to their rage now ſhall their judgement be anon: It ſhall reach unto Heaven and be lifted-up unto the skies: Jer. 51. 9. Certainely the Church could not have wanted any of all this, which has fallen-out at Briſtoll, &c. nor the diſcomfiture at Newarke, Through their prayer, all this ſhall turne to their advantage and furtherance of the Goſpell. That and this will make the ſtinke of the Kings Campe come-up into the noſtrils of all the Chriſtian world; if they are not an abomination yet, they will be ſhortly; every man will come-out againſt them with their ſword in their hand (without hire of money) as once they did againſt grievous
wolves. The people of the Land have been diſspirited hitherto, now the Lord has taken a courſe to put ſpirit and life into His people. The great whore, that ſhe might put back her deſtruction, and reprieve her judgement, may give faire words ſometimes after her manner, and yeeld farre to accommodate a peace. It ſhall not ſerve her turne; The arrowes of the ſtrong-ones ſhall be ſharpe in the hearts of all her friends; and the ſword of the Lord ſhall eate her fleſh and then ſhe ſhall be burnt with fire Rev. 17. 16. 19. 18.. In the next place, we are aſſured, That,

7. The Builders of the waſt places, the repairers of the breaches, I meane the Parliament, and Aſſemblies, all the faithfull in all three Kingdomes, all theſe will worke high now; Their words, and their actions, and their heart, and their faith, all will be upon the wing now; They will worke (as he at Jeruſalems wall) earnestly, Neh. 3 20. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
(i. e.) inflamedly, with a zeale boyling hot for the houſe of God, for the Cauſe of God; And yet they will not truſt to the Cauſe, though as good a Cauſe as ever was truſted to in the world; But this truſt to the goodneſſe of a Cauſe, is a greater Idoll than was that in Cheapſide, in the Chappell or in the Cloſet, for that was ſetup
in the heart: Therefore God has ſmitten it, and broken it in Antient times, and ſo upward to this day: And yet He has maintained His Cauſe when He has confounded the truſt, and confidence in it, and the managers of it; A matter of infinite uſe, and commands our obſervation now.

8.
