The ſervants of the Lord, truſted to the goodneſſe of their Cauſe; they contend for the pearle in the Goſpell (that is the Goſpell) the Diadem, the Crowne of three Kingdomes; never had men a better Cauſe to contend for ſince man was created than this is: And may they not truſt to the goodneſſe of this Cauſe? Yes, they may, truſt and be confident, That a good Cauſe ſhall have a good iſſue; that it ſhall overcome at the laſt; that the Lord will bring it forth to victory; that the end ſhall be good. It is as much as can be ſaid of a good man, his end ſhall be peace. But note we, A good Cauſe may be ill managed; It may be carried alſo by the hand of God variouſly, toſſed-up and downe, as David ſaid of himſelfe, like a locuſt; To teach us, that the goodneſſe of the Cauſe does not argue the goodneſſe of our truſt: Ile adde this; The goodneſſe of the cauſe gives me warrant to expend my purſe, and my ſpirits, and my life for it; But it does not warrant me to put my truſt unto it: Where this truſt ought to be fixed, we ſhall heare ſo ſoone, as we ſhall better underſtand, how vaine the confidence is we put in the goodneſſe of the Cauſe; It is an Idoll, God has broken it to pieces: It is His manner ſo from dayes of old upward to this day. Ile inſtance only in two famous examples; Iſraell in old Elies dayes [or rather when it was night with him] had a good cauſe in hand, which they (as we now) maintained againſt the Philiſtines, and yet they fell before the Philistines about foure 1 Sam. 4. 2. thouſand men. They truſted more yet to the goodneſſe of their cauſe; and up they brought the Arke accompanied with Hophni and Phineas, and then confident of the goodneſſe of the Cauſe, how bad ſoever themſelves were, they ſhouted with a great ſhout; and ver. 4. 5. ver. 8, 9. ver. 10. the Philiſtines were ſore afraid. But their courage overcame their feare, and they fought with Iſraell, and ſlew of Iſraell thirty thouſand footemen: and the Arke of God was taken too: and the two ſons of Eli ſlaine alſo. They truſted to the goodneſſe of the Cauſe; It was the Lords Cauſe, the Arke was the Lords, that would ſave ver. 3. them from the hand of their enemies. No, but it would not, The
Cauſe of God, the Arke of God was ſo farre from helping them, that it expoſed them to more wrath, which they could not be delivered from, till the ſervants of the Lord had taken their heartsoff from the goodneſſe of the Cauſe, and ſet their hearts fully towards the Lord, in returning to Him, according as Samuel counſelled; which is very notable; for having done ſo, the Lord wrought a mighty ſalvation for His people, as you may reade 1 Sam. 7.. Ile paſſe on to another example.

The Tribes truſted to the goodneſſe of their cauſe. So they might they thought, for it had the impreſſion and ſtampe of God upon it; They went-out, as our men doe, by Gods command, againſt notorious delinquenis in Gibeah, ſons of Belial, as vile and abominable almoſt, as theſe are now in the Kings Army, the Princes and Nobles there; Gods Cauſe, and Gods command, and they muſt proſper ſure, they thought. No; notwithſtanding the goodneſſe of their cauſe, they fell before Benjamin heapes upon heapes, twenty and Judg. • . two thouſand at one time; eighteene thouſand at another: that Iſraell may never put confidence in a good cauſe after this time. And yet ſo Iſraell have done, as at this day. But I hope they will doe ſo no more, never truſt to the goodneſſe of our Cauſe any more; truſt God with that, and truſt we to the goodneſſe of our GOD, that truſt never failes: A good God ſtill, and if the newes be bad, He can make it good: And if, as the Malignants would have it, the worſt, that ever was told in Gath, yet this Good GOD can make it beſt of all: O that we could truſt in Him, to the goodneſſe of our God! Though men be treacherous, God is faithfull: though they faile, He never failes thoſe that truſt Him. 2. Let us truſt to the goodneſſe (that is) to the ſoundneſſe of our converſion, our turning from Idols to ſerve the living God; If our converſion and turning be ſound, we may truſt to it, and not care for all the turnings and windings of the crooked ſerpent, they ſhall doe us no hurt; the changes of things here below makes no change in them, whoſe heart is truly changed: nor makes it any change in God; though meanes are weake, He is ſtrong; though men faile, God never failes! And note we, the turnings and tydes of things here below, doe but ſerve to turne our hearts unto God; to ſtabliſh them there. And when the heart is ſet-upon that bottome, though the world be turned upſide-downe, yet the man ſtands upright.
The failing of mans arme, (too ſhort at the longeſt extent to bring ſalvation) brings-up the heart to cloſe with the Almighties arme, which neither ſhortens nor lengthens, but is ſtretched out ſtill. And when the heart is brought thither, then it is fixed, and not till then.

9. The Iſraell of God muſt praiſe God for their diſcomfitures; for thereby they are inſtructed to diſcretion, to know GOD and themſelves, that He is all, and does all; that they are nothing, and can doe nothing. Thereby alſo they are wrought-up unto an acceptation Lev. 26. 41. of their puniſhment, to a ſubmiſſion, a willing reſignation, and quiet yeilding-up themſelves to Gods diſpoſe; Doe Thou with us whatſoever ſeemes good unto Thee Judg. 10. 15.: An excellent temper of ſpirit after it is over-powred, and beaten downe. And yet this humble and proſtrate ſpirit, has its Reſerves; Only let Thy Cauſe prosper; doe good unto Zion. [So the LORD will, and His Cauſe ſhall proſper; and though it may ſeeme delivered-up into the enemies hand, yet, as the Arke did, it ſhall but plague the enemies] And deliver us not-up into the hands of a cruell Lord, an ungratefull ſnake, deliver us not unto him. [God will not doe it, unleſſe it be good for His people, ſo to be delivered-up, that they may know, and feele the difference betwixt the ſervice of the God of Heaven, and the ſervice of the gods of the world 2 Chro. 12. 8:.]

10. Laſtly, When the adverſary and enemy begins to fall before the ſervants of the Lord, he ſhall ſurely fall downe to the bottome, like a milſtone into the great waters. But Iſraels fall is but a riſe E •• . 5. 14. towards their higheſt elevation. When (righteous) men are caſt downe, we muſt ſay, there is lifting-up. The righteous are caſt downe Job 21. 29. to humble them The Church never yet loſt by her loſſes: They ever to this day roſe the higher by their falls: So it will be in after ages., and no ſooner humbled but they are lifted up, they are regarded and ſaved; And He ſhall ſave the humble perſon. When the righteous are ſmitten into the place of dragons, when they are in a low pit, there can they ſpie Heaven, and ſee the Starre of Jacob there (as we, ſtanding on a low bottom, can ſee Heaven beſt-of all: ſo the righteous in their depths) I meane, when their diſtreſſe is greateſt, then is their truſt the ſtrongeſt; then they hold-up their heads in expectation of a redemption drawing nigh.

Now put all together, and ſee whether any victory the Church has lately had, gives us ſo much matter of praiſe, as does the diſcomfiture
at Newarke, though as great as the enemies would make it.

God has diſcomfited His people: Of meere faithfulneſſe He has done it, becauſe He loves them and will have them love Him, and truſt Him, and ſeeke Him ſervently, worke for Him earneſtly, ſight His battles valiantly; carefull ſtill, and now more carefull to remove the accurſed thing. Becauſe He will have His people truſt Pſal. 20. 7. Hoſ. 14. 3. in charets and ride upon horſes no more; Truſt in the goodneſſe of their cauſe no more; truſt on the arme of fleſh no more; but remember the Name of their God evermore; and their duty to be holy, who manage an holy cauſe. So they ſhall proſper, riſe and ſtand upright for evermore, Amen.

To ſumme-up all, and to put a cloſe to this excellent Theame; It muſt be the ſame, which we ſhould put downe at the foot of all our Receits, all the Mercie, which we receive (and we have nothing, which we have not received) either from the right or left hand of God: All are Mercies, either manifeſtly ſuch (thoſe only Manifeſt is que max • mè delect •• t: occultis quae proſunt etiam no • entibus. See Thankoffring, p. 16. we call Mercies) or ſecretly ſuch, wherewith our GOD will doe us good againſt our wills: He muſt be praiſed for all, and this muſt be the cloſe of all, O that men would praiſe the Lord for His goodneſſe: and for His wonderfull workes to the children of men
• ſ • . 107. 8.. Surely the Lord, as He ſaid to Moſes, has made all His goodneſſe to paſſe before us alſo Exod. 33. 19.: Even theſe laſt yeares He has proclaimed His Name, fearefull in praiſes, doing wonders; O that men would praiſe the Lord, for,

He gave us the Lord Chriſt, (a Mercy inexpreſſible, which we never prayed-for: but there we muſt begin, the beginning of Mercies, and foundation thereof) and with Him, all things; The Fountaine, from Whom all the Churches freſh ſprings of comfort do •
• low in unto her; In Whom are all the Treaſures, rich Mines of Grace and Glory: all praiſe to God for Him, through Whom God is a Father of Mercies, and a God not of ſome, but of all conſolations. O that men would praiſe the Lord, &c. and for,
2. Caſting the rayes of His glorious light, upon this Land firſt of all. O that men would praiſe the Lord: and for,
3. Breaking the yoke of His burden, and the rod of His oppreſſor the Pope, when the Lord caſt-out thoſe ſix damnable Articles almoſt an hundred yeares agoe; O that men would praiſe the Lord, and for,

4. Giving us a Child-King, yet making him a nurſing-Father: and a Maiden-Queene, yet making her a nurſing-Mother: And for all the goodneſſe, the Lord gave, through the hands of thoſe excellent Princes (He delights to worke by weake inſtruments,) to bretheren and to ſtrangers. O that men would praiſe the Lord. and for,
5. Delivering us out of the floods of great waters: and making His Adverſaries ſinke downe there like a ſtone. O that men would 56 Yeares ago. praiſe the Lord for His goodneſſe, and for,

6. Not ſuffering the fier to kindle upon us: but conſuming His Adverſaries in their own fornace, which they had heated ſeven Almoſt 40 yeares ago. times hotter than ordinary. O that men would praiſe the Lord, and for,

7. His Parliament, which the LORD would have, His Adverſaries give, and continue unto His Land: (O wonderfull!) And when they would curſe their own gift, (O abominable!) The LORD would bleſſe it; how admirable! O that men would praiſe the Lord, and for,
8. Thoſe excellent, marvailous, diſtinguiſhing, ſeperating-Mercies, which the LORD hath reached-forth to all His Kingdomes, through His ſervants hands. O that men would praiſe the Lord; and for,

9. The Parliament at Oxford; yes, though the Devils Parliament, yet praiſe the Lord for that: for both the Houſes there; The ignoble houſe of Robbers, where Littleton ſpeakes little, (nay not one word of) Law: And the baſe houſe of Theeves, where Eure ſpeakes as little Reaſon. O that men could praiſe the LORD for this Anti-Parliament. The Lord has ſuffered it to be ſet-up for excellent reaſon, To try and proove His Parliament, whether they will not be as active for GOD, as that Parliament is for the Devill: As ſpiritfull for the LORD Chriſt as thoſe Adverſaries are for Anti-chriſt. O that men would praiſe the Lord: and for,

10. All His deliverances: Here I ſtand in a maze; Whoever could reckon-up the deliverances God gave to one particular perſon! how much leſſe able, to account the deliverances to a whole Kingdome: 1. The deliverance at Edg-hill
October 2 • , 1642. On the Lord day., ye ſervants of the Lord, praiſe ye the Lord. 2. That at Brainford
Novemb. 12, Saturday.: open the month and praiſe ye the Lord, for that wonderfull deliverance.

3. For the deliverance at Newbery
Septemb. 19, 1643. • huſd • y.. O that men would praiſe the Lord for that. And for that neare Wincheſter
March 29, 16 • 4. 2 Chro. 20. 26. A comfort, that comes too ſoone, is a diſcomf • ture afte • wuds; what ever we think, the Lord God helps His C • u •• h • lways right carly Exod. 28. 36.. O that men would praiſe the Lord for His goodneſſe, and for His wonderfull workes to the children of men! O that BERACHAHS, Bleſſings and Prayſes were written upon them every one, ſpecially upon thoſe, that came not too ſoone, when we deſired them. O that BERACHAH, Bleſſing and Praiſe were written upon the places where, the dayes when, the perſons by whom the Lord wrought theſe deliverances. O that this were engraven upon their perſons, Holineſſe to the Lord, then men would praiſe the Lord for His goodneſſe. And for delivering His ſervants into His enemies hands. O that we could praiſe the Lord for this, for this ſhall tend to their eternall go • d. O that we could praiſe the Lord, for ſuffering the enemy to fier upon us, as thoſe that would ſet our houſes on a flame over our heads; theſe will kindle His ſervants zeale (Luke-warme before) againſt their own ſins, and ſuch great ſinners before the Lord. Bl • ſſed be the Lord for this; God does aſſure His ſervants, that, as Davids deliverance was neareſt, when his Ziglag was fiered 1 Sam. 30. 1., and his enemies rage at the higheſt: So is His • hurches deliverance at hand, when He ſuffers His enemies to caſt about the rage of their great wrath: now the Devill has but a ſhort time Rev. 12. 12.: O that men would praiſe the Lord for His goodneſſe, and for His wonderfull works to the children of men! Let Ireland praiſe the Lord, He has thrown down her Tabernacle, but it is to raiſe it up, and to ſtabliſh it for ever. Let Scotland praiſe the Lord, who has wrought wonderfull works there once and againe; and more wonderfully will He worke for them and by them, if they and we can give God all the glory: If we can make God our ſtrong arme, He will uſe His ſervants hands, thereby to bring to paſſe great matters. O that we could praiſe the Lord (i. e.) aſcribe ſalvation to our God! Let England do ſo, now a burning buſh all on a flame, yet not conſumed. Not conſumed! not hurt in all this fier; She is reſining, ſhe is purifying now from all her tinne, all her droſſe: Never in ſuch a way to exaltation, to be made the head of Nations, and the moſt honourable of Kingdomes! O that men would praiſe the Lord, aſcribe ſalvations to their God. Let Hull ſay ſo, a monument of ſalvations: Let Gloceſter ſay ſo, an everlaſting pillar for everlaſting praiſe: Let London ſay ſo, the City of God, that has
lyen among Lyons yet not devoured; amongſt thoſe, who were ſet on fier, yet not conſumed: A City, that has been ſtormed with all the granadoes, that could be ſhot againſt her; Proclamations, Detestations, Commiſſions, all the fiery darts, haile-stones and coales of fier, yet ſtands untouched as a monument of everlaſting praiſe before their God; and as a mirrour of Mercy and ſacred providence, before the eyes of all the Chriſtian world; that City of God ſo exalted, will exalt the Lord, will praiſe the Lord for His wonderfull works, to her and her children, ſo preſerved, ſo marvailouſly ſeparated: and for this very end, To ſhew that the LORD is upright: He is her rock, and no unrighteouſneſſe in Him. London will praiſe the Lord, for had the Adverſary had power anſwerable to his will; (i. e.) had he had an arme like God, as he thinks he has; then had he caſt abroad the rage of his wrath; he had deſtroyed the humble perſons there, and trod them downe in their places: he would have commanded fier and brimſtone from Heaven, and rained it downe upon London: Therefore will that City ſhew forth the loving kindneſſe of GOD in the morning, and His faithfulneſſe every night, Amen. Now I deſcend to p • al. 9 • . 2. the particular, for we are loſt and deceived in generals.

div.head: § II.

argument.p: The prime meanes of Poſturing a mans ſelfe, Prayer, How prevailing; and hovv comely Praiſe.

div.p:
THis Souldier hath not, by his own hand, gotten himſelfe the victory, victory over himſelfe, in denying, in cru • ifying that ſelfe; victory over his Idols; caſting theſe forth: He has not, in his own ſtrength taken-up his croſſe, and followed his Lord Chriſt. He does not, aſcribe this to his ſword or to his bow. A poore man • to ſtand-up againſt Principalities and powers! A poore creature to wraſtle with fleſh and blood; to carry forth or ſubdue all the filth of his heart, and to bring-in every needfull grace: All this is without the ſpheare of natures activity, beyond the power of all created ſtrength; he prayed and he wept concerning all this, and ſo had power with his GOD: All this was a Naptal • , the fr • ut of mighty wraſtlings with his God: So he quenched the fiery darts of Satan,
thoſe granadoes, and ſo forth, for I know not what he has done. But all is done by the good hand of his God with him; In the power of His might he has quitted himſelfe as a good Souldier of Jeſus Chriſt; he has done valiantly, and yet not he; no, but the grace of GOD which was with him 1 Cor 15. 10, still ſtrengthening him and inabling him, to doe all things
〈◊〉 4. 1 • . 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .: His God has done great things for him, He has quenched thoſe darts, put oile into the wounds thoſe made; The more fiery and piercing thoſe were, the wider paſſage they made for joy to come-in, and to open the mouth the wider for praiſe to goe forth. Theſe great things God has done for His poore ſervant. He has wrought great works in him too; It was His good pleaſure ſo, though he be nothing 2 Cor. 12. • 1.; And now this mans heart being fixed, he is as ſecure as any man in the world, truſting in the Lord, he is carefull for nothing: If the temptation be ſtrong, and the ſtrait great, he does according to the counſell Phil. 4. 6., and the example 2 Co • . 12. 8. before him, once and againe, and the third time, makes his prayer and ſupplication before his GOD: and if the temptation be not removed, and he enlarged, yet that is done which is beſt for him; It is ſanctified; and he is made able to beare it, and a way made alſo to eſcape 1 Cor. 10. 13.. Prayer now, and Gods grace now, are as prevailing, and as ſufficient as ever: and ſo he has concluded, and is carefull for nothing; But in all things he gives thanks; he ſees infinite reaſon for that, ſpecially for his temptations, for he has ever found the way God has made to eſcape has been the more wonderfull, the ſharper the temptation, and the greater the ſtraight has been: Honour, and glory, and praiſe, be attributed to this deare God for all His mercies, and loving kindneſſes to His poore ſervant; for His Heaven here [which was more than he looked for, or was Joh. 16. 33. promiſed,] and for all his Hell too, his loſſes, and croſſes; his paines and his ſorrowes; his conflicts and his troubles, not mercies in our eſteeme, but mercies to him, and in his account made ſo, and found ſo to be by many experiences, therefore regiſtred in the beginning See Thank off •• ing, chap. 3. of his calender of mercies; Glory and praiſe to God for all His mercies, and loving kindneſſes to His poore ſervant. How many are thoſe all? he will tell you when you tell him how many haires you have on your head, for he will not require of you, how many ſands on the ſea ſhore, or Starr • s in the firmament of Heaven; all the mercies to his ſoule; There he begins, with righthand
mercies, from everlaſting to everlaſting; all cauſes of, and conducing to his eternall well being: Poore man, poore in ſpirit, rich in faith! He never thought himſelfe worthy to enjoy the light of the Sun in the firmament: but that the LORD the Creatour thereof ſhould lift-up the light of His countenance upon His ſervant! That, the day-ſpring from on high, ſhould viſit him! That the Son of Righteouſneſſe ſhould ariſe unto him with healing in His wings. This! how admirable, how unſpeakeable a—mercy is this See Thankoffring, ch. 3. You may commend this man, ſayes Luther, for he is an humble man, a child may leade him: his ſervant may reprove him: Chriſt dwells and walkes in him; the man is and does nothing: And if he be an humble-man, he is a thankfullman even for the leaſt mercy and greateſt a •• liction; Iu all things he gives thanks, Luther. ! I can tell you no more of this, his own words are ſwallowed-up here with admiration, as Jobs were with griefe: Here come-in his Selahs, his Mictams, his Hallelujahs, as we read before, and ſhall reade hereafter. All left-hand mercies (under that generall he comprehends all deliverances, all mercies to the Churches, (he is much taken with them, much enlarged in his praiſe to God for Jeruſalem, her proſperity! he prefers it before his chiefe joy;) very thankfull alſo for mercies to himſelfe, to all his round about him, and about his table, relating to their warfare here.) All mercies! he is loſt and confounded in particulars here, yet by his will he would not forget one: he writes upon all mercies concerning his ſoule, his body; day-mercies, night-mercies, all within him, all without him, all beſtowed upon his bretheren and ſiſters, upon himſelfe and his about him, he writes upon all, Askt of GOD; the gift of GOD; all is a kind of ſalvation; upon all thoſe gates, whereat evill went-out, or mercy came-in, he writes, The ſalvation of the LORD: upon all thoſe out-lets and in-lets he writes PRAYSE, which attends prayer evermore; He writes Praiſe alſo upon his converſation, even holineſſe unto the LORD, he lives unto His praiſe, Who has given all to him, has done all for him, wrought all in him, for all is from the LORD the God of his ſalvations; to whom he aſcribeth all honour, and glory, and praiſe, from everlaſting unto everlaſting, for ever and ever, Amen and Amen.

div.head: CHAP. III. The Word Preached is mighty to Poſture a Kingdome.

argument.p:
The propog • t • ng thereof has been and is the endeavou • of all good Patriots in all ag • s of the world. What this Land was before the 〈◊〉 of this Sunne gl • mmeted forth unto the peopl • t • ere. What th • People we • t when covered over with the d • rkn • ſſe o • P • pe • y. Wh • t the darke pl • ces of the earth are now. How this eng • geth the 〈◊〉 to promote th •
Gospell with ali their might; how mighty through God, yet l • ſſ • exp • cta •• on of Peace from the world now, than ever; The Reaſons why it • uſt be ſo: Aſſured Re • ce is from H •• ven, Chriſts L • gacy to His, in Me • eace.

div.p: THus victoriouſly have the Worthies of the Lord marched-on hitherto, not in their own ſtrength, nor aſcribing any thing to their own arme: but to the right-hand of the Lord, He has done valiantly; They brought Him down to their ſide; intereſſed Him in the Cauſe; lifted up their hearts and hands to Him; ſo they wraſtled, even with ſtrong wraſtlings, and ſo they are prevailers, All the people of God, that little little flock, all the world over, ſtriving with them alſo in their prayers. But ſo they could not have done, if they had not beleeved; and beleeve they could not without a word; and a word they could not have, in an ordinary way, without a Preacher: No bleſſing without prayer; no prayer without faith; no faith without a word, a word of promiſe, wherein Thou haſt made me to hope, ſayes David. This conſideration and ſome others, which I may hint at preſently, made the Worthies of the Lord very ſerious, and moſt actively-buſie, as were all the Nobles and truly honoured before them, to ſend-forth able and faithfull Miniſters (Indeed the Meſſengers of the Churches, and the 1 C • to. 17. 7. Kings C •• on. p. 1 • . glory of Chriſt) To teach in all the Townes and Cities of Judah, That is the way to poſture a Kingdome fully and indeed; the way the Nobles ever tooke, and ever ſucceeded-in, upward to this day. That we may raiſe this mercy to the height, give men their honour, and God the glory; let us make a ſtand here, and turne back our thoughts very farre, to the people of this Land, before the day-spring from on-high did viſit them, I meane, before ſome ray of Heavenly light did glimmer-forth unto them. Let us conſider this in the firſt place.

1. What manner of people were they in thoſe dayes? ſurely, as Agur ſaid of himſelfe, when he knew himſelfe, and had ſome knowledge of the Holy one: Theſe were more bruitiſh then any Prov. 30 2. man: they had not the underſtanding of men: and ſo bruitiſh they were truly and indeed, becauſe they knew not themſelves ſo to be, nor had they any knowledge to be holy: That we may ru • ne-over this as quickly, as our thoughts uſe to doe, this ile only ſay; Theſe people were then as the poore Indians are now, as Idolatrous as theſe: Theſe worſhip the Devill now, ſo did the people in England then. He ſpeake nothing of their other worſhip which they gave to the Hoſt of Heaven, nor of their Arch-Flamines and Flamines,
• ilamines, I lid. , their Arch-Prieſts and Prieſts; the very ſame with ours, not ſo much heatheniſh, but altogether as unchriſtian, whom we called Arch-Biſhops and Biſhops: Ile paſſe over all this, that our thoughts may returne-upward againe, untill we come to, As it is at this day. Conſiderwe then in the next place, That

2. When it pleaſed God to break through that thick-cloud of Atheiſme, by the preaching of Joſeph, (for ſo we have it by tradition That Ioſeph of Arimathea, preached the Goſpell firſt to this Iland.) the cloud quickly thickned againe, and grew more darke all over the Heaven, by the ſpreading of Popery: And then the people were worſe than before, abominable Idolaters; They ſacrificed to Devils before, ſo they did then; but then they did more than ever they did before; They worſhipped the Sunne before, for that was moſt glorious in their eyes: But afterwards they worſhipped the workes of their own hands; and that was a more bruitiſh worſhip; They made gods with their own hands, as eaſily as they could carve wood and ſtone: And then they fell downe before the gods, which they had made. And obſervable it is, how monſtrouſly cruell they were at that time; They devoured one another as bread; they cut one anothers throat • s, as ordinarily, as they dranke Ale: And to ſave their throates one friend was a pledge to the other, while he was drinking; whence our word ſo ordinarily uſed ever ſince, He pl • dge you. Who ever ſaw Idolaters that were not cruell; Th • y that could make gods, could make no conſcience of marring the Image of GOD. And thus they have continued to make gods upward to this day: for that Art, whereto nature is very apt, is quickly learnt; and once learnt, nature never unlearnes it againe. Now in our returne upward to this day, let us conſider how bruitiſh
theſe god-makers were in thoſe dayes, how like to the gods they made.

3. And we will reflect no farther back, than to the beginning of Elizabeths Raigne, that excellent Queene, of the ſweeteſt memory. What a bruitiſh people then! They that made gods, made no conſcience of unmaking men, of deſtroying themſelves made in the Image of God; To tell you one of their mad and bruitiſh prankes: In our Northerne parts, where the people alwayes were, and now are, very expert to make gods, and can ſerve them as well, this their manner was, To hang up a glove in their Church, in way of a challenge, where meeting upon our ſol • mne day, they made that place like our Paris-garden, where the men are more bruitiſh now, than are the beaſts there. Thus bruitiſh they were in thoſe dayes.

And now we will come-up to, As it is at this day, and enquire, how it is now: Who are they, that have deſerted the Parliament, all the faithfull in all three Kingdomes, and aſſiſted a warre againſt them, as at this day? Who are they, that are now fighters againſt God; the right hands of the times; eldeſt ſonnes to that Prince, that rules in darkneſſe? Who are thoſe vipers, that eate through their mothers wombe to make their eſcape; Who are thoſe but ſuch who lived in darkneſſe, and hated the light? Who made the loweſt and baſeſt of things (their luſts) their gods; and put from them the Holy one, would have none of Him. True it is, theſe mighty Nimerods, Marqueſſes, and Earles, and Lords, whom their horrible—butcheries, and Turkiſh cruelties have rendred men of Name now, but ſhall render them a curſe to after generations, All theſe were borne and lived in dayes of light: But they put it from them, they cared not to know the Lord; they never heard, or not cared to heare any other, but Court-Sermons, which courted them for the ſervice of their King, never taught them how to ſerve the LORD of lords, and God of gods. The Sermoniſts there (I cannot call them Preachers) the beſt of them, except one, (a prime one once, the laſt now in eſteeme) were but Engliſh Senecaes at the beſt, they had no more ſavour of Divinity
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Baſil, Ep. •• . They make ſuch a compound of Divinity, with art and wit, as he of his Roſes with ſpices, that they mar. ••• the ſavour of it quite. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , 〈◊〉 . de var. Hiſt. l. 4. • . 39., of Chriſt, and His Goſpell, than thoſe Epiſtles have. And for the Chaplaines there in Court, and in their Lords houſes, their Sermons there were not halfe ſo good as Senecaes Epiſtles; Theſe containe excellent humanity and morality, and good Divinity too, (if Divinity can be
there, where the Name of Chriſt is not:) but theſe Court-Sermons had not that in them, which we call humanity: and for divinity, there was no more ſavour of it there, then there is in the white of an Egge: No marvaile now that men, who thruſt away the light, doe walke now as men in the darke, and are yet more cruell and bloody than their fore-fathers were. For the people now generally all over the Land, theſe are as bruitiſh as their Lords and Leaders are, and for the ſame reaſon, for their guides and Paſtours are ſo bruitiſh. From theſe premiſes, which we doubt not, but were throughly conſidered on by the truly Noble and highly Honoured now in Parliament, we muſt conclude, Firſt,
1. That the darke places of the earth are now as they ever have beene, full of cruelty.

2. That there are a people in the City, and Countrey (not to ſpeake of Wales) who live in as palpable darkneſſe, under as thick a cloud of Popery, as they did a thouſand yeares agoe I know ſome Pariſhes in the very heart and center of the Land, where neither the children now, nor their Fathers, ever • heard the Goſpell preached:; nay their darkneſſe now is more palpable, and the ſhadow of death more groſſe, and thick now, in theſe dayes, than in dayes of old, for this reaſon; Becauſe ſome places in the City and Countries, are as Goſhen was, which make the other places more darke: for a ſpirituall light, as does a naturall, but flaſhing only in the face, and not abiding, does but darken the eye of the mind the more, as a naturall light does the eye of the body. More might be added here, but I paſſe on, and conclude.

3. That the Arch-biſhops and Biſhops tooke the readieſt way that could be taken, to bring an Egyptian darkneſſe all over the Land: For 1. They thruſt the Miniſters of God, (excellent men, I never think of that Bith •
nian, but I think of our Biſhops and their Curates, Lact. l. 5. 1, 2, 9, chapt. and pretious) out of Gods houſe, and their owne: and thruſt the vile men into their places, ſuch, whom Job would not have admitted to ſit with the doggs of his flock. 2. They taught the people by their own example; I ſay, by their own example, to make gods, and then to worſhip before them: and that was the only way to make a people, as now they are, as bruitiſh as ſtocks: and as fierce as Lyons. I ſay nothing here how they did blaſpheme the Lord and his day; I conclude.

4. That there is not a man, I ſay not a man, that has heartily joyned himſelfe to the Kings Army, who has not received the marke of the beaſt either openly in his forehead, or ſecretly in his
hand; or he has damnation written in his forehead: not a man in the Kings Army, willingly there, and on that ſide, who is not a Papist, or, which is as bad, an Atheiſt (that is) bruitiſhly ignorant, or notoriouſly profane: So I have liſted that Legion, that black Regiment, the Devils guard, under two generall heads, Papiſts and Atheists all: And when the Nobles there ſhall goe about to recruit their Army, as ſure as the Devill is in Hell, and his angels, his miniſtring ſervants are on earth; ſo ſure it is, they ſhall not find a man, hearty to their ſervice, not one man in all the Chriſtian world, who is not one of theſe two; one that knowes nothing, as he ought to know, he is a Papiſt; or one that is bruitiſh in knowledge, and more bruitiſh in practiſe, he is an Atheiſt.

5. That ſhould the Nobles and Worthies have parlied, as many yeares as they have weekes, upon a way how to remedy all this, how to make a firme Peace, and eſtabliſh Truth in the Land, that theſe may meete and kiſſe each other, they could not have thought of a ſhorter, more compendious, and more ready way, than that they have taken. And ſo now I muſt returne back againe, that I may traverſe the way the Worthies of the LORD have taken from the firſt day they ſate in Parliament upward to this day: The ſimpleſt reader ſhall then more clearely underſtand, the changes and tydes of things as they are at this day: and be able more than by conjecture to tell what ſhall be in after-dayes. The way they tooke. Firſt,

1. And it muſt be alwayes firſt in all orderly proceedings, They proclaimed a fast, that they and we might afflict our ſelves before Ezra 8. • 1. our GOD, to ſeeke of him a right way: That muſt be I ſay againe, alwayes firſt, for we all know, and are aſſured, That the hand of our God is upon all them for good, that ſeeke Him: but His power, and His wrath is againſt all them, that forſake him. Of this before. ver. 22.

2. They called-in the exiles; opened the priſon doores, brought forth the pretious, thruſt the vile into thoſe places; they opened the Miniſters mouthes; and then, as matters did require, they entred into a Proteſtation, they avouched God to be their God; to
May 5, 1641. ſerve Him after His manner; and to ſtand-faſt in the liberty wherein God and Man, the law of God, of Nature, of the Kingdome, of Nations had made them free: We muſt enquire in paſſage, how did this take? And anſwer: That there were very many,
Arch-biſhops both, and Biſhops all; Princes and Nobles; Paſtours and people, who refuſed. Ah Lord! Refuſed to take God for their God! Refuſed to maintaine the Diadem and Crowne of three Kingdomes! Refuſed to ſtand-faſt in the liberty wherein God and man had ſet them! Ah Lord! Indeed it is to be pittied, but not to be wondred at, if we conſider the places where theſe people live; The Teaching they had there; and the influence that teaching had into the hearts and lives of men all over the land. I pray you let us conſider, The place firſt, where lived they?

1. Under the droppings or near about Cathedrals. It is as barbarous a word as the people are who live there: yet we now know what the Cathedrals are, The Biſhops Churches, and the Devils Chappels: There the Biſhop had his ſeat, and Satan has his throne.

2. What teaching had they there, under thoſe droppings, or near there abouts? what teaching there? None at all, no catechiſing, no inſtruction there: A Sermon perhaps there was, ſuch as it was, which nouriſhed no more than nuts doe, which fill with wind: or Clem. Alex. than Stock-fiſh does, which, Eraſmus ſayes, nouriſheth no more than does a ſtone. And for the places further off whereinto their Prebends there had an influence, The people were not taught at all; not that there was any Spirit good or bad, or that the people had any other ſoules, than what the beaſts have. True it is, and not to bely the Devill, The Doctour told the people, when he came to receive his Eaſter book, and gather in his Tythes, That there is a God, and they muſt ſerve Him; A Devill too, and they muſt fly from him, and hate his workes: for a heaven there is, and everlaſting Joyes there; And hell there is, and eternall paines there. But the people beleeved none of all this. That was their fault, you will ſay. Indeed it was. But the Doctour was foully to blame: Becauſe, what he taught with the mouth once or twiſe a yeare, he untaught with his hands every day: for no ſooner preached he the preaching, his owne heart ſuggeſted to him, but away from the Church to the Ale-houſe, where he would drinke like a ſwine; or if not given to that ſin, (as all are not) yet to another as bad; Beſides all this, he would earth himſelfe in the earth; hunt after honours, ride after preferments furiouſly, as Balaam did; drowne himſelfe in the world, as if he knew no other God, as certainly he does not. And
this ſpoiled all his Philoſophy to the people; he, that told them there is a God, and then turned his back upon Him, could they beleeve him? He that ſaid, there is an heaven, where the Righteous are eternally happy; and an hell, where the wicked are eternally, miſerable, and yet lived like the unjuſt judge, that feared not God, nor regarded man; as one, that had a ſoule for no other purpoſe than a ſwine has (pro ſale) to keepe his body freſh, and ſweete; could the people Truſt him? Ah Lord! ſhould I tell the Reader in the laſt place,

3. What an influence theſe Cathedrals had, and the Prieſts there into the lives and manners of all round about; If I ſhould tell how As Bunbury a viſe perſon in Reading. brutiſh Prieſts and people are in the Cities and countries round about, men without God in the world, he would not wonder, that there are ſo many found every where fighters against God: what can be expected from a brutiſh people, but to walke brutiſhly? What wonder is it to ſee men contend againſt God, whom they know not? To fight againſt the Goſpel, the glory whereof they never ſaw, nor any more light, but what ſlaſhing in their face, blinded them the more? what wonder is it to ſee Paſtours and people more brutiſh and more cruell than in ancient dayes, when they are more ſuperſtitious now than they were then? We are more cunning god-makers now than were our fore-fathers 16. hundred yeares agoe, they were but bunglers to us: but we more unexcuſable (the time of that ignorance God (over-looked) winked Act. 17. • o. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . at): And, as is ſaid of a cunning Gameſter, The more cunning he is, the more knave he is: ſo, the more cunning we are, the more abominable we are, but very exact we are at that craft now, this godmaking, we exceed all our fathers; for our skill, which is naturall, we have confirmed by imitation: and we thank our Prieſts we are more brutiſh than the Flamines were of old, we can make many breaden gods, and woodden gods, and ſtone gods: and a book a god, yet not Gods Book neither, we can doe more as naturally as the fire can burne, for we can make every lust a god. How can we now avouch God for our God? But you will aske me by the way.
How doe men and women make gods? The prime and chiefe Idolaters in all the kingdome haply never made a god with their hands?

Very likely, but as the cunning Artificer makes gods with his
hands: ſo there are as cunning as he, who can make gods without hands: for by bowing before this or that, be it bread, fleſh, or fiſh; ſtock or ſtone, we make it a god, as well as we can, ſuch an one as it is. The Lord plagued the people becauſe they made a calfe which Exod. 32. • 5. Aaron made. Aaron made it, and the people made it; he made it a calfe, and the people made it a god by doing ſuch homage and ſervice unto it, as ſhould be done to God only. What calves were they? even ſuch as we are, while we ſerve dumb Idols, the works of our owne hands, or the works of our owne hearts. I pray you mark that, they are Idols ſet-up there, the Devill, the world, and the fleſh: while we give ſuch a ſervice to them, as is due only to God, we make theſe our gods: We make the world a god, and the Devill a god, and pleaſure a god, and the belly a god, by ſerving the creature more than we ſerve the Creator, who is bleſſed for ever. Amen. And now that we are ſuch cunning workmen at making Rom. 1. 25. of gods, All the Chriſtian world may ſee in what a poſture we ſtood to a Protestation, to take God for our God; To avouch Him. But yet neither the worke nor the workers did ceaſe, The faithfull all the land over, who had avouched God for their God; were aſſured, That God would avouch them, and them only for His people: ſo they followed-on to ſeeke the Lord, in the way where He is alwayes found: They knew they were in the way toward a glorious peace, in the purſuit of Truth: and were more confirmed in it, Becauſe the Princes of the earth, and the heathen people there ſet themſelves againſt that Peace: This made them gird-up their loynes like men, and walke on, filled with the Spirit. They are not meet to doe Gods worke, who ſay there is a Lion or ſhe Beare in the way; Who cannot maſter difficulties, and make uſe of them for encouragements; To leape over wals, and skip over mountaines; In Gods ſtrength they can doe all this: And ſo, two yeares after, the Worthies entred into covenant with their God; and fairly propoſed it to the people; and they all tooke it, all that were free-men, not under the Anti-chriſtian yoke, and had any knowledge of GOD, or how to ſerve Him: all theſe tooke it. Only Atheiſts, and Papiſts, (god-makers) they refuſed (for all theſe had, with their Paſtours and people, made a covenant with ſinne, death, and hell, and they would ſtand to that): and to maintaine their ſtanding, their rage workt higher, if higher could be; The Adverſary ſtormed the more,
the more the Covenant of GOD preſſed toward them, and the equity there-of flaſhed in their faces, and cleared to their eyes, how abominable, and bloody their devices were, even to destroy a mother Citie in Iſrael. But all this rage (for now hell was moved; Nay, all this while, from the firſt day, that the Proteſtation was entred-into, ever ſince, all the gates there were ſet-wide-open, but all) did ſerve the more to confirme and ſtabliſh the ſervants of the Lord in their way comming-up to the LORD To joyne themſelves to Him, in a Covenant never to be forgotten: And up they are brought three Kingdomes together, God ſpeaking to them with a ſtrong-Hand, and they are in a faſt-Covenant with their God. (This will be the ſubject of the ſixt Chapter.) Here only we muſt obſerve with all obſervation, how the Covenant takes, What letteth ſtill, and will let till it be removed? Treacherous Prophets, and vile Prieſts, theſe muſt be removed; Pretious and faithfull, ſuch muſt be put into thoſe places, as forerunners to prepare the way of the LORD, and a people for Himſelfe. Alas! It cannot be expected, that we, a poore darke people, ſhould (underſtanding what we doe) enter into Covenant to take God for our God, His Chriſt for our Lord, and King; His Spirit to be ruled by Him, and to walke after Him. Indeed we underſtand none of theſe things: I affirme, and can confirme it in the name of all the brutiſh Paſtours and People all over the land, That we have no more ſaving knowledge of thoſe matters, God, and Christ, and His Spirit, than the ſeat has whereon we ſit; or than Heyly • s deaf-ſtone, Heyly. Geog. p. 503. or than Heylyn himſelfe; nor poſſible we ſhould; Wee heare our Paſtour, (in name), a brutiſh man indeed, more brutiſh than our ſelves (and that is more brutiſh than the Oxe and Horſe we drive) ſay prayers, as our ſummer-bird ſings, ſtill the ſame: he is dead, and his prayers dead; In an extraordinary way, whence ſhould we have life? Then he reads the holy word of God; but with ſuch unwaſhed hands, and uncleane lips, That he makes it, as doth our ſin, and unpreparedneſſe, uncleane to us alſo. Indeed my ſpirit is ſtirred now: I ſee plainly for want of knowledge we periſh all. Ye Worthies of the Lord, lift-up your ſelves upon the wing now, your hearts, and your Prayers, come-on, make ſpeed to helpe us, carried-on as upon Eagles wings, ſwiftly, ſtrongly: deliver us, we pray you, from Treacherous Prophets, vile Prieſts, and brutiſh Paſtours, our ſoules
are wearied becauſe of theſe murderers Jer. 4. 31., The LORD deliver us. Till we have Paſtours after Gods owne heart, we cannot avouch God for our God: we cannot enter covenant with Him: we ſhall doe, as we have done, breake all your bands, and caſt from us your cords, as brutiſh Paſtours, and people, Children of Belial, uſe to do. For Gods ſake haſten for our helpe, flying as upon Eagles wings, and deliver us from theſe unreaſonable men. Nay, though we may be ſo brutiſhly ignorant, That all our talke is of Oxen, we aske not after ſuch a mercy for we underſtand it not: yet, Aske ye after Iſai. 65. 1. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
patefact us ſum vel obviam expoſitus. I met them who would have ſhunned me. 2. Chro. 30. 22. Act. 8. 30. us, ye have your LORD GOD for an example, He manifeſted Himſelfe to them, who never Asked after Him, (nor ever would); Hee was found of them, that ſought Him not. Ye will conſider this, and more which your wiſedomes can better ſuggeſt, To haſten your worke and ſpeed our deliverance, by ſending forth unto us thoſe, that can teach us the GOOD KNOWLEDGE of The LORD: We might truly ſay, as the Eunuch did, (had we ſuch a ſenſe of our owne ignorance) we cannot underſtand what we hear or read, except ſome man ſhould guide us: had we a guide, an interpreter, one, that were able to expound and ſhew us by his life and doctrine the meaning of what is read (which was the old and Nehem. 8. • . and gave the ſenſe. good manner never to be forgotten) poſſible we might goe from our ſeats in our meeting places, rejoycing, as others have done, becauſe they had underſtood the words, that were declared unto ver. 12. them; Though we are very forgetfull, and as ignorant (the more need of a guide) though, I ſay, we are ſo, yet we forget not, what the Diſciples ſaid; our hearts did burne within us while He (the Lord Luke 24. 32. Christ) opened to us the Scriptures: Then they felt that heat, and fervencie of ſpirit, when the Scriptures were opened; the ſenſe thereof given, then heat (An Almighty Hand working therewith) comes-into the heart; Then the ſpirits of men are quickned; Then the ſtubborne will is ſubdued; Then the man is pliable; then the heart yeelds, is flexible, ready bent, and girt, to obey in all things. Now, Speake, LORD, Thy ſervant heareth: now, command, Lord, Thy ſervant obeyeth; Nothing now too much to doe, nothing now too hard to ſuffer; The will is ſubdued, it is gained; the man is taught now: Now offer him the Covenant, bid him lift-up his hand to it, and ſubſcribe his name; yes, that he will, with all his heart, he will doe it with rejoycing. We ſhall heare of that anon, we are but making
way to it now; The only ready way, which the Worthies of the Lord (the Lord inſtructing them to diſcretion) alwayes, and now have taken, To appoint teaching miniſters for every congregation; To thruſt-out the vile thence; To put in the pretious there; ſuch as may come unto us in the fulneſſe of the bleſſing of the Goſpell of Chriſt Rom. 15. 29.; ſuch as can, by the good hand of God with them, open our eyes, turne us from darkneſſe to light, (oh how mighty, and as excellent is the worke of a miniſter,) and from the power of Satan unto God: ſuch miniſters the Worthies endeavour now, Act. 26. 18. with all their might, to ſend forth, and appoint through all the land: for they would have all the people now to joyne and knit themſelves all together as one man, to contend for God, for Religion, for the faith, againſt the mighty Adverſaries to God, and the Lord Jeſus Chriſt, All the Devils in Hell, and his Angels on earth, Papiſts and Atheiſts there. And this is the only way, That the Word of God be publiſhed, and that great may be the company of Preachers to publiſh the ſame. We will obſerve what we read now, for it will ſuffice touching this matter. And I ſaw another Angel fly in the midſt of heaven, having the everlaſting Goſpell to preach Rev. 14. 6. unto them, that dwell on the earth, &c. We muſt ſet a Mark now on that which followes, And there followed another Angel, ſaying, Babylon is fallen, is fallen, That great City is moſt certainly fallen: When the everlasting Goſpell goes forth, when that is preached to them, who dwell upon the earth, then it is fallen, it is fallen: All fals before it, or vaniſheth as Darkneſſe before the light; ſuperſtition is fallen, it is fallen, it is certainly fallen; Hereſie is fallen, is fallen, is certainly fallen; prophaneneſſe is fallen, is fallen, all this is certainly fallen. All this was ſet-up and maintained in the dark; all this will fall or vaniſh in the light before the ſun-ſhine of the Goſpell; The Adverſarie took advantage of the night, and joyned ſhoulder to ſhoulder, To thruſt out the faithfull, and to thruſt into their Roomes paſtors as brutiſh as themſelves; and then what edification could be expected but of Altars and Images and crucifixes, and ſuch like ſervices as brutiſh as theſe Stockes; In the Darkneſſe Altars were raiſed, were raiſed, were certainly raiſed: The Adverſary and enemie took the Advantage of the Night when men ſlept. Much might be ſaid touching the methods, wiles and depths of Satan this way, how his miniſters ſought all wayes,
turned every ſtone, whereby to ſtint prayer, To ſtop the mouthes of the faithfull, to Thruſt them out, to block up the way and paſſage againſt the Goſpell, that it might not paſſe on with the increaſe of God. Bleſſed be God That the children of the Light and Reſurrection are as wiſe now (almoſt) as were the children of darkneſſe, and the world: They have (what they can) removed that which hath l • tted, made a mountaine a plaine, ſo as the Goſpell is like to have a free paſſage. And then we know what followes, Babylon is fallen, is fallen, that great Citie, Mother of witchcrafts, and profanations, is certainly fallen: And in that fall Atheiſme, ſuperſtition, hereſies, prophaneneſſe fall alſo; Now that the Word of God has a free paſſage; now that faithfull miniſters are ſent forth to prepare the way of the Lord, to make His path ſtrait; now Babylon is fallen, is fallen, is certainly fallen. Doubtleſſe The Lord has thoughts of peace towards His kingdomes, I doe make no doubt of it, They doe not queſtion it neither who are wiſer than I, ſeeingmen, and have wiſely conſidered the out-goings of the Lord towards His poore ones. This I can obſerve, I thanke God, and ſo does every man, who is not ſtarke blind, that in the Cathedrals, thoſe Dens of Robbers; (where the vile Prieſts and treacherous perſons lay ſlumbring, and ſleeping, (though they had blood for their pillowes,) and where they thought to lie ſnorting in their neſts for ever: In the Cathedrals where the ſinging-men, who divided their times betwixt the Ale-houſe and the Chappell, giving three houres unto that curſed place, and one unto this; where they pray-ſinging, and ſing-praying; In theſe places, Churches, and Chappels, as we call them, The people are taught now out of the Word of God, what God is, and how God muſt be ſerved; what prayer is, not an howling; what faith is, not a conceit in the brain, which has no bottome, but the mighty worke of God there, &c. In thoſe places, where was barrenneſſe barrenneſſe, the footſteps of the Lord drop fatneſſe now upon His people there, for there the good Word of God is opened, is expounded, ſo as we, by the good hand of God with us, underſtand what we heare, and goe away rejoycing, our hearts burning within us. Verily, the Lord will doe great things for His land. Will! ſaid I? He has done great things and glorious already, and yet but pawnes and pledges of greater mercies; The Angels, having the everlaſting Goſpell, are
gone forth to preach, and wherever they come, they ſay with a loud voice, Feare God and give glory to Him; For certainely we ſhall heare this voice next; Babilon is fallen is fallen, that great City, Rev. 14. 7. mother of whoredomes, that has made the Kings of the earth drunke with the wine of her fornication is certainely fallen. Nay we have heard this voice, it is fallen, it is fallen, more then once already: And this voice alſo, Come out of her my people that ye Rev. 18. 4. be not partakers of her ſinnes, and receive of her plagues; The complement whereof is, A drinking of the wine of the wrath of God, powred out, without mixture into the cup of His indignation: Bleſſed be GOD, Who has ſhowne ſuch a favour to His people, Rev 14. 10, 11. given them Paſtours after His own heart, who can preach the word, the Lord Chriſt unto His people; can open the treaſury of Grace, and knowing the terrours of the Lord, can perſwade men: Bleſſed be God for this unſpeakeable gift, Amen. What could the Lord have done more for His Land? He will give His people an heart to the prizes in their hands, and that is all. I cannot leave this point yet. Truely a wonderfull thing is done in our dayes; In the eveningtide it ſhall be light; When we thought it would be the darkeſt time, with us; behold how lightſome! We, poore ones, thought verily, there would be no viſion. Behold ſtand ſtill and wonder, and give glory unto God, lights are ſet-up in many, and are ſetting-up in all Congregations: It followes; The Northerne Army, thoſe locusts and caterpillers are fallen, are fallen, are certainely fallen. The mother of whoredomes ſhall be ſlaine now with the breath of Gods mouth: Darkneſſe muſt vaniſh, for light is come; the everlaſting Gospell is preached. I remember Luthers words a new;

I will not buffet darkneſſe, to beat it away, (ſaid he;) I will bring-in a light, and the darkneſſe is gone: I will not ſo eagerly contend with the Pope, for the throwing downe his Images; I will pluck them out of the heart, for I will labour to exalt the LORD CHRIST there in my miniſtery, and then the Idoll falls. This puts me in mind of another grave ſpeech; A grave Divine was ſpoken unto thus, or to this purpoſe; I pray you (Sr) chide that man for wearing long haire, ſo like a Ruſſian. I will not, ſaid the good old man They ſay it was Mr Dod the oldeſt Miniſter in England. , be eager with the youth, touching that matter, but I will teach him to know himſelfe, Ile
ſhew him the judgement of God upon long haire, (It was Abſoloms halter 2 Sam. 18. 9. c 1 Cor. 11. 14. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Chryſoſt. I •• d. Hom. 26.!) I will expound unto him, the words of the Apoſtle c, whereunto hee muſt needs ſee how contrary he walkes. Ile ſeeke to hide pride from his eyes, and to weede it out of his heart, and if I can doe ſo, I need not bid him cut his haire that we may ſee his forehead, that he may appeare like a man and not like a fury: This is the point which carrieth all before it, if it be caried home; preach Chriſt into the heart, and then the Idoll goes-out, and every thing, that exalts its ſelfe againſt the LORD CHRIST will be throwne downe, for Chriſt will be Lord where He comes. I may conclude now, that my ſelfe and others as my ſelfe, cannot contribute to the battles of the Lord; yet let us contribute to this worke, The ſetting-up a faithfull Miniſtery in the Countries, where Satan has his throne, keepes his intereſt, and holds his poſſeſſion by tenure of ignorance: Let us pray to the Lord, Who workes and none hinders, that the Lord would pitty the Countries which are under the ſhadow of death; that He would ſend forth Angells, unto thoſe dead folkes, to preach unto them, that dwell on the earth, and to every Nation and kindred, and tongue, and people, ſaying with a loud voice, Feare God and give glory to Him, and ſo forth as we have read. Certainely where-ever this voice is heard, there will be a marvailous change; the Lords name blaſphemed there before, will be hallowed, reverenced, ſanctified now in ſome ſuitableneſſe and proportion to ſo great a Majeſty; the Idoll before the eyes, and in the heart, maintained before, and argued for, will be caſt-out now; Gods houſe ſhall be, as it is called, an houſe of prayer; they ſhall worſhip him there in truth, and as He has commanded; the good word of God, and the diſpenſers of it, deſpiſed before, will be honoured now: The Lords day, prophaned there before, will be duely obſerved now, And the Covenant rejected before, will be taken now, and ſtood unto. Doubtleſſe the next newes we ſhall heare is, That Idols, and Idoll-men, and Idoll ſervices are fallen, are fallen; for the Kingdome of the Lord Chriſt is ſet-up, is ſet-up; the everlaſting Goſpell is preached; Angels are ſent-out, are ſent-out upon that meſſage: Certainely that mother of witchcrafts muſt be made manifeſt now, as on the day ſhe was borne, her ſhamefull nakedneſſe muſt appeare; and then ſhe ſhall be cut in ſunder, Amen. And then
it ſhall be with the Church as when that wicked woman was ſlaine, The people of the Land ſhall rejoyce, and the City of God ſhall be 2 Chro. 23. 21. quiet: then ſilence in Heaven, when this wicked woman, ſo gorgeouſly apparelled (yet nothing but earth about her) ſhall be Rev. 17. 4. ſlaine. But O that we did not expect peace before that time, a peace of the worlds giving: O that we were not too haſty, and quite miſtaken in our purſuit after this ſo fundamentall, ſo comprehenſive, ſuch a mother bleſſing Peace: O that we could waite Gods time with patience, and full aſſurance, that they, who waite for Him ſhall find Him, and themſelves no looſers at the laſt. Every thing is good in its ſeaſon; ſo is peace the better, the longer expected; and the more wholeſome, and excellent, if not, as ſome fruits are, ripened before its time. A mercy given too ſoone, when we would have it, proves a judgement after ward. A calme is pleaſanteſt after a ſtorme: ſo is peace, uſhered-in with warre, as this peace muſt be: For I am miſtaken quite in the booke of God, and in our booke of Dayes, Chronicles and Hiſtories of the Church, if a ſore brunt and great fight of afflictions be not yet behind: That wicked woman, the Jezabell of theſe laſt dayes, was long in riſing, by ſtepps and degrees to her height and zenith of her glory: She is now fallen from thence, and ſhe falls apace, yet, by ſtepps and degrees, not yet as a milſtone: She has received a blow, an aſtoniſhing blow on her forehead, and yet the blow, hitting not ſo right, ſhe has broken looſe, as we know an Oxe has done, and is mad with rage: the next blow will ſtrike her at once downe to the ground, Booke of Martyrs. ſhe ſhall not need a ſecond blow; but like a beaſt, whoſe throate is cut, ſhe will ſtruggle for life. All this aſſures us, we muſt expect no peace yet, unleſſe ſuch a peace, which the men of the world give, and that the ſonnes and daughters of God abominate, even all offers and aſſayes that way. They expect warre now and gird-up their loynes in expectation of an hard-brunt, for thus they reaſon, firſt,

1. From ordinary obſervation of our wayes, I ſay ours, a poore ignorant bruitiſh people, they obſerve with what eagerneſſe of ſpirit, and zeale according to our ignorance, we have contended for our Service-booke, and how we pout, and whine, and ſcratch, and bite too, while we have no other weapon, becauſe our Servicebooke is caſt-out: What is become of our Religion, ſay we, how
ſhall we pray now? how ſhall we ſerve God now? and thus we are in a rage, ſtarke mad upon our Idoll, our Maſſe-booke, perſwaded as verily that a Divinity is in that booke, as a people were That the Moone was in the Aſſes belly L. Viv. Com. in Aug. de Civit. Dei. 10. cap. 16.: I think to tell you-out this ſtory hereafter; In the meane time, they that are wiſe in heart doe obſerve this, for thus they reaſon againe;

2. If we are ſo mad now, becauſe that bruitiſh ſervice, which has made us ſo bruitiſh, is caſt-out of the Church; how mad will we be think they, when we our ſelves muſt be caſt-out; when we muſt be excommunicated, thruſt away from partaking of holy bread, becauſe of our uncleaneneſſe; when we muſt be deliveredup to the Devill; (for the deſtruction of our fleſh) when this muſt be (certainely the time is at hand when it muſt be) how mad will we be then, think the wiſe in heart; how will we fret, and fume, and rage, and ſtorme then? Certainely, he that conſiders this, though he conſidereth no more, and though he heares of peace, will yet hearken to the counſell; he that hath no ſword, let him ſell his Luk. 22. 36. garment, and buy one.

A. No need he ſhould be at that coſt, for now the prophecy is fulfilled, Out of Zion is gone forth the Law, and the word of the Iſa. 2. 2. Lord from Jeruſalem: Angells are gone forth with the everlaſting Goſpell; It followes, and the people ſhall beate their ſwords into plow-ſhares, and their ſpeares into pruning hookes; Nation Ezra 2. 4. ſhall not lift-up ſword againſt Nation; neither ſhall they learne warre any more; A bleſſed peace now, now peace, peace, a perfect peace, inward and outward, Amen.

B. I could joyne with you heartily, but ſtay a little, nay, for ought we know, we may ſtay a great while. This promiſe was made to the Church almoſt three thouſand yeares agoe, it is not fulfilled yet; the Church waites the accompliſhment of it now, for it ſhall come to paſſe in the laſt dayes. Theſe dayes are now: But the last dayes containe a large length, and extent of time, they have beene running-out theſe ſixteen hundred yeares, and whether this prophecy ſhall be fulfilled in our dayes, or not, wiſe men cannot tell, ſome of them think not; This is my firſt Anſwer. 2. If by Peace, you underſtand an inward peace, that is peace indeed, then we grant; That, unto whomſoever the word of Chriſt comes with power, it brings this peace along with it, at laſt: I
ſay, at laſt, for at its firſt comming to the heart, it finds all the oppoſition, that the heart can make againſt it; And ſtirres and tumults there will be within this little kingdome, within the mans breaſt: for there are Idols there, which muſt be caſt-out; and he that is called a ſtrong man, muſt be overcome, and his goods ſpoiled; which ſhall be at the laſt. At firſt entrance, there will be an hot contention, stirres and tumults, as was ſaid, even theſe within that little kingdome, the mans own breaſt. And if ſo in that little kingdome, we need not propheſie (for we ſee it fulfilled before our eyes,) what ſtirres, tumults, oppoſitions, perſecutions muſt be expected now, through all the Lords Kingdomes, now that the Angels are gone forth with the everlaſting Gospell: Now that the Mountaine of the LORDS houſe muſt be eſtabliſhed in the top of the mountaines, and muſt be exalted above the hills; now expect fier and ſword, all the oppoſition, that Hell gates, the Devill and his angels by force and fraud can make againſt theſe Angels, who are carrying forth the everlaſting Goſpell; and ſaying with a loud voice, feare God, &c. Now the Nations are angry, the wicked gnaw their tongues; we muſt expect from theſe Nations, theſe Heathen, bruitiſh people, as from an angry people, men mad upon their Idols, and with rage, nothing but fier and ſword; Therefore muſt all, that love the Goſpell, the Nation, and their own lives, all theſe muſt learne warre now; they muſt beat their plowſhares into ſwords, and their pruning-hookes into speares; for never was it known, if you aske from one end of the Heaven to the other, You never read of an unbloody Reformation, when there was ſuch a deformation all over the Church and State. That the Angels lifted-up their voice, ſaying, feare God, &c. and the angry Nations did not lift-up the ſword at the ſame time againſt thoſe Angels: That the Angels preached the Goſpell of Peace, and the Heathen people, yea and men civilized, profeſſing the truth, but denying the power, did not learne to warre againſt it at that very time. Will theſe Angels expect better welcome from the world than their Maſter had, the Angell of the Covenant? No ſooner opened He His mouth to preach, but the people opened their mouth againſt Him, and reached forth their hand to caſt Him downe headlong from the edge of the hill: He would teach them, they would perſecute Him, with the tongue and hand both. His Apoſtles, (men ſent forth to preach,) fared no better, not one of them: But their bruitiſh dealing with Paul is moſt notorious,
we never read or ſaw the like untill this very day, Ile but point to it. It muſt be ſo, and ſo it muſt be expected; Theſe Angels, like Paul Acts 19. and the other Angels, will turne the world upſide downe, and the little world we call man there, all upſide downe; they will tell men as plainely as Paul did, That thoſe are not gods which are made with hands; They will bid men feare God, worſhip Him, that made Heaven and earth, and the ſea; this is to turne the world and men therein upſide downe, for it is to turne the heart Heaven-ward wherto it ſtood croſſe ever ſince it had a being. We cannot think now, that ſuch turnings upſide down, can be without confuſed noiſe; for in this turning, Heaven & earth are brought together. We expect now the downfall of Antichiſt, he muſt fall, he muſt fall down, down like a milſtone into the great waters, how great will that fall be! There will be a great noiſe ſure, for all the ſhoulders in earth and in Hell, are conjoyned to ſupport and hold-up Babylon: When all theſe ſhoulders ſhall crack and its pillars be broken to pieces like earthen veſſels; there will be a great noiſe ſure! We underſtand by reading, that the prophecy is fulfilling now, when the mountaine of the LORDS houſe ſhall be eſtabliſhed on the top of the mountaines, and exalted above the hills; Now the Devill and his angels, the mountaines and the hills, the Kings and Rulers on the earth will bend all their force to hinder the accompliſhment of this prophecy, which does aſſure us, that theſe mountaines and hills ſhall now be made plaines, therefore the gates of Hell ſtand wide open now to oppoſe the exaltation of Chriſts Kingdome; A mighty oppoſition, and a confuſed noiſe will be now, the ruſhing of Nations as of mighty waters will be heard now.
A. Why now? does the preaching of the Goſpell, or the Angels that preach it, cauſe this confuſed noiſe, ſore paine, and trouble to the inhabitants of the earth?

B. Yes that it does, by accident, as ſchollers ſay; As the Sunbeames cauſe the poiſon in a ſerpent to appeare, & drawes forth its malignancy; The Sun puts no poiſon there, but finds it there, draws it forth, and actuates the ſame. You may, for farther illuſtration, compare the malignant-Lords and Rulers of the world to a dunghill; (to that ſtinking place, the beſt men of the world have compared their own hearts, to a dunghill) The Sun puts no filthy ſent there, nor are the Sun-beames impured or defiled by ſhining there,
(nothing can defile the Sun-beames) but the Sun-beames upon the dunghill drawes forth a filthy ſavour thence, makes it reak there: ſo the ſetting-up the Lord Chriſt upon His holy hill, does not put any rage, envy or malice into the hearts of His adverſaries, the Princes of the earth and Rulers there; no, all this is in the heart before, as in its proper place; but now it is quickned, and actuated by the brightneſſe of His comming, as the poiſon in the ſerpent, or as the filth in a dunghill by the heat of the Sun, and cleareneſſe of his beames. The maine intendment of the Goſpell, and of thoſe, that preach it, is, to cauſe peace to the earth. But there is much bloodſhed there, which the earth has drunk-in, and this muſt be diſcovered, yea and required alſo: There are many Idols there, thoſe muſt be caſt forth as abominable things, and that cauſeth the troubles, ſhakings of Kingdomes, and earthquakes as at this day; And indeed the Nations muſt be ſhaken, before the Lord Chriſt can be the deſire of the Nations. And this is the power of Hag. 2. 7. the Goſpell, or the Goſpell preached with power, to ſhake the Nations terribly, to make the earth tremble. Then you will ſay,

A. Give us our Idolls againe, crucifixes and Images, and our Idoll-Prieſts and their Idoll-ſervices, as in our Cathedrals, and in the Kings and Queenes Chappels [where there were mimick Jer. • 4. 17. actions, and antick geſtures, not altogether ſo ridiculous as now they are in the Jewes Synagogues: but altogether as abominable in Gods ſight there and here, yet give them thoſe ſervices againe] for then it was better with us (as they ſaid it was with them, when they offered to the Queene of Heaven.)

B. The anſwer is neare: The ſame, which Jeremiah made to thoſe people of old; did not the Lord remember our doings? our abominable ſervices, came they not into His mind? So that the Lord could no longer beare, becauſe of the evill of our doings, and the abominations, which we have committed? So it may be ſaid to us, therefore the ſword devoureth as at this day; our abominable Idols ſet-up before the eye, and kept-up within the heart, our abominable ſervices unto them, have cauſed all this; and now that the light is come, and has diſcovered all this, ſo that the earth ſhall no longer cover her ſlaine, nor hold faſt her Idols, therefore is the earth-quake.

And now to ſhut-up this Chapter, with the beſt-counſell, and to
follow the beſt example, let us doe now as they doe whoſe God is their portion and His peace their legacy. Theſe doe not ſtand expecting when peace will be in England: not when the King will come home to his Parliament (he muſt come home to himſelfe firſt, and then all the Chriſtian world ſhall heare of it, what a ſhaking there is in his breaſt) theſe tarry not for man, nor waight for the ſons of men. They will doe their duty, ſearch their own Tents, thruſt-out the Idols thence, that is firſt. They will ſeeke to God alwayes; And, not ignorant of the Devils wiles, nor of his malice, nor of his ſtrength, that now he and his angels will caſt about the rage of their wrath, diſcharge againſt the City of God (the butt and marke of their malice) all their granadoes, fiery darts, haileſtones and coales of fier, ſo to ſtorme the City of God; knowing all this, theſe ſervants of the Lord will take unto them the whole Armour of GOD, They-will gird their loynes with Epheſ. 6. Truth; fence their hearts with righteouſneſſe, their feet with Patience; They will put on the helmet of ſalvation, and ſhield of faith; they will take unto them the ſword of the Spirit, which is the word of God: for the ſame word, which ſo ſhakes the earth now, and, againſt the nature of it, ſo diſquiets the inhabitants of Babilon, becauſe of their poiſonous natures, will be the beſt weapon a man can take both for offence and defence: and will procure aſſured quiet, reſt and peace at the laſt: I ſay, as aforeſaid, at the last; for while the mountaine of holineſſe (called the mountaine of the Lord, becauſe of its excellency, ſtability and perpetuity) is exalting in the heart, there will be ſtirres and tumults there, as are now in the world, for hills muſt be made levell there alſo, and mountaines muſt be plaines; But when this mountaine is exalted there, then there is peace, be the Nations never ſo unquiet: And ſo in the world, when the mountaine of Gods houſe is exalted above the hills and mountaines, then Peace, Peace, a perfect peace, a peace of Gods making, a created peace.
A. But there are faire offers and overtures towards peace now.

B. See! what hearkning there is ſtill after a peace from the world; I pray you hearken what the word of God ſayes, which is this, That out of the ſame mouth does not proceed bleſſing and Jam 3. 12, 12. curſing: as the ſame fountaine does not ſend forth, at the ſame place, ſweet waters and bitter. Theſe things ought not ſo to be, nay
they cannot be: they cannot call for a curſe upon the Land, and call for a bleſſing, a bleſſed Peace at the ſame time: The ſame hands cannot grievouſly oppreſſe the people; and, at the ſame time, eaſe their conſciences; Theſe things ought not to be, nay they cannot be; theſe are the wiles, depths, and deceits of Satan, all to ſtop the Angels way, that the everlaſting Goſpell may not be preached to them that dwell in the earth; therefore we regard not what is parlied on touching a peace of mens making; But by the good Hand of God with us, we will heare the Angels voyce, ſaying, Feare God, and give Glory to Him, and worſhip Him, as He has commanded, in Spirit and in Truth. And then, though the earthquake continue (as it is like to doe, for the bloud is not diſcovered yet, nor required, as it muſt be; nor are the idols caſt forth yet,) yet the ſervants of the Lord ſhall not be greatly moved, though the Lord ſhould forſake the earth, yet He wil not forſake His people.
A. Ai, But His People are very low.

B. Like enough they may be lower; and yet not ſo low as their Head and Lord was. But He is riſen, and the higher He is riſen, the lower He was; and as ſure as He is riſen, ſo ſure His Church ſhall riſe, for they muſt be made like Him, as in ſufferings, ſo in Glory. In the meane time, the Lord will give His ſervants quietneſſe, and aſſured Reſt in the moſt unſetled and unquiet times; Peace in God, and then Peace Peace, Peace in life, and Peace in Death, Peace Peace, a perfect Peace, Amen. And ſo we underſtand fully, what Peace is to be expected now from the world, now that the Goſpel is preached there. But the ſervants of the Lord ſerve a good Maſter, and He has ſpoken to the hearts of His people good words and comfortable, In ME PEACE; be of good cheere, I have overcome the world. I come now to the devout ſouldier.

div.head: § III. The Word of GOD mighty to poſture a mans ſelfe.

argument.p: Of high account, and pretious uſe.

div.p:
THis man can ſpeake great things of the Word of God; for, through God, it has wrought great things in Him, a wonderfull change: he that was blind before, now ſees, [As in making
the world, light was the firſt creature: ſo in making a man every whit new, the firſt work is the ſetting-up a light in the underſtanding; that worke is done] The Word, not as ſpoken by man, but ſpoken with a ſtrong hand, has wrought-upon the will too, has made that pliable, and flexible, which was ſtubborne and ſtiffe, as an Iron ſinnew before, and cleane croſſe to the good pleaſure of God; it is wrought-up now, it is turned back: and it is as wonderfull as was the turning back of Jord in or a Giant in his courſe: All is turned now, the whole man from darkneſſe to light, from ſerving of Idols to ſerve the living God. By the good Word of God, received in truth, this man is emptyed now, (in his meaſure) of himſelf, ſelfe pleaſing, ſelfe ſeeking, that great idoll of the world, which crams and fils-up the heart ſo brim-full, that it leaves no roomth there, for God and our neighbour: This man is emptied of himſelfe now, and filled with God. The first Table, the commands there, is this mans firſt and chiefe delight; and the ſecond Table, the commands there, is next unto it; His inward man takes delight in the Law of God; He loves God above himſelfe, and more then heaven; and his neighbour as himſelfe: In a word, he is made poore in ſpirit, and rich in Faith: and all this is done by the Word of God, made mighty through God, bleſſed be his Name. And now how ſweet is the Word of God unto him! ſweeter than honey, or the honey combe: he eſteemes it more than his neceſſary food. The Job 23. 12. word of God • now he ſees it, and underſtands it, he ſees wondrous excellencies in it, therefore he meditates thereon day and night. It is his Oracle, he does all he does by direction therefrom, for it is Quid eſt Scriptura ſacra niſi quadam epiſtola omniſ o • Dei ad creaturam ſuam. GODS mouth, his Lords will concerning his ſervant; A letter ſent unto him from God Himſelfe to ſignifie His pleaſure to the Children of men; It is of the higheſt account with him, for it makes him, as it did David, wiſer than Saul and his politike Councellours, theſe were Davids enemies; wiſer than the Doctours Pſal. 119. 100. and Rabbins, they were his teachers: more prudent than men of large, and long experience, they are the ancients. The good word of God! this fits him with counſell and ſtrength, and all for war; This ſupplies him with every part, and parcell of his Armour, tels him how to put it-on, and gird it unto him, even the whole Armour of God. The word of God! with that he chargeth and charmeth every luſt, he ſtils them, and they are quiet; and if they riſe againe to
ſtorme his ſoule, he ſtormeth them by the Word of God; he brings his Idols before that Glory, and ſo ſlayeth them before the Lord: It is light with him now, for the Word of God is in his heart; he lieth-downe with it, riſeth-up with it; walkes with-it, it is his companion; O how ſafely does he goe • how wiſely does he order his ſteps! The Word of God is a light unto him, that goes before, he followes; he ſees now little ſmall ſinnes, if we might call (in compariſon we may) any ſinnes ſmall, or little, which are committed againſt a great God: and makes us liable to great wrath, he ſees the ſmalleſt ſinnes, for he is light in the LORD: The Sun of Righteouſneſſe has darted-in His beames into his ſoule: where the ſun-beames come, there moates are ſeene; when in the night of ignorance and ſuperſtition mountaines are covered from our eyes, ſinnes that reach as high as heaven: This man diſcerneth ſmall ſinnes, and is humbled for them, for he is light in the Lord; and he walkes in the light; he has a word for every thing, and there-after he moves: Therefore it is, that he delights ſo much in the good Word of God, more as was ſaid, than in his ordinary food; he is ſtill looking into his Fathers will, for there he lookes to find all concerning him; And he knowes in all his heart, and in all his ſoule, that not one thing of all the good things, contained in that booke, ſhall Joſ •• 23. 14. faile: All ſhall be made-out unto him, through the hands of his Mediatour, in the fitteſt time, as it has been to all the ſervants of the Lord, before him, and ſhall be, To all after him, unto the worlds end. And now it is the deſire of his ſoul, that all may partake of the good Word of God; taſte the ſame ſweetneſſe in it, as he does, and ſee the ſame wondrous excellencies in this law as he ſees. It grieves his ſoule, and he weepes in ſecret, that there ſhould be any places in Judah, where God is not knowne; where the dead bury the dead, and the blind lead the blind every day: where there are like Prieſts and like People, one as brutiſh as the other. Therefore he contends mightily, that able and fit men be ſent-out to all townes and Cities, who can inſtruct, teach, and catechiſe young and old, (the old needs inſtruction as much as the young, more neceſſary to both than their daily food, to be inſtructed) in the good Word of God; he ſets to his ſhoulder with all his might, that the Lord Chriſt may be lifted-up to his Throne, that his Ordinances may be ſet-up in their purity, not mixed, nor mated with the mixtures of
men, and their fooleries: for where the good Word of God is ſetup, whether in a Towne, or in a man only, there idols fall: By the ſame degrees as the Lord Chriſt is exalted, idols are thrown down; If he heare the good Word of God is preached, then he knowes what will follow, Babylon is fallen, is fallen, the idols of his own heart, theſe are fallen; and the idols in the land ſhall be ſhaken-out of the land too, and then Chriſt ſhall be the deſire of the nations: All theſe things ſhall be according as the Lord Chriſt takes to Himſelfe power; As light breakes-out, ſo darkneſſe vaniſheth away: By the ſame degrees as the Word goes forth, and the ordinances are ſet-up, ſo ſuperstition, hereſie, and prophaneneſſe fals. Therefore all his delight is in the Word of God, and in thoſe, that are the publiſhers of it, and ſo he concludes.

div.head: CHAP. IIII. The Sanctification of the Lords day, an excellent meanes to poſture a Kingdome.

argument.p:
The profanat • on of it muſt worke contrary effects; The Biſhops Doctrine and practice m • ſt notorious that way; The meanes by which they pre
••• led with the people and made them as brut • ſh as themſelves. The Par
〈◊〉
