•• t doe worke now as all the Worthies of the Lord before them: but Then they w • rk • to purpoſ • , when the Biſhops are caſt-out and their book • into the ſ • e, whereby we have been taught, yea compelled to prophane the Lords d • y by a l • w; and when the ordinances and good lawes touching that ſole •• e mat •• r, are indeed and fully executed.

div.p:
THere is one day in the weeke of ſpeciall obſervation ſet apart for ſpeciall ſervices, more ſpecially for the making knowne this good Word of God, the declaring, interpreting, giving the ſenſe thereof unto the people; This is the Lords day, the only Holy Day, deputed and ſet-apart for that Holy Holy ſervice, to be performed in publique and private: We muſt obſerve now in paſſage, the counter workings of the Adverſary, the Devill and his Angels; Theſe marred the beauty of this Day, more than of any day: they plotted as great a diſhonour to that Day as their fathers did to the Lord of that Day, when they platted a crowne of thornes for His head: the Adverſary and enemie did; what did they doe? All
the Chriſtian world knowes what, and did they know no more of their witchcrafts, prophanations, impieties, iniquities, no more but what they did againſt the Lords Day in ſcorne of That Day, and the Lord of that Day, even that were enough to render them as they are, odious and abominable unto all the world to the worlds end.
A. The world knowes, and muſt not forget their vertues; the Biſhops did ſome good workes, and they wrote a few good books, that they did;

B. A few indeed; I have much to reply to that, and ſome replication is made. But I will ſay no more to that here but this, and this I will inſiſt upon, They did prophane the Lords Day by a law, that they did, and having ſaid that I have ſaid all; When the Lord complaines, ſayes Mr Calvin, [he is much quoted to juſtifie the taking liberty on the Lords Day: and a liberty to change that Day to any other day in the weeke, which every ſober man knowes now (for the light is cleare) that all the wiles, d • pths, policies of Satan could never effect, and never ſhall, for ſo the Righteous God decreed, that the Jewes Sabbath, a memoriall of the Creation: and the Chriſtians Sabbath of the Redemption, ſhould be both ſo obſerved to the worlds end, as that the ſix-dayes of the weeke ſhould be kept intire not broken: But though Calvin be quoted for this negligent conceit] yet thus he ſayes, when the LORD complaines, That His ſacred Majeſtie is contemned, His commands ſlighted;Ezek. 20. 21. that His people have provoked Him more than any people; then the Lord ſaies no more but this, They have polluted my Sabbaths; intimating this now, that, as the honour and height of Religion in thoſe dayes conſiſted ſpecially in the due obſervation of the Sabbath Day: ſo now in the obſervation of the Lords Day: And that the breach of that law, and the pollution of that ſacred Rest was the greateſt diſobedience then, and ſo the complement, the very filling-up of their iniquitie now. But ſo the Biſhops and their C •
r •• tes have done, they have ſo polluted that Holy Day, their Lords Day, ſo polluted it, as the heathen never did their dayes ſacred to their gods: for they thruſt forth thoſe Paſtours, that were not ſo brutiſh as themſelves, and ſet up a Minſtrill in his ſtead, and a May-pole, and gave free libertie to all that would, the Minſtrill to play, and the people to dance before it. This was the readieſt
way that could be thought on (and that the Biſhops knew very well) to cut the ſinnewes of a nation; to weaken, to infeeble a people, to make them fit for war, ſaid that curſed paper, To make them fit to be devoured by war, as it is at this day.

I will ſtir-in the Biſhops ſinke a little more, for it is fit that their ſtinke ſhould goe through the land, and come-up into the noſtrils of all the inhabitants there at this time: for now Gods Hand is ſore upon-us, it may be we will conſider what Biſhops we had, and what an Advouſion of libettie they gave us, and how we accepted of it, as men in covenant with Hell, and in love with death; The Lord is now warring with the land, He is powring downe His wrath upon us, and we complaine bitterly: O that we could underſtand what our Prieſts have done, and what we have done; They made voide the law of God, and we loved to have it ſo, and never conſidered what would be the end thereof; never thought of that. Let us thinke of it now, and then we ſhall ſay, The LORD is Righteous, we, our Princes, our Prieſts, and our people, we have all ſinned a great ſinne, they in giving, we in taking paſs-times, and ſports on the Lords Day, which were not lawfull on any Day: but on the Lords Day, how ſtupendious, how aſtoniſhing a profanation on that Day! They and we [but if our Prieſts have no conſideration, how ſhould we conſider, and yet we had a naturall light, which we ſhould not have put-out] we ſhould have thought upon ſome other Day, for now we have done juſt as the ſtrumpet did, I have Peace offerings with me this day, ſaid ſhe, I have paid my vowes, come let us take our fill of love; Her Adulterie had been hainous on any day, but this greatly aggravated her ſin, that the ſelfſame day ſhe had been at the ſacrifice and Altar, the very ſame day ſhe went to the Adulterers bed [ſome Popiſh votaries are reported to be very foul this way, riſing from the harlots ſides to conſecrate the Sacrament, and then from the Sacrament to the harlots bed] our Prieſts have committed as great a ſacriledge in this point, touching the Lords Day; and, which aggravates the ſame, they have commanded the ſame ſacriledge, that we ſhould riſe from our ſeats in the Church to drunkenneſſe, to a prophanation of Gods Name, to riot and wantonneſſe, for all this is in this granted libertie, as in a root of bitterneſſe, ſpringing-up, whereby many are defiled: and we muſt grant it to be as ſacrilegious and foul every whit,
to riſe from our ſeats at Church, to goe to the Ale-bench, to tiple there, or to the May-pole to riot there, as it is to come from tipling and rioting unto our ſeats at Church, there to preſent our ſelves before God and His People, with them to partake of the Holy holy Word of God.

I pray you let us conſider this alſo, that this libertie does not only prophane the Day, which we, common people, are not ſenſible of, but it doth utterly deforme the Solemnity and Beautie of the Day, even to the eye and eare of the meaneſt Perſon and of the loweſt conceit; The Beautie of the world is but from that comely order, wherein every creature is placed, and thence the Beautie and comelineſſe of the body, Our little world, in the conformitie and comely proportion of the parts with the whole: ſo alſo the Beauty and comelineſſe of the Day conſiſteth in the ſutableneſſe and congruitie of ſervices upon the Day, that they be homogeniall, and conſiſtent one with another, and holding ſome conformitie with the holineſſe of Him whoſe Day it is. Experience tels us, That comely upper-parts and lower-parts uncomely ſute not well: Becauſe comelineſſe ſtands in • n one-neſſe, in a fit agreement of many parts to one: If one ſhould take away but the haire from off one of the eye-browes, it would diminiſh nothing (ſaith August.) from the D • Civit. lib. 〈◊〉 . cap.
• 2. bulke of the body, but very much from the beauty of the body: ſo exactly and curiouſly hath the Lord framed it, ſo decently, and every part in ſuch order, giving comelineſſe to every part, and a fit agreement of all the parts with one. And certainly, He that hath made the body ſo comely, and ſtampt upon it ſuch beauty, doth require that we make an honourable account of our body, as of the Temple of God: and maintaine the beauty of the Day alſo in keeping unto ſuch Duties as are comely, holding a congruitie, a correſpondencie, a conſiſtencie with the holineſſe of the Day, and with the Lord of the Day. If we ſhould ſee a body whoſe upper-parts were like a man, and whoſe lower-parts were like a beaſt, we could not well tell what to call it, but a monſter it is in nature. And is it not as monſtrous to ſee one part of the Day dedicated to God, in ſervices ſutable unto Him, and beſeeming His M • jeſtie! [for if we are to entreat the ſervants of Chriſt in a Godly ſort 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , in a comely fitting manner, as is worthy of God, and as we may expect acceptance at His hands: much more ſhould we ſo obſerve,
and uſe the Lords day, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , as becometh the Lord of the 3 Joh. 6. Qui ingreditur ad placandum non de • et egredi ad exacerb • ndum, neque enim 〈◊〉 officij eſt indulgentiam poſcere & iracundiam provocare. Sed aliud ora hominum aliud corda agunt, & dum verbis praeterita mal • plangunt ſenſ • futura meditantur, &c. Denique ſi 〈◊〉 quiſp • am ſcire quid in templo • ujuſmodi homines cogitaverint videat quid ſequatur, Salv. de gub. l. 3. p. 89, 190. Ingyrum acti, poteſtatem • undi quò vellent, &c. Buxh •• mj Queſt. Rom. 4 • p 128. day.] And is it not I ſay, as monſtrous to ſee one part of the day dedicated to God, and another part of the day devoted to the Devill, in ſuch ſports and paſſe-times as are ſutable to, and advantagious for the enlargement of his kingdomes; let me contribute hither, Salvians words, which are to this purpoſe; Now I come into Gods houſe to partake of the ordinances there, that I may obtaine grace, and be edified, or built up therein: Then I goe-out to trample upon grace, and to throw away what before I had received: Nay I come-into Gods houſe, to appeaſe Gods wrath, then I goe-out to provoke His anger, as if it were not ſo much as the anger of a man: Now I come-in ſetting my face towards God, then I goe-out turning my back upon Him. This is to provoke the HIGH And LOFTY ONE; To make Him (in the day of our trouble and out-cry,) to turne to us the back alſo and not the face: It is to make our ſelves, and our ſacrifice an abomi
• ation.

Hitherto I have been opening the Biſhops Charter, the height, bredth and extent of it, which thoſe Princes have indulged, extended and enlarged (for they muſt beare the odium of it) to us ward. They made us a free-people after the manner the Romanes uſed to make their ſervants free; They turned them round, bid them looke what way pleaſed them beſt, and take it: So the Biſhops ſaid to us; When you have ſa • e out your houre at Divine-ſervice, then take your own way, as is beſt pleaſing in your own eyes; If to the Alehouſe, then thither; If to the May-pole, then thither. And that we may not doubt of the validity of this Charter, it was ratified and confirmed to us by great Divines, Engliſh, French, Dutch, but all ſpake Engliſh to us, in ſeverall Treatiſes and Sermons; The firſt Dr White Pi
• hop of Ely, now gone to his own place. Treatiſe enveighed againſt the Sabbatarians [Thoſe indeed, who, in the ſtrength of God, and His command, did and now doe, ſanctifie a reſt unto the LORD.] A ſecond Dr Hey •• n a notable,, writes an Hiſtory of the Sabbath; A third D •
D •• , a ca • e not hal • e baked; he is • alled Dove, a ſilly man without an heart. appeares by his ſcribble to be one of the Tribe, and faction: but carried the diſpute warily, ſhewed his ſpirit againſt God and good men, and now has declared himſelfe a very malignant.—A fourth Dr
〈◊〉 , a notori • es blaſphemer. preached againſt the Day, told us it was no Sabbath. A Dr Turner a notorious Divine.
• ift grants it to be a Sabbath, but intended only for maſter and ſervant, to riot all that day, re • erving;
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
only two houres for Divine ſervice: and he thanks the holy Fathers of the Church for granting that liberty. A ſixt Dr Prideaux then; now Biſhop would be. , whom I ſhould have named firſt, becauſe he was Chaire-man in Oxford, did reade a Lecture upon the Sabbath.

Now he that can reade and hath examined what he reades, has ſeen clearely, that theſe Treatiſers, and Sermoniſts have given no more honour to their LORDS DAY, than the Romanes gave to their Gooſes holy-day, (ſuch a day they had in their Calender.)Aug. de Civit. 2. 2 • . But we common-people reade nothing, nor regard what is written: We hearken only to what others ſay, make uſe of their readings and obſervations, ſpecially upon ſuch a ſubject as this is, of liberty: And thus we have heard thoſe ſay that have read our Prieſts books, and obſerve unto us, That our Prieſts in the firſt place,
1. Put-in this Caution: we muſt not call the Day, Sabbath (a ſanctified reſt) that was Jewiſh [they might call it Sunday, for that is no more heatheniſh than Moonday is.]

2. They aſſured us. That the fourth Commandement had no binding power with a Chriſtian, [That pleaſed the people well, we might riot as aforeſaid, for we had the leave, yea the command of the Magiſtrate, and no law againſt it; for a Law, without a binding Lex ſine coertione null • . power, is like a b • ll without a clapper.] Thus we were made free-men, turned round, and at liberty to take what way they pleaſed.

3. They told us moreover, That they who would not run with us into the ſame exceſſe of riot, were too ſuperstitious, as the Sabbatarians were of old, and the Jewes before them. Theſe words did eate like a Gangreene, It is neceſſary, I tell the Reader what theſe Sabbatarians were, and how the Jewes ſome of them of old were charged. The Sabbatarians in the enemies account, and as they told us, were almoſt as ſuperſtitious, as the Jewes were, who, in obedience to Gods command [Abide you every man in his place: Exod. 16. 29. let no man goe out of his place on the ſeventh day] but miſtaking it quite, kept themſelves to their place, and to the ſame poſture of body, (kneeling or holding up the hands) all day long, wherein they had ſet themſelves in the morning. Ile reply a word to this in paſſage; That, though the Adverſary quotes his Authour for this, yet this is an horrible lye, impoſſible to be true: For chooſe the eaſieſt poſture of body that is conceiveable, ſitting, or lying, or ſtanding,
or kneeling, and you cannot keepe to it all day long. But ſuppoſe, that there were ſome of them ſo ſuperſtitious, ſo to doe; yet this cannot prove that the Sabbatarians ancient or moderne, were as ſuperſtitious as theſe Jewes are ſaid to be.

Yes ſayes the enemy to all goodneſſe; The Sabbitarians were, and now are, almoſt, as ſuperſtitious as the Jewes were; For though they did not abide and keepe to one place, yet they doe keepe-to one worke all day-long: They heare at Church, and they repeate at home, and in ſo doing they croſſe the practiſe of the This fellow conſidered not, That where the Lord Himſelfe is, there is a Sermon: And the place where the Lord Chriſt came, He made it a Synagogue to His ſervants. In Deo hoc speciale eſt, quod quem • un
que locum ſu • dignatur preſentiâ ſanctificat. Cat. Eccleſ. 39. Lord Chriſt Himſelfe, who ſtatim a Synagogâ, preſently from the Synagogue went unto Simons houſe to dinner: for now He had ended His Sabbath dayes worke. O horrible! what a blaſphemy is this! This is Pocklington, a notoriou • —and blaſphemer. I paſſe over this blaſphemy, noting this by the way, That the enemy could not ſpeake more peſtilent and corrupting words, than theſe are to our eares; Alas! our manner is not to repeate Sermons; No, no ſooner are we out of the Church, but our talking is of Oxen, and making of furroughes. As for the word of God, if we are not aſleepe, we let it-in, never ruminate or chooe upon it; it will nouriſh as our meate does we think, though we never thinke of it afterward: A damnable conceit! yet we are ſtrongly conceited, that ſo careleſſe we may be, for the enemy ſets before us the example of the LORD JESƲS, ſo blaſpheming the ſtepps of the LORDS ANOYNTED: I forbeare now, that I may proceed a little farther: And ile grant,

That the Sabbatarians, ancient and moderne, are not almoſt, but altogether as ſuperſtitious as were the Jewes of old, they will abide in one place all the Sabbath long: Be it ſo, ſo that place be not in an Ale-houſe, or before a May-pole. But indeed it was no better then ſuperſtition, to keepe to one place and one poſture all day long; And yet their ſuperſtition will riſe-up in judgement againſt the monſtrous prophaneneſſe of our Prieſts and people, one giving, and the other taking a liberty to riſe-up from their ſeat at Church, to play and riot on the Lords day. The Habbaſens, ſayes Brerewood, Enqui • ies, 25. thought it not lawful for them, after the receiving of the Sacrament, to ſpit that day till the ſetting of the Sun. This was ſuperſtition too; but yet this reproves our bruitiſh Prieſts and p • ople, the one giving the other taking an exceſſe in tipling and drinking
that day, till they overcharge themſelves ſo, that they muſt ſpue that day. But thus charitable our Biſhops and Prieſts are, to us, they will not have us be ſuperſtitious, becauſe we are Chriſtians; thanke them for that; But let us remember, becauſe we are Chriſtians, we muſt not walke more looſe than did the Heathens; No, ſay they, nor ought we to be ſo ſtrict in obſerving our Lords day as the Jewes were in obſerving their Sabbath day: We are not bound-up ſo cloſe as were the Jewes; we have more liberty than they, for we are not under the Law, but under grace.

True; but take we heed of turning ſuch grace into wantonneſſe: Mr Jewell inſtructs us very well at this point, from his booke I take theſe words, Ʋnder the Law, then it was, Chriſt ſhall come; now it is, Chriſt is come: ſhall come, and is come, are ſundry words, but Chriſt is all one Yune Chri •• us ve • tur • s, 〈◊〉 Chriſtus venit; ventur as & venit d • verſa verba ſunt ••
• dem Chriſt •• . : (So) The Jewes had their Sabbath then, we have our Sabbath now; Then, and now, are divers words, the Reſt is the ſame to both, and the Reaſons the ſame, binding both: but our band is the ſtronger. Stronger! Infinitly ſtronger. And let the Anti-nomian, he that is againſt the whole Law (if there be ſuch a madde fellow in the world, for • ure he is not ſober) let him heare this, as it referres only to the fourth Commandement. Tell me, why ſhould the Chriſtian take more liberty in the world, than the Jewes did? why ſhould the Chriſtian be more looſe on his Lords day, than the Jew was on his Sabbath-day? Good reaſon you will ſay, Becauſe the Jew was held under a yoake like Iſacher, crouching downe under that burden: But Chriſt has made the Chriſtian a free-man. That is true, and he is free indeed. But, as it is the greateſt honour in Heaven, ſo it is the greateſt engagement on earth, to ſerve before Him: Where there is a breaking of the yoake; there is a making that people goe upright Lev. 26. 1 • . Qu • a pura eſt pupilla oru itum para eſſet 〈◊〉 bo •• inis vit • . Degu • Dei l. 3 p. • 8, 84. Pl •• ex •• it Deus a Chriſtianis, &c. A • e •
• a 〈◊〉 rel • atio eſt, ••• M •••• o devoti •• em no ••• um • et o •• p. • avit Salv. ad E • cle. Ca • h l. 2. p. 38 4, 38. , walking according to the truth of the Gospell. Salvians words are very remarkeable, The life of a Chriſtian ſhould be kept as pure as the apple of his eye: then he puts it downe poſitively, and proves it notably, That God doth require more of Chriſtians, then of the Jewes. Chriſtians have greater prerogatives than the Jews had, why then is not our bond of obedience, as ſtrong as the •• s was? Yes, doubtleſſe, and the reaſon is plaine, which he gives forth with a full hand, and in full weight, and demonſtration of the Spirit: That the Chriſtians prerogatives are above the Jews; So he inferres, and
concludes, Therefore we pay more, becauſe we owe more: therefore we muſt be more devout, becauſe the Lord hath purchaſed our devotion at a greater price. So Salvian. Ile now draw-up to this concluſion, which I find made to our hands, a thouſand yeares agoe Lege Oſiand. Epit. C • nt. 6. l. 4. c. 14. Art. 1. That we are to ſet-apart and to ſanctifie a day to the Lord, and to ſanctifie it as the Lords day, in exerciſes well fitting the day, and enjoyned by Statute-Law, long ſince upon the day, and the fore-going evening of the day: And, which is yet more obſervable, enjoyned alſo, That the Prieſts, implacabiliter and in an holy indignation, ſhould very ſeverely puniſh ſuch as would violate this Statute-Law; I thought it fit to put downe this Statute in the laſt place, enacted a thouſand yeares agoe, that we might ſee, what a wide difference there is, betwixt the Prieſts now, and the Prieſts in thoſe dayes; The Prieſts then implacabiliter, they muſt have no peace with them, who wilfully broke the Law of their God; who would not apply themſelves to the duties of the day; and, on the evening before the day prepare themſelves for thoſe duties: So the Prieſts a 1000 yeares agoe in thoſe darke dayes; our Prieſts now in the Sun-ſhine of the Goſpell, implacabiliter, they were in a rage with thoſe, who would not teach the people, yea command them to riot, to dance, to drinke, to ſpue on that day: Ah Lord, what Prieſts have we in our dayes, how different from thoſe in thoſe dayes? Our Prieſts have committed a great ſacriledge, never the like; The Lord Chriſt reſerved to Himſelfe but one day, gave us ſix dayes; our Prieſts took from their Lord, that one day, and gave it to the people, that they alſo might plat a garland of May-flowers, and, in ſcorne of their Lord and His day, ſet that garland upon that day: We had ſix dayes, the Biſhops and Curates had exceeding many Holy-dayes (the Church can ſpare them every one) yet the Biſhops spared to take any one of our ſix dayes, or of their own holy-dayes, though (ſo many) and tooke that one day, ſet that ſcorne upon the Lords-day. An horrible ſacriledge.

We hope the Worthies of the Lord will obſerve all this; they will implacabiliter, they will be carried with an indignation againſt theſe vile Prieſts, who have walked ſo contrary againſt God, and good men. I know, what has been done againſt theſe Prieſts, and their bookes, and that many wholeſome Laws, and good ordinances
are made, and iſſued forth; bleſſed be God. But yet God will have more done againſt them, who have done ſo preſumptuouſly againſt Him; more muſt be done againſt them than is a bare taking from them their office; They commanded the people of the Land to riot, to drinke, to be drunken, to ſpue on the Lords day; the Lord will have them spued-forth for this: And for theſe Infidels bookes, [I ſay Infidels, for when they doe beleeve unto ſalvation, they will confeſſe, and ſhew their deeds, and bring forth their books, Acts 19. 19. with their own hands, and burne them before all men, as we reade they dealt with their bookes, which yet had not bewitched the people, ſo as theſe Infidels bookes have done] theſe muſt be purged in the fire; That all the Chriſtian world may take knowledge, that the Church of England abhorres thoſe more than heatheniſh doctrines contained therein, which have laid the whole Land [I can take no good man off from communing with his own heart; and ſearching out his ſins alſo, added to the common heape, and as fuell to the common fire] under the wrath of the Lord: So as the wonder is, that the whole Land is not Hormah, utter deſolation: The Lord is gratious, He remembers he has a people in the Land, whoſe ſoules abhorred that prophanation; But becauſe of thoſe heatheniſh bookes, permitted in a Chriſtian Church, therefore a fire is kindled againſt Jacob, and anger is come up againſt Iſraell:Pſal. 78. 21. ver. 49. Therefore the Lord has caſt upon us the fierceneſſe of His anger, wrath and indignation, and trouble: He has ſent evill angels among us. We cannot doubt but the conſideration hereof and of the premiſes, will kindle the zeale of our Worthies, and make it burne ſeven times hotter than ordinary. They will take for an enſample Nehemiah, who loved his Nation, and was zealous for it, and fervent in ſpirit, for the glory of his God, which he ſhewed in nothing more, than in vindicating the diſhonour put upon the Sabbath day, The ſame reaſon of zeale for the Lords day. We will obſerve with all obſervation, how zealous Nehemiah was, and what kindled his zeale, and ſet it all on a flame, made him ſo earneſt; what was it? The judgement of God, like a great mountaine, was ſtill before his eyes: The people did not hearken to hallow the Sabbath day, ſayes Nehe. 13. 17. he, and not to beare a burden entring-in at the gates: Therefore the LORD kindled a fire in the gates thereof, which is not quenched at this day: Nehe • iah remembers the people of that ſore bnrning, Jer. 17. 27.
(hotter than was that at Taberah) the thoughts of that heated him ſo, that he contends with the Nobles and Merchants about it, and chargeth the Prieſts and Levites touching that matter. Numb. 11. 3. The zeale of the Nobles and Worthies now need riſe no higher, than as Nehemiahs zeale roſe then: and ſo high it ſhould riſe, for there is the ſame cauſe; The fier of Gods wrath is now burning amongſt us, which muſt put fire to their zeale: And as their zeale riſeth, ſo ſuperſtition, hereſie and prophaneneſſe will fall: for the readieſt way to ſtrengthen and fortifie a Nation, to make it fit for warre indeed, to make it the head of the Kingdomes, is to take the cleane contrary way, the Adverſary tooke to enfeeble and weaken a Nation, to make it the baſeſt of Kingdomes. To kindle our zeale, and to make it yet more fervent for the Lords day, the due ſanctification thereof, both in publike and private, I will adde this; If our Reformers ſhall ſhew their zeale in removing thoſe prophaners of the LORDS DAY; and in burning thoſe bookes which have given a liberty that way, and have ſpread over the Land other 1 King. 8. 58, 60. damnable doctrines, Then will the LORD remove farre-off His Northerne Army, thoſe locuſts; which have devoured every greene thing, where they came: The Lord will drive them, and their Prince, with His tempeſt, into a Land barren and deſolate: And He will reſtore unto us the • ares, which that Army has eaten: We ſhall eate in plenty and praiſe the Name of the Lord, that has dealt wondrouſly with us, Amen. So I conclude. The only way to quench the fire entred-in at our gates, is to ſhew our zeale of ſpirit, fervent and ſeething hot, for our LORDS DAY: for as the Lords day, and His worſhip, on that day, is maintained, ſo will the Lord of the day maintaine the cauſe of His ſervants at all times, as the matter ſhall require, that all the people of the earth may know, that the LORD is GOD, and that there is none elſe. I deſcend now to the good Souldier, to ſee how devout he is in his obſervation of this day.

div.head: § IIII. The Lords day is a good mans delight.
div.p:
THis is the day, which the Lord has made, this man will rejoyce and be glad in it: The day wherein He records with rejoycing, and meditates on the glorious wayes of ſalvation, particularly the Reſurrection of the Lord Chriſt, and that plenteous Redemption by Him. He calls this day, honourable, a day of obſervations; and ſo he engageth his ſoule to keepe it; and on this day to ſtock his ſoule with his gathering, for all the dayes following, maintaining his communion with the Father and the Sonne through His Spirit, in the meanes and exerciſes proper to and becomming the day: And ſo keeps-up on the mount all that day (as humane frailty can give leave, man is ſuppoſed in a Chriſtian:) for he lookes to keepe a day in Heaven, which ſhall never have night, whereof the firſt ſeventh day was a figure or type: for that day is not deſcribed by evening and morning, as were the other ſix, which conſiſted of light and darkneſſe; but that ſeventh was all day or light, figuring-out the Saints perpetuall joyes in Heaven, where he, with Gen. 23. M •
A • ſ. the Saints of light, ſhall enjoy a perpetuall Sabbath, or reſt, even a long day, a perpetuall light, where is fulneſſe of joy for evermore.

div.head: CHAP. V. The administration of the Sacraments in right order, of high concernement to a Kingdome.

argument.p: That theſe ought to be adminiſtred by, and unto ſitting perſons.

div.p:
IT is a matter of high conſideration, how exact and accurate the zelots in all ages, good Kings and Princes, all have beene touching Temple or Church-matters: Kings gave their attendance and all diligence thereunto: It was their charge they thought, and their honour, we are ſure, to ſee unto it, that all the filthineſſe was carried out of the Temple, every thing provoking in Gods ſight removed: that the veſſels there, even thoſe be cleanſed; the Prieſts
and Levites, who did execute the charge of the Lord, that they be purified; the people ſanctified; all things muſt be done decently and in order for the great Feast was now preparing, they were to keepe the Paſſeover, unto the LORD GOD of Iſraell Reade 2 Chr. chap. 29. & 30. chap. 34, 35. 1 Joh. 2. 16.. It is enough to point at theſe things, and now to ſhew in a few words (in ſo cleare a caſe) how all this relates to us, and is written to provoke them to give all diligence, and to be zealous, whom the LORD has ſet as over-ſeers in ſuch high matters. Ile only ſet down briefly, how it has been; They, whom it does concerne, and are aſſembled together for that high end, will conſider how it ought to be.

Next to the LORDS Day, nothing has been more prophaned, than have the LORDS Sacraments, ſeales of the righteouſneſſe of Faith. The Sacrament of Baptiſme has been adminiſtred by ſons of Belial, who knew not the LORD: And to thoſe children, whoſe Parents, both father and mother, were openly prophane, made no acknowledgement thereof, neither cared, nor could, nor would give a reaſon of their faith, or hope that is in them: I will only adde this to be enquired into, whether a Parent; preſenting his child to the Sacrament, is not to give firſt an account of his faith, and reaſon of his hope, that is in him, and of his intereſt to the covenant? Certaine it is, that, if the Parent were ſo to doe, he would preſent himſelfe and his child before the Lord and His people in a more ſolemne manner, and with more conſideration. We all know how queſtions have been anſwered, and matters ſlubbered over, I FORSAKE THEM ALL; What doe you forſake? All, that is in the world, the luſts of the fleſh; the lusts of the eye; and the pride of life. The Good LORD pardon His ſervants, we have ſpoken, we know not how often, very unadviſedly with our lipps; When we ſaid we forſake them all; we forſook nothing at all; Even at that ſolemne time, and before the Congregation, there was nothing in ſight, but the luſts of the eye; and pride of life. We ſlubbered over, with our Parſons helpe, another queſtion as unadviſedly, as the former, and made anſwer thereunto; ALL THIS I STED FASTLY BELEEVE; All what? That, though the Miniſter can but ſprinckle water upon the child, he can neither cleanſe the water, nor can the water cleanſe the child, yet the LORD CHRIST has done both, and her •• in this Sacrament.
He gives us cleane waters, Bloud to juſtifie, Water to ſanctifie, All Himſelfe, and all in Himſelfe; and all this, we ſaid, We ſtedfaſtly beleeve. Oh Lord! we underſtood not what we ſaid, We cannot have Faith, and no knowledge. Lord! pardon the iniquitie of thy ſervants; We have provoked Thee exceedingly this way, in not conſidering what we ſaid; We have ſinned, It is in the purpoſe of our hearts to do ſo no more. This now I have ſet downe by way of enquiry only; The Lord inſtruct us to diſcretion touching theſe matters.

The other Sacrament has been (for what is done, I leave to the wiſe to judge) as much prophaned by brutiſh Prieſts, and by us, a brutiſh people, as much, I ſay, nay more than the former: To ſay all, I will ſay, in Mr. Calvins words; The Sacrament of the Lords Supper has been too commonly adminiſtred by ſuch vile Perſons, whom you would have di • dained to have ſet with the dogs of Job 30. 1.
〈◊〉 . • oeda per
•• ſtio, dum ſine delectu impudenter ſe i • gerunt ſ • eleſti & palam flagitio ſi homines, quos nemo honeſt us & verecundus ad communem convictum admitreret? ut ad • uc miramur unde rot bella. Calv. • n prim • ep • ſt. ad Cor. cap. 11. • er. 30. your flock: and given to thoſe whom you would not admit to a common table; He addes, and doe we wonder wherefore it is that we are devoured by the ſword, eat-up with famine, conſumed with the peſtilence; that the LORD has opened His Armory, drawne-out againſt us all the weapons of His indignation; doe we wonder at this? Why doe we wonder? the Cauſe is apparent, and in every mans eye; Let us never look to ſee an end of our miſeries, till our lives be amended: and this horrible prophanation of the Lords Table, ſo highly provoking in Gods eyes, be taken away. Bleſſed be God, there is we hope all poſſible care taken, touching theſe great matters, for the removing the ignorant and brutiſh Parſons, the ſetting in their places the honourable and the pretious, that all may be done about theſe Tremenda myſteria, knowingly, conſcientiouſly, decently, and in order. To preſſe this upon thoſe to whom this care doth ſpecially belong, Ile take leave to contribute this to this place. There is one clauſe alwayes ſaid at the Buriall of the dead, where at good men have ſcrupled very much, they have pronounced thoſe received to mercy, who have gone in a way moſt contrary to mercy all their life long. In handing-forth the Bread and Wine to the people, they utter words, which are more to be ſcrupled at, when they give forth thoſe conſecrated ſignes of the Bod •
and Bloud of Chriſt to thoſe that are brutiſhly ignorant, or op • nly prophane. Here Ile tell the Reader
a ſad Relation; though he may have heard of it before, yet, perhaps, not ſo well conſidered on, as now it may be, thus it is related; A man that had laid-up treaſure for himſelfe, but was not rich towards God
Luke 12. 21., fell ſick unto death; he perceived plainly his ſoule was now required of him, and an account of his ſtewardſhip; he ſends in poſt-haſte for his Paſtour as the manner is, demands of him whether he could give him any comfort; The Miniſter after ſome conſultation with him, anſwered, no, not any comfort for him, he had walked contrary thereunto ſerving the creature more than the Creator: No comfort for ſuch ſervants ſaid the Miniſter; ſay you ſo, ſayes the ſick man, (for now he was ſick-indeed) how have you deceived me! You have, from time to time ſpoken moſt comfortable words to me in the Church, and can you give me no comfort now on my ſick-bed? How oft have you ſaid thus unto me; The Body and Bloud of the Lord Jeſus Chriſt which was given for thee: then you bad me, Take and eat; Take and drinke, in Remembrance that Chriſt gave Himſelfe for me? And can you give me no comfort now? Oh! you ſhould have denyed me comfort then, when time was, and ſo I might have been in a way for comfort in this needfull time now that my dayes are cutting off, I muſt have time no more. Had you told me then when time was, that the Childrens bread belonged not to me, then I might have be thought my ſelfe of my miſerable condition, and have asked more grace. But you, giving me the Lord Chriſt, I thought all was well; Theſe words pierced the eares, and the very heart of the Miniſter, ſo it is reported; And well they might, and engaged his care for after time, to underſtand, as farre as man can doe, the ſtate of His people, whether they be worthy to whom he gives the Body and Bloud of the Lord Chriſt. It is enough to engage all Miniſters to the ſame care: and to haſtenup as neare as can be, to the pattern in the mount, to be patternes and examples before the people, going before them in an holy way, teaching their people publikely, and from houſe to houſe, testifying Acts 20. 20, 2 • . to them every one, Repentance toward GOD, and Faith toward the LORD JESƲS CHRIST. Amen.

div.head: § V. A good man preciſe in theſe high matters.
div.p: THe good ſouldier has much to ſay here, and much againſt himſelfe, but his ſcribe cannot ſet it down; he puts-up his ſupplication to his God, that he would not regard what he did, and how he walked in the dayes of his ignorance; nor be extreme to marke what His ſervant has done, and does now in the dayes of light: he does acknowledge that the ſin of unworthy Receiving is his ſin alſo, he cannot quit himſelfe of it: That ſin is gone into the common heape, and helps to make as the fire kindled in the kingdome, more ſcorching: ſo alſo, the herbes the ſow • er, but yet the Paſſeover the ſweeter: I meane, it helpes to encreaſe a godly ſorrow, and through the exceeding mercy of His Saviour, it makes his Joy the fuller. And now, for the preſent time, and hereafter before He § 11. 2 Cor. 5. 9. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 We ſtrive as the men of the world for the higheſt preferment and roomes in the world. preſents himſelfe at that table, he ſearcheth his heart, and prieth into it as narrowly as the Jewes into their houſes, which was ſaid before: and ſo he is a worthy Communicant in Gods acceptation: and the lower he fals now before the Lord in humilitie, the higher he riſeth in his Faith, and acceptation with the Lord, which is the earneſt labour and travell of his ſoule, even that he may be accepted of Him. Amen.

div.head: CHAP. VI. A Nationall Covenant mighty to eſtabliſh and fortiſie a Kingdome.

argument.p: There are objections againſt it, ſpecially two charges. 1. That it engageth to maintaine Religion by the ſword. 2. That it is as a body without an head. There is a ſcruple concerning our undertaking the Defence of the Kings Perſon reſolved: And objection • againſt the proſperity of the Covenant anſwered.

div.p:
WE have ſeen with our eyes, that the ſervants of the Lord working with God this Day have wrought as great a Salvation for the Kingdomes, as Jonathan for Iſrael: We have obſerved the way (it is but one and the ſame) they went-in, the very
ſteps and degrees of their happy proceedings. And now we are come to the higheſt ſtep, the entring Covenant with the high God, which containes much, nay, all the forementioned, for all that went before, has a direct tendencie hereunto, as to its end, next to the glory of GOD; The engaging the heart of a Kingdome as one man, unto one God; The intereſting, intitling Him to the kingdome, the giving-up the Government of it into Gods Hands, which is the way to make a Kingdome ſo ſtrong, ſo well fortified, that all the devils in hell, with thoſe in the Ayre, and all their ſworn ſervants on earth can have no power againſt this Kingdome now to doe it hurt; though they rage againſt it, and, to their power given unto them, doe ſtorme it, yet they cannot hurt it: for the kingdome is brought-up to God; the Government yeelded-up into His hands; He will looke to His owne. But I was ſaying, as this covenanting with God was the End, and tendency of all that went before, ſo this containes the meanes, and perfects them; I meane thus, The firſt ſtep towards this work was the caſting forth the accurſed Perſons and things; theſe will returne againe; the heart of the kingdome will deale with theſe, as Iſrael of old dealt Jer. 34. 11. with their ſervants when the ſiege was removed, they will take them-in again: But now the Kingdome has covenanted againſt theſe, they have ſworne to maintaine war againſt them, and their encroachings, they will never ſerve dumb idols any more, thus they have covenanted; No peace with themſelves any more, ſo far as ſelfe is its ſelfe; no peace with Rome any more, or her idols, no peace with any thing that makes roomth for ſuperſtition, hereſie, prophaneneſſe; no peace with any of theſe any more, as a Kingdome lookes to maintaine their ſtanding, and peace with God • vermore. And becauſe the Kingdome has found how prevailing faſting, and praying, and praiſing, and preaching is, to advance this worke, and to compleat the buſineſſe; They have covenanted with their GOD to maintaine all that, which has brought them-up to Him into that ſacred Band, viz. to be in faſtings often, to pray continually, to praiſe the Lord while they have any being, to holdout the Goſpel what they can unto the whole land. Wal • s ſhall be viſit • d; The places of the earth ſo full of cru • lty; lights ſhall be ſent downe thither; choiſe Miniſters ſhall be appointed for that great
• nd, who know the terrour of the Lord, and will perſwade
men to underſtand the will of their Father, and will declare it; doe conſider how Holy the Lords Day is, and will have it ſo obſerved; Doe feele the weight of the charge of ſouls, and by the grace of God will quit themſelves like men of God, in the diſcharge of their Dutie. So I have recalled the ſum of that which went before, and given a taſte of that which ſhould follow. I ſhould now demonſtrate and make cleare to the Reader, how mighty a Nationall Covenant is to eſtabliſh and ſecure Kingdomes; That indeed a Covenant is the One thing neceſſary for that great purpoſe: But I am Mr Caryl. Mr Coleman. Mr Caſe. happily prevented herein by the labours of excellent men: many very excellent Sermons, full ſpeeches, and Treatiſes not a few, are extant touching this great buſineſſe: I will ſay no more
•• r it, unleſſe by way of anſwer to that which is ſaid against it; many cavill againſt it, and ſome queſtion the lawfulneſſe of the Covenant; That I may ſet it free from theſe cavils, and put the Covenant out of all queſtion, I will diſſolve my ſpeech continued hitherto into a ſhort Dialogue.

A. There is a Covenant talked-off, and entred-into by ſome few, which ſeemes to engage three nations: But not the one nation have taken it, no not Scotland; and not above a third part of our owne Nation.
B. True, and I will give you a mighty reaſon for that anon.

A. You can never give me a Reaſon, why ye ſhould all enter into covenant as one man, To maintaine Religion by the ſword. Chriſtians muſt be ſufferers, as meeke as ſheep before the ſhearers, as their great Maſter was, from whom they have their names. Can you give me any one example of any in any ages of the world, that ſtood-up with their ſwords in their hands to maintaine their Religion?

B. Verily I could, though a man of ſmall reading, give you twentie examples ancient and moderne both; whole Kingdomes, particular cities, that theſe have all in all ages, as matters did require, ſtood up with their ſwords in their hands to maintain their Religion, Lawes, and Liberties; But I will confine my ſelfe to a beggarly The leſſe of man, the more of God; The weaker the men, the ſtronger their God. example (as the adverſary cals it:) Ile inſtance in thoſe beggarly poore peeled people (ſo their lords made them, and ſo they eſteemed them; ſo the Maſtives of the world touſed theſe ſheep of Gods paſture,) the Waldenſes inhabitants of Angrogne and Luſerne
in the County of Pied mont. Theſe poore people (ſo rich in faith) were perſecuted from place to place, as David by Saul, like Booke of Martyrs, p. 871. a Partridge on the mountaines by the Nimrods the Maſtives of thoſe Dayes. They parlied upon the buſineſſe with their Miniſters, Whether they ſhould take the ſword into their hands for their defence or not? It was reſolved at firſt, No: They might not, though their bloud was ſhed, yet they muſt in any caſe take heed of bloudſhed: ſo away the poore people ran, and their Miniſters with them, whether they could, like a chaſed-bird to that mountaine, and to that rock; and that did but enrage the enemies (the popiſh lords) the more. Then ſome other Miniſters in the places adjoyning tell the poore people, that their Miniſters were quite miſtaken, they aſſure them that all the lawes of God and man, the law of Nature and of Nations doe allow them their ſword, wherewith to fence their throats, and maintaine their lives; and, if to maintaine life, then much more to maintaine their Religion, which is more than life: ſo the poore people were reſolved. But they would, as before they had done, deale with their Lord of Trinity (it is not pertinent to give you the reaſon of the name) by petitions, and ſupplications, deſiring only that they might hold-faſt their God, and keep faſt to their Religion: for that is the way to keepe God with them: It would not be granted, no anſwer could they heare: but, To the fire with them They could gain nothing of their adverſaries hands by intreatie, but knocks.; to the fire: Then they fell to praying, and fasting, their beſt weapons.
A. We allow that, and Teares too, the Churches weapons, but no ſword.

B. You ſhould not interrupt me, I was ſaying, they prayed fervently, they ſpent, as a great commander did, Ante bellum in oratione jacuit, Sal. de Gub. li, 7. p. 251. a whole night in prayer, being to goe into the field next morning: ſo theſe prayed in prayer, were earneſt with the Lord God of Hoſts, and in His ſtrength they marched into the field the next day, ſo ſoon as it was light: for ſayes the ſtorie, The Lord would make His people know, that they ought to defend their life, that pretious thing, and their Religion (their crown) with the ſword: And how ſpiritfull they were; how well they quitted themſelves; how an old-man dealt with his potent Adverſary; how a young-man 18. yeares of age dealt with his mighty enemie: how foure chaſed fourty, and fourty put an hundred to flight, this is marvellous to conſider,
which I leave to the Reader. Only this Ile tell him, that the adverſaries and enemies ſaid openly, that the Waldenſes had bewitched and charmed their weapons: Indeed ſo they had done; but it was with prayers, and ſtrong cries to their God. O how omnipotent Prayer is! for the ſtrength of GOD is in it. But I muſt paſſe it over and proceed: When this poore people had worſted their adverſary, he would parley with them then; and they were willing to yeeld to any thing, ſo they might keep their God, and to His Faith. But notable it is, whenſoever they ſounded to a parley, then the Waldenſes were at a loſſe: for their adverſaries were treacherous, tooke advantage againſt them ſtill when they met to treat of peace: Whereby the LORD GOD would aſſure His ſervants ſtill, That they muſt not treat with idolaters: And ſo they left treating, and fell to fighting again, and proſpered in their battles to a wonder; for they brought downe God to their ſide: The ſword of the Lord and of Gideon; We know what that has done, and we are as confident for the after time.
A. You have told me a moderne hiſtory, not an hundred yeares old, ſure I am the Primitive Christians were ſufferers all, in all times.

B. Yes, you may be ſure of that, while Ethnick Rome (the Dragon) raged: and Anti-chriſtian Rome (the Beast) raigned, all this while the ſervants of God muſt be ſufferers: where-ever that ravenous beaſt ſet her foot, there muſt follow a treading downe, as in our dayes.
A. But my meaning is, The Chriſtians never reſiſted, they ſuffered and indured patiently.

B. True, they did endure patiently the wrath of GOD: but they did not expoſe their throats to the wrath of man; they were fighters too, as they had power in their hand, and law on their ſide: and they were as glorious in fighting for Chriſt, as in ſuffering for Him: and they did it by the ſame Faith, By Faith they put to ſlight the Armies of Aliens. The ſervants of the Lord Chriſt have been ſufferers Heb. 11. 34. a great while; they have ſuffered in Germany, ſuffered in France, in Ireland they have ſuffered, what ſhall I ſay? the ſpoiling of their goods and of their lives? yes and more, they have ſuffered heavie things, even what the rage of the enemies wrath could inflict upon his poore people, I cannot expreſſe what ſuff •
rers
they are in Ireland; nor what ſufferers they are in England. I ſay no more. But the ſcene ſhall turne ſhortly. The ſufferers all this while are fighters now, and ſhall be more than conquerours anon. The ſervants of the Lord ſhall be delivered, and their adverſaries ſhall come into their roome. Certainly though the enemie and adverſarie thinks he has prevailed over the Church of God; he has brought her low, even to the duſt of death, in ſome places to a dry-Bone, yet Spirit and life ſhall come-into theſe Bones againe, and the Lords warriours ſhall not ſit downe, till they ſhall execute the wrath of the Lord upon that bloody citie, rewarding her even as ſhe rewarded them: and doubling unto her double according to her workes: for this is the charge of the Lord; In the cup which Rev. 18. 6, 7. ſhe has filled fill to her double. They, who are engaged upon this ſervice muſt execute the vengeance, then theſe are fighters ſure: Therefore the ſervants of the Lord may fight, nay muſt fight, and will fight: It is their ſword which muſt eat the whores fleſh, and drinke her bloud: And this is not done by prayer, though Prayer has a great ſtroake in it; but by fighting with the ſword: Therefore I conclude yet again, The ſervants of the LORD may uſe the ſword: It is their charge from the Lord. But that you may be more fully and clearely reſolved at this point, That Chriſtians may uſe the ſword, Ile now aske you one queſtion, and you ſhall reſolve it your ſelfe.
B. Has the Lord Chriſt had any battles fought in the world: or are His battles fighting now?
A. Yes ſure, for there is large mention of the Lords battles in the ſacred records every-where: and of a levying war againſt the Lamb (that is) againſt the Lord Chriſt: I cannot doubt of this.
B. Who are thoſe that have fought the Battles of the LORD in all ages of the world?
A. I cannot tell their names, but ſure I am, they have been the faithfull ſervants of the Lord in all ages.
B. Very well, then the ſervants of the Lord may fight.
A. Yes, the Battles of the Lord.
B. You are ſure the ſervants of the Lord will fight no other battles, only war againſt them, who war againſt the Lamb.
B. One queſtion more, who do fight the Lords battles at this day?
A. The Lords ſervants ſure, The King and his Armies.

B. You conſidered not what you have ſaid, you muſt recall it againe: I ſhall aſſure you now, that your anſwer is not ſhort of blaſphemy; It reacheth even to that height, even to a ſinne, that ſhall not be forgiven to men: For your own ſake hearken; The LORD CHRIST had wrought an amazing worke for His poore Mat. 12. 23. creature, man, whom the Devill had poſſeſſed, made him blind and dumb, he could neither ſee, nor ſpeake, nor heare; The Lord Chriſt throwes-out the Devill, and ſo torments the tormentour. The people, beholding this amazing worke, ſaid, Is this the ſonne of ver. 23. David? (that is) Is this the worke of a meere man? Yes, ſaid the Phareſies, a meere man, and no more, has done this: And for that, he has done above the ſtrength of a man, he has done by Beelzebub the Prince of Devils. The Lord Chriſt heard all this, and ver. 24. knew their thoughts, ſayes the Text, (i. e.) he knew that their thoughts had more malice, more of Hell in them than their words ſhewed forth, yet their words were abominable, contrary to a cleare light; And put words and thoughts together, they reached to a blasphemy againſt the HOLY GHOST
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , &c. L • g Baſil. Reg. Brev. 273.: So ſaid the Lord Christ, and proves it: For, ſayes He, the Devill will not putforth his ſtrength againſt himſelfe, to ſpoile his own houſe, to breake-in pieces his own kingdome; Men may ſay ſo, that the Devill will doe ſo, fight againſt himſelfe, that ſo they may darken that, which will be more cleared than is the Sun-beame; but no man thinks ſo: and the LORD knowes the thoughts. You will conſider this, and then you will not dare to ſay, what, you are not ſuch a foole, to thinke, That the King and his Armies, (Atheiſts and Papiſts all) will pluck down their own houſe of gods; throw-out their own Idols, deſtroy their own kingdome; fight againſt their god, the Pope; you cannot think they will doe to: Then I pray you doe not ſay ſo; for you heare it proved from the LORDS own mouth, it is blaſphemy ſo to speake.

A. I ſpeake not my own words, therefore they muſt not be charged upon me. The King has proteſted, you and all men know what, and we all know how often: And the prime Biſhop Primate of the world undertakes, I heare, to ſatisfie every man touching that matter; he is the oracle in Oxford, no man departs from him, but he is fully reſolved in his heart touching the lawfulneſſe of the Kings way, and warre: and ſo they clap their hands
upon their breaſt ſaying, The voice of God and not of man, he has cleared the point of Reſiſtance, how fully! Let me adde one thing more, That the Biſhop is ſaid (but indeed I doe not beleeve heare-ſay) to caſt an odium upon your praying and faſting people in London, Miniſters and others, that they faſt to debate and ſtrife, and how they may take away their Kings Crown and life.

B. To quit you and ſet you cleare of this Biſhop firſt, though it ſhould be laſt. The Primate is a well known man, of more reading than ordinary, and of leſſe judgement than is conceiveable; It is certaine, God has not given him a diſcerning ſpirit; he is very credulous; It is verily conceived, that if a man will ſweare that ſnow is black, or your kitchin fire will not burne, or that evill is good, he will beleeve him; A very good natur'd man, if that be good. Nay ſome doe beleeve, That, if the Devill ſhould come to the Primate, proteſt and ſweare unto him, that he (and his angels) love Gods people, ſeekes their preſervation, he will be a wall about them and their houſes night and day; if the Devill ſhould vow and proteſt ſo much, the Biſhop would beleeve the Devill alſo, that he will not ſweare and lye. No credit to be given to what the Biſhop ſayes, but yet, I wiſh from my heart he had ſaid nothing: for what ever he ſayes, though, That Papists will fight for the Proteſtant Religion, there be fooles enough in the world will beleeve him: The Lord pardon what the man hath ſpoken, if he has ſpoken as it is reported: howſoever he has need of the largeſt indulgence from the Lord. But for your part, you will beleeve your own eares: for you heare and ſee both what is ſaid and done at London, upon our publike Faſt-dayes: doe our Miniſters there, doe the people A King muſt protect • is people, their King will doe it, f • r it is the office of a King. there, faſt to debate and ſtrife? doe the Miniſters there ſpeake good for their King, [ſo they doe acknowledge him at this day, though he has caſt-off the care and protection over His people] doe they ſpeake good for him before the Lord? Speake; doe they or doe they not?

A. They doe, God is witneſſe, their ſoules are witneſſe, our eares alſo, that the Miniſters of the Lord wraſtle with the Lord night and day for their King, that his heart may be brought-up to GOD, and his Perſon to the Parliament.

B. I will adde what cannot be contradicted, no not by the Devill
himſelfe; That the King (though he has not ſhewed himſelfe a King to his poore people) yet is he in their hearts, and a King of prayers in their mouthes: O! how doe the ſervants of the Lord deſire, how importunate are they that he may be a King of prayſes; And let the ſervants of the Lord pray without ceaſing; though Samuels mourning, was not heard for Saul, yet it was heard for 1 Sam. 15. 35. 16. 1. David, whom God gave to His people, a King after His own heart. Prayer is no vaine worke, it ſhall have a returne, if not what we would, yet what is better; And what hinders the returne of prayers, the Lord, that knowes the Kings thoughts, knowes, it is his ſinne, that lieth in the way, that ſin of—and ſo I come to his proteſtations; You ſay he has proteſted three times, That he and his Armies, will maintaine the true Proteſtant Religion: That he fights the battles of the Lord, ſo you ſay.
A. I told you indeed, that the King ſaid ſo, and you know, and all the Chriſtian world knowes, that ſo he has ſaid, and proteſted ſeven times.

1. That the Lord God has had His battles alwayes in the world, ever ſince there was a kingdome in the world ſet-up againſt His Kingdome, which is not of the world: He has had His warriours alſo to fight His battles: for theſe words relate one unto the other. I conclude.

2, That theſe battles of the Lamb againſt the Beaſt, and of the Beaſt againſt the Lamb, will now in theſe our times, riſe to the greateſt height of oppoſition: becauſe now the prophecy muſt be fulfilled, and the judgement upon the Beaſt muſt be executed; Reward double unto her: In the cup, which ſhe hath filled, fill to her double: I conclude.

3. That theſe are the ſervants of the Lord, who fight theſe battles now; and to ſay contrary, is to ſay that the Beaſt will wound her ſelfe, will powre down a violl of wrath upon her own head; that the bloody City will ſhed her own blood with her own hand; that the Devill will be devided againſt himſelfe, and oppoſe, yea deſtroy his own kingdome: To ſay ſo, for ſo we cannot think, is blasphemy againſt the Holy Ghoſt. In the laſt place, we muſt conclude;

4. That theſe warriours, who now fight the Lords battles, are not come forth into the field, as a great Commander, to ſhew the
abſoluteneſſe of his command, brought-forth a great Army, to pick Cockle ſhelts. No; They fight for their Lord Chriſt, to maintaine His Cauſe, His Crown, His Scepter, the Diadem of three Kingdomes, (the Goſpell) and the Crown of their rejoycing now, and in that Day of the Lord, the day of His appearing, when His warriours ſhall be made more than conquerours, receive their palmes into their hands, and their crowne (ſet) upon their heads: Therefore they are reſolved to ſtand to it, to quit themſelves like men, to be vahaut for their God, for His Chriſt, for His cauſe I heard a man ſay, who had loſt an eye in Br • inſord fight, That had he had a 1000 eyes and as many lives, he would be content to ſacrifice them all to this Cauſe., and City of God; and this is matter of high praiſe; that the Lord has continued them to theſe dayes; their lives, liberties, livelihoods, that they may expend all, livelihood, liberty, life and all, to teſtifi • the Goſpell of the grace of God. Bleſſed be the Lord, who has given ſuch gracious ſpirits, unto the ſons of men.
A. You have cleared your Covenant at that high point, The lawfulneſſe of bearing Armes for defence of Religion; But you ſweare alſo, to defend your Kings Perſon.

B. No, but we doe not. What man dares ſweare, that he will defend His Perſon, who ruſheth upon the Angels ſword every day, as blindfolded as Balaam did. As the King is a publike perſon, and walks in Gods high way, we ſweare to defend him: yea if we ſhould ſweare the contrary, which never any but Gods enemies have done, unto whom his loule too much cleaveth, yet the Lawes would defend the Kings perſon and Crown both: But while he walks as a private perſon, and as his will leades him, in his own way without GOD, and without the law, we cannot undertake for him: We will pray for him, and ſeeke to reſcue him out of his own hands, and the hands of them, who hate his ſoule: But we cannot ſweare, nor doe we ſweare, to preſerve his Perſon and Authority, unleſſe in the preſervation and defence of the true Religion, and liberties of the Kingdomes. The Lord God has made a covenant with His poore ſervants, that He will defend them, that He will. Lord! what is man that Thou ſhouldſt regard him? but that Thou ſhouldſt ſet Thine own guard about him, what a wonderfull mercy! Yet ſo the Lord does; He will ſet a guard of Angels about His ſervants bed, and about his path, and about all his ways: A wonderfull grace • And we reade, that theſe miniſtring spirits, are never more readily employed, than in their diſpatches and
workings for the ſalvation of man: I ſay againe, A wonderfull grace • But now the man muſt be gracious; he muſt looke to his way; he muſt keep in Gods way; If he ſtr • ggle-out, walking in by-paths of his own chooſing, he forfets this great priviledge, and charter of preſervation; he walks as one out-lawd, a man from whom the defence is gone: If the man walks in the way of Caine, he has no Letter patent for ſafety now, no more than Caine had; A man walking in his own way, a way of ſinne and death, goes-out from the preſence of the Lord, and from under His protection, The concluſion is; We, ſwearing to defend the Kings Perſon, doe undertake to doe our utmoſt that way in the Preſervation, &c. And this is as much as God. Himſelfe undertakes; which may ſuffice to cleare that ſcruple, if any ſuch there be.
A. But ſurely if your Covenant were of God, it would have a freer paſſe through the Land, whereas this meets with a mighty oppoſition.

B. The beſt ſigne, that it is of God: for the more of God is either in a Perſon or in a Thing, the more the Devill and his angels, will bend their force and fraud againſt it: I told you at the firſt, I would give you mighty reaſon, why there are ſo mighty obſtructions, why Hell gates have ſtood and doe ſtand wide open againſt the holy Covenant; The reaſon is; Becauſe it is holy, therefore the Abomination of deſolation, the Kings Army, ſpread-over the whole Land by the Kings command, has indignation againſt the holy Covenant; and therefore the heart of the King is againſt it alſo.

A. Now you are at the top and head of the buſineſſe, and there you muſt reſolve me, that I may reſolve others, who doe much queſtion the lawfulneſſe of your Covenant, becauſe it is as a body without a head a headleſſe Covenant.

B. It is an headleſſe objection; he has but little braine, as the ſaying is, a man of no underſtanding, who makes this objection. That Covenant wants not an head, which has the Lord Chriſt, the Head of His Church, chiefe in it, and all the concernements of His Church contained therein, which is aboundantly ſufficient, to render this Covenant moſt ſolemne and ſacred.
B. But you have not the Principall verbe, the King in your Covenant.
B. Yes that we have, and there is an undertaking there to preſerve his Perſon, and his Crown; and if that way does not take, neither his Perſon nor his Crown can be preſerved.

A. My meaning is; ye have made a Covenant without the King, which makes it queſtionable to me and many others, whether your Covenant be lawfull? Tell me; Was it ever knowne, That Princes and Worthies brought their King and people into Covenant? No never; The King evermore brought his people into Covenant with their God: and indeed there is no decency in it, if it be otherwiſe, nor is there order: It is a plaine guiding and leading that, which ſhould leade, the head I meane.

B. You have asked me a Queſtion, and you have anſwered it your ſelfe: you ſhall correct your queſtion, and ile correct your anſwer; Was it ever knowne that Princes and people brought their King into Covenant? No, ſay you. Yes, ſay I: Princes and people have brought their King-up into Covenant: But what if we had no example, nor preſident from former times: It will not therefore follow, that Princes and Nobles may not enter Covenant with their God; to take Him for their God; His Chriſt for their King; His Goſpell to be ſubject to it, without their King; If he be a child and cannot; ignorant, in ſuch an high matter, and cares not; conceited, and beleeves not; or wilfull, and will not be drawne to enter Covenant with his God. We ſay of a Parliament (the higheſt Houſe in the Kingdome) They cannot alwayes walke and worke by preſidents: but if their • athers have ot done that, which may be a preſident now unto them; then may they, as matters may require, doe that, which may be a preſident to their children. They, who make Covenant with their God, have a preſident for ſo doing, you may be ſure, more antient than the world is, but let that goe. The ſafeſt, the ſureſt, the only way to fortifie, and ſtrengthen a Kingdome, is, to bring a Kingdome-up, and into Covenant with their God, To ſerve, to ſerve (it is twice repeated) the LORD their GOD. If the only ſure
• Chr • . 34. 33. way to ſecure a Kingdome, then it muſt be done; The Princes, and Nobles, and Worthies muſt bring themſelves, their King too (if they can) the people alſo (if they will) up into Covenant with their God; They muſt do it; they ſtand bound to doe it, though they had no preſident for it: What if there be no preſident fo. it, yet the
Cauſe, th' extremity, never the like: Therefore the Worthies muſt doe it, as they love themſelves and the Kingdomes, and their children after them, they muſt doe it, and ſo be a preſident to their children. And bleſſed be God ſo they have done, and they have an example, a preſident for ſo doing; Jehojada a Prieſt, he poſtureth the Kingdome, orders the Militia, and which is the chiefe work, Jehojada made a Covenant between (Him) GOD and between all the people: and between the King, that they ſhould be the Lords people. There is a preſident.
A. True, Jeho • ada did it, but he was a chiefe man, the Government was upon his ſhoulders.
B. True, ſay I too, And will you not give the ſame power to all the Princes and Nobles, all the Worthies, all the Faithfull in all three Kingdomes, which you give to one Prince in Iſraell?

A. Yes, God forbid elſe; But I conceive there is a wide difference betwixt what Jehojada did, and what the Parliament have done; Jehojada might doe what he did, for it was his place, and he might governe the King being a child, in his non-age, but ſeven yeares old, The Parliament may not doe as they have done [I reaſon as a man according to my ignorance and little underſtanding in theſe matters] their K • ng is ſix times ſeven yeares old, of that age, which the Latine call a conſtant age.

B. I am preſſed to it: Curſed is he, that flattereth with his mouth, when he is to ſpeake for his King and Kingdome: In dread of that Curſe, I anſwer; That there is a greater engagement upon the Worthies now to doe as they have done (which is the ſame, which Jehojada did) than was upon Jehojada: he had to doe with a child-King in his non-age, yet he made the Bond ſtrong between God and the King: and the King and the people; a ſtrong bond, that he ſhould be King to rule for the Lord, the Lords King • and the people the Lords people. The Worthies now, have to doe with a Man-King, in his dotage. Dotage! It is more than ſo, he has given-up his power into his enemies hands; himſelfe and his Kingdome into the hands of them, that hate him, and his good people: The Worthies now muſt make the Bond ſtronger than ever, if ſtronger can be, for theſe have to doe with a King, who does walke moſt con • rary to what a King ſhould doe; A King is Gods Deputy, ruling for God; he puts-forth all his power againſt. Go •
A King muſt protect, guard, defend his poore people, (therefore made He thee King,) to maintaine the Defence, and to keep-out the wilde Beaſts; he takes-away the defence, breaks-up the hedges, lets-in grievous wolves to deſtroy his poore people. A King rules over men, he muſt be iuſt; This King breakes Gods people
• Sam. 23. 3. Pſal. • 2. to pieces, he is ſo unjuſt. A King muſt judge the poore of the peopl • and breake in pieces the oppreſſour; he condemnes the poore, and needy men, grinds their faces, and breakes in pieces the oppreſſed. A King muſt build-up the houſe of his Kingdome, and Gods houſe there; he pluckes all downe, and if he had power in his hand, he would raigne downe fire and brimſtone upon it: Mighty reaſon • all theſe, why the Worthies ſhould make their Bond-ſtrong, like a treble cord, which cannot be broken; Jehoiada brings-up all Judah into covenant with their God; A ſtrong bond: the bond is ſtronger now, Scotland and England, and Ireland are come up to their God, there is a three-fold cord. God be praiſed.
A. But Jehoiada did all he did to eſtabliſh the King in his throne.

B. Very true, and this is as true, that the Princes now in Parliament have taken the ſame way to eſtabliſh the Kings Throne, which can be done by no other meanes but this, By making a Covenant between Him (God) and between all the people: and between
• Chro. 2 • . 16. the King, that they ſhould be the Lords people; Wicked men, vile Prieſts, brutiſh Paſtours, fooles, to whom it is an abomination to depart from evill, theſe fooles will make cavils here, and exceptions againſt this; what? making a covenant between God &c.
A. The King would have no ſuch covenant made, nor will he enter into it.

B. We know that well enough, his heart is againſt it, yea he has indignation againſt it: but in ſo doing he ſets his heart alſo firme as the Leviathans heart againſt his own peace, and the peace of the Kingdome, for aske from one end of heaven to the other, and enquire concerning this matter, Whether there be any other way to ſave a King and Kingdome but this, To make a Covenant between God and between all the people: and between the King that they ſhould be the LORDS people: Therefore we conclude, if the King will have nothing to doe with the Covenant, if he will deſpiſe that Oath of GOD, then he ſhall have nothing to do with the Bl • ſſing, he rejects that alſo againſt his own ſoul. But yet he may live to ſee
his people proſper, as certainly they ſhall, being made the Lords, being entred into covenant with their God, and made the LORDS people: The King may live to ſee this, he may behold it with his eyes, even peace upon Iſrael, but he ſhall not partake of that Bleſſing, being out of Covenant with his God.
A. Why, but the King is not involved within the Covenant, therefore, though he does deſpiſe it, he cannot be involved in the curſe.

B. A bold ſpeech, and as bold an inference, the King not involved in the Covenant! The Princes have made a Covenant between GOD, and between all the people (and between the King too) That they ſhould be the LORDS people; And the King not involved, not concerned in it? The King is concerned, he is involved in it; All his deare pledges are there; All his concernments, All his good people, and all the bad, all the Malignants too, All this and all theſe are involved therein, in this Covenant, as much as Joaſh was, and all the people were concerned in that Covenant, which Jeho • ada had made. Joaſh was but a childe ſeven yeares old, and he underſtood like a child; And for the people, you cannot conceive that they could be all gathered together at Jeruſalem; There was a Congregation, which we now call a Parliament, the Captaines of hundreds, and the Chiefe of the Fathers; and when they had ſlain that vile perſon, that murdreſſe, then Jehoiada makes a Covenant which involved all the people, even to the utmoſt parts of Judah; There is no doubt but Athaliah that wicked woman had her favourites at court, and ſome in the citie, and countries too, as vile, as wicked and idolatrous almoſt as ſhe her ſelfe was, who ſecretly, if not openly, as that curſed woman did, called out Treaſon, Treaſon. But where-ever they were, though as far remote from Jeruſalem as Wales is from us, yet were they involved within that Covenant at that time: And ſo are they involved in this Covenant at this time, which the Princes in the two houſes of Parliament, (I meane by two houſes, Scotland and England, and God be praiſed they are made one alſo) have now entred into. I know, for all the Chriſtian world knowes, that there are ſome who murmur •
now, and ſome mocke, and ſome call out, Treaſon, Treaſon, calling others by their owne name; But yet, they are involved in this Covenant they and all their families, they and their wives, their children and
ſervants. I will give you one inſtance for all this, it will ſuffice to ſatisfie any reaſonable man; The Princes of Iſrael had made a league with the Gibeonites. The children of Iſrael journ • yed and Joſh. 9. 17. came to Gibeon, and they would ſmite it with the ſword. No, but they muſt not. No? Had the people made any league with Gibeon? Yes, that they had, for the Princes had made a league with them, and what the Princes have done, the people have done; and they muſt ſtand to it. Then all the Congregation murmured at the Verſ. •• . Princes. That was not well that the people would murmure againſt the Princes. But yet their murmuring would not ſerve their turnes, We have ſworne unto them by the LORD GOD of Iſrael, now therefore we may not touch them. We may not! That is true, and all Reaſon for that, for We Princes have made a league with Gibeon, ſo it may be objected. But the words are miſtaken; We includes Princes and people, we have made a league with the Gibeonites, and with us the people, now therefore we may not touch them. What the Princes have done, the people have done; We Princes have made a Covenant, We and You muſt ſtand to it; can it be imagined that the Princes can be bound, and the people looſe? now therefore not WE (that is, neither we nor you) may touch them: Princes make a Covenant as they make a Law, not for men aſleep but for men awakened; that all may take notice of it, none pleade ignorance, &c. Indeed I thought to have proceeded, But I underſtand very well that this one Scripture is ſufficient to ſtop Contradictions of ſinners will n • t ceaſe, till th • y ceaſe to be. the mouthes of all the Malignants in London, and brutiſh Paſtours in Wales, where they roare and ſtorme, and open their mouthes now againſt the Covenant, I will ſay no mo • e to that.
A. You are very brag now; you boaſt much of your Covenant.
B. You are miſtaken, We boaſt in the LORD all the day long: Who has inſtructed His people to diſcretion, and, by His Almighty Arme has brought them into covenant.
A. And what great matters have you done now, ſince you entred into covenant?

B. No great matters we, but the GREAT GOD that delights to uſe ſmall things has done great things by little meanes. Indeed I could be large here, I could goe from North to South, and tell what great things he has done, Indeed I could. The ſumme would be this, Little meanes and a great GOD has effected great things, wherein
we rejoyce; Ever ſince the LORD has brought His people into covenant, He has wrought for them, and with them, and in them, like a God; He has proſpered His people wonderfully; delivered them miraculouſly, marvellouſly ſeparated betwixt His people and the Egyptians, here and there the Lord has, &c. but I ſee the booke ſwels bigger then I would have it, I muſt forbeare.
A. What has the Lord done, the malignants, as you call them, obſerve no ſuch matter.

B. Doe they not? Whether they obſerve or not obſerve, no matter, Gods people muſt obſerve the works of God and the operations of His hands; ſo muſt all, whom the God of this world has not blinded, obſerve what the God of heaven has done for His friends, and againſt His enemies ever ſince the taking of Briſtoll, and entring Covenant with their GOD; They muſt obſerve how the proud men have fallen; how the Lord has puniſhed the hoſt of the Iſai. 24. 21. high ones, that were on high; How He has brought them downe, &c. But the wicked will not obſerve it, thoſe wilde Aſſes will traverſe their way ſtill, till their month come, then they ſhall be big Jer. 2. with ſorrowes, and then they ſhall be found: When paines are upon them, when the LORD ſhall teare them to pieces, as a lion teareth the caul of the heart, and goes away, leaving them in a torne Hoſ. 5. 10. and helpleſſe condition; when He ſhall put them into the fire of Ezek. 2 • . 20. His wrath, and leave them there (the utmoſt of judgements) then they ſhall obſerve.
A. Well: leave that unto your LORD GOD, and let us come to your Deare brethren the Scots, as you call them; Long looked for are come at laſt.

B. Yes, that they are, bleſſed be God, who has put ſuch a zeal into them, ſuch a love, as ſtrong as death, much water could not quench it. They came out in the coldeſt ſeaſon, in their zeal to GODS houſe are they come forth, for their vowes are upon them; And the Lord is with them, and with their families, whence they came-out: The Lord will not leave them, who are engaged upon His ſervice; the Lord will goe before them ſtill, and be a •• re-ward unto them; He will be to them a ſun and a ſhield; He will be all to th • m, who are All for Him, He will be all which their families ſhall need, or what their ſoules, and Gods Cauſe ſhall require, Amen.
A. But what have they done, the Scots, I meane.
B. I cannot tell; But ſure I am, the Hoſt of God, a people in Covenant with their God ſhall doe Dan. 11. 32.; it is not expreſſed what, but great things we are ſure.

A. Shall doe! Boaſt not of that, the Armour is but girding on yet, it is not put off: Tell me, for we heard you ſay, If the Scots were come, all were done; they would carry all before them; New-Castle and all: Is your expectation anſwered?

B. Yes, the expectation of the Righteous, for they expect no more from the creature than what the creature can doe; And that is nothing, unleſſe the Lord ſhall be pleaſed to worke with it, and then the creature ſhall doe great things: our expectation indeed, who have little or no faith in God, but all in the creature, our expectation is not ſatisfied: And it is well it is not. It may learne us alſo, weake creatures, as weake as water, ebbing and flowing, as the Newes is from the North, up-and downe; as the meanes are in ſight or as the Arme of fleſh is before us, ſo we riſe or fall; It may learn us after ſo many experiences of the commings-in of God unto us, to do dontrary to what we have done, to put little or no faith in the creature, all in God. Bleſſed be God, who does check our vain hopes for excellent purpoſes, to wind-up our hearts to Him; Indeed we doe, what in us lies, to break our own Arme to pieces, by laying ſtrength upon it, which it cannot bear, and not upon Him, who is Mightie: while we are ſo conceited of the Creature, that it can doe ſo much, God can doe nothing; But the Lord we hope has taught us now to look-up to Him, and there to reſt, in expectation of all from Him; And now that we can doe ſo, we can aſſure our ſelves, that the LORD will uſe His pretious ſervants in the North, and every where, and doe great things (exploits) by their hands, for which His ſervants will give Him the glory; they know the cauſe is His, the Kingdomes His, the People His by Covenant; the Lord will work like a God now, as alwayes He has done, for a people in covenant with Him. Amen.

A. I know not what God will doe in future times, what has He done at this Day? here you have made a long diſcourſe concerning this and that, a third meanes, and a fourth, all tending to ſtrengthen, and fortifie a Nation, and a Perſon, and to render them as a well of braſſe: See your ſelfe ſpeak! Are the Kingdomes ſtrengthened? The one Kingdome is not, the other, this Kingdome, is torne to Hoſ. 5. 10.
pieces: God tears it like a lion, and ſeemes to goe His way; And Scotland ſcarce able to defend its ſelfe.

1. I have indeed ſpoken, as I could, touching this and that, the third and the fourth meanes, mighty to poſture and fortifie Kingdomes, whether you reſpect the People or a Man only; Theſe are mighty means and ſufficient, God working with them, to bring to paſſe this glorious end: You cannot blame the meanes; how they are uſed, that is the queſtion, which I will not reſolve here. As was ſaid of Scanderberges ſword, It had done and would doe great matters, but then Scanderberges Arme muſt ſet it on: So theſe things I have treated on will doe great matters, but they muſt be well managed, and an Almighty Arme muſt accompany them; And this I will ſay more, that

2. This poſturing work, whether you reſpect a Nation or a man only, is a glorious work: See now, I pray you, what hinders and recards
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Niz. Ep. 100. this work! We expect Great and Glorious things, but not from the Great and Glorious God; we ſtand gazing upon the creatures-arme, and doe depart from God Almighty; If the creature be weak, we are weak; if meanes are ſmall, we are men of ſmall hope; yet the Lord does weaken meanes, and check them, that men may know they are but men, not God; their horſes fleſh and not ſpirit: He does make the meanes of ſmall and of no account in our eyes, that He might greaten and heighten himſelfe in all the peoples ſight; and yet (ah Lord!) how weak is our faith! we cannot get-up our dependance, to place it above, though there it never failed, was never diſappointed.
