3. You ſay, Ireland is not (that is) it is wholly deſolate Jer. 50. 13.; Grant that, yet God is juſt, for Ireland was
• holly oppreſſion Jer. 6. 6.: There are great deſolations, there were great abominations Lev. 26. amongſt His
own people there, it is Tabarah Numb. 11. 3.; The fire of the Lord burns there; Much ſcum is in the pot, very much droſſe there. But yet, I doe not grant, that it is wholly deſolate; there is a remnant there, and God is good unto them yet, even to the pure in heart; the LORD has indeed wounded Ireland with the wound of an enemie, with the • haſtiſement of a cruell Jer. 30. 14. one: and for the multitude of their iniquities has the LORD done this, becauſe their ſins were encreaſed: And yet the Lord ſayes in the very ſame caſe; All this, the Lord has done to Ireland; is but a correction and in meaſure; He will not make a full end of His People: but He will make a full end of His adverſaries (i. e.) He will deſtroy them utterly, they ſhall be wholly deſolate. The Lord is refining Ireland now, and, which is very comfortable, He ſits as a Refi • er Mal. 3. 3., that is, He ſits by His peoples fornace (of affliction) while they melt there, and will ſee to it, that their droſſe ſhall be conſumed only, and not His people, they ſhall be purified; ſo then, Ireland is, and though ſhe is but ſmall and low, yet the great GOD that raiſeth from the dead, can raiſe them again: It is a wilderneſſe: Eden before, a wilderneſſe now: Now I will up; ſayes the LORD. They are as dryed bones, can they live? We muſt not queſtion it, life and ſpirit ſhall come-in by the very ſame means, which the adverſary and enemy has uſed for the driving-of all life and ſpirit out; By the ceſſation of Armes there, and calling-over thoſe murtherers bither; By theſe very meanes ſhall that people live: for never was it knowne from the beginning of dayes to this day, That mans very ſhort Arme could out-reach the ALMIGHTIES ARME. And let me give you an account of my Faith touching this bleeding countrey of Ireland; I verily beleeve, that the Reſerve, the Remnant of the LORD there, ſhall help to fulfill the prophecie, they ſhall help to reward her enemies double according Rev. 18. 6. to their works. And the ground of my Faith is GODS Promiſe, They ſhall take them captives, whoſe Captives they were: Iſai. 14. 2, 3. 4, 5. and they ſhall rule over their oppreſſours. And it ſhall come to paſſe, &c. I pray you read it out, it is as comfortable for England brought to that condition now, that her people need comfort; now therefore they muſt read and confider ſuch promiſes, which will be ſweeter than Sugar kept under the tongue. To make anſwer now, as it relates to England.

1. It is a torne Land indeed; Is that a wonder? No, This is the
wonder, that there is any whole part in all the Land.

2. It is a torne Land, and the LORD has torne it; He teares, but Hoſe. 5. 14. He does not goe away; He ſtands by His torne pieces, they ſhall come together againe, for the LORD will gather-them, and unite them ſo, as they ſhall ſtand the firmer, and faſter together for ever. The Lords fire is in Zion, His fornace is in Jeruſalem: The Lord will not leave His people there, He will ſtand by them, while they melt, nothing but the ſcumme and droſſe ſhall goe-out; He is winnowing, cleanſing His Church now, not the leaſt graine ſhall Amos 9. • . be loſt.

4. All theſe tearers, and spoilers, and Robbers in the Kingdome, their ſtrength and their power in themſelves, and in their ſtrongholds, does but argue the difficulty of this poſturing worke; it does argue no more; And that is nothing, to diſhonour, or diſcourage the worke, but to honour the worke very much, and to enliven and quicken the workers. Hell-gates ſtand wide-open now againſt this worke; a cleare argument that the work is of God, and the godly will proceed in it with the more courage and reſolution; The Devill roates now, his ſervants rage, what will you conclude from thence? The Gaudeo ſic Satanam indignari & blaſphemari quoties a me tangitur, Luther, 2 Epiſt. ad. Am • . Devils are pinched now, his ſervants are Gaudeo ſic Satanam indignari & blaſphemari quoties a me tangitur, Luther, 2 Epiſt. ad. Am • . pricked at the heart Quod ſignum miſorie gloriae eſt omnes haeretici deteſtantur, Hier. Iſa. 41. 10., they gnaw their tongues now, becauſe they ſee the breaches in Jeruſalems walls are making-up, the worke muſt proſper; A wide dore is opened, (that is,) the paſſage for the Goſpell is widened more; you muſt expect as Paul ſaid, many Adverſaries, all the Devils in Hell, and in the ayre, and all his ſervants on earth. The difficulties in a worke cleare it to be of God; honours the worke, and the work-men: I ſhall contribute more to this anon. I would conclude now with a word of comfort from Gods mouth to His people in England, the City of God there, Feare not, feare not, [I know not how often it is repeated, for the ſecuring and eſtabliſhing of the Church.] O thou afflicted,
toſſed with tempeſts, and not comforted ſhall I ſay? No, The Lord has comforted thee in thy greateſt diſcomforts, in thy greateſt agony He has ſtrengthened and helped thee; thy puniſhment has been leſſe, indeed, than thy ſin; thy puniſhment is but a correction, indeed, and in meaſure: The Lord ſits as a Refiuer over thy fornace; lift up thy head now, thy redemption drawes neare, it is at hand, when the prey of the terrible ones ſhall be delivered, Iſa. 49. 25, 26. when thy mourners ſhall be comforted, when thou ſhalt ſee thy deſire upon thine enemies, when the LORD ſhall give thee an EXPECTED END; A gratious promiſe. What end is that? Jer. 19. 11. A GLORIOVS END; His ſervants, who keepe their watch, and to their worke, have heard and known what end their LORD makes, cannot expect any other end, than glorious, from a GOD, ſo full of mercy and of glory. Certainly, the Lord will make a full end with His Adverſaries now, His people ſhall ſee ſuch a deſtruction all over the Kings Army, as has not beene yet ſeene, nor ſhall be the like unto it, till Gog and Magog be ſlaine, the laſt enemies Eceeh. 35. the Church ſhall meet with upon earth; and no ſooner ſhe meets with them, but ſhe ſhall overcome them; preſently upon ſight of them, they ſhall ſee their carkaſſes fall on the ground, not by the ſword of a mighty man. The Church expects now the like confuſion ver. 3. 4. upon her adverſaries, now her Lords men of warre ſhall render their adverſaries double. It will be a glorious end to His people, who waight for Him; an end farre exceeding expectation, for the ſervants of the Lord will conſider the way their LORD has walked-in before them all this while; His goings-out againſt their adverſaries; His commings-in towards His friends, theſe have exceeded all expectation. Certainely the end will exceed much more; This is much to be conſidered on.

1. The LORD has ſuffered the adverſary and enemy to plow upon the backs of the righteous, and to make long furrowes. True, but His people ſee with open face all this has been greatly conducing to a glorious end, the making fruitfull the field of the Church. Our taskmaſters have beene many, their burdens and yoakes grievous. Theſe have been but outward, upon the body; the Lord has taken-off ſpirituall yoakes, burdens of conſcience, grievous to be borne, not a few: A mighty conſideration, to aſſure His people, they ſhall have an Expected end.

2. The Lord has indeed given His people the bread of adverſity, and the waters Iſa. 30. 20. of affliction: All this is grievous, yet not ſo grievous as this is comfortable, Thy teachers ſhall be removed into a corner no more: thine eyes ſhall ſee thy teachers. (Ile adde,) and thy murderers, vile Prophets and Prieſts caſt-out. An unſpeakeable mercy, Amen.

3. The Lord has emptied our purſes, taken from us (our ſuperfluities, things that may be ſpared very well, ſnares unto us) our ſilver and our gold, He has leſſened and cut-ſhorter our proviſions we had made for the fleſh: Well, and what if we never have ſuch proviſions any more, ſuch full tables, ſuch fine cloathes, &c. Surely the ſoule will be no looſer by that; and we ſhould count nothing a loſſe, whereby the ſoul is no looſer: and nothing a proſperity, whereby the ſoule does not proſper. But what proviſions has the LORD made for our ſoules? that is to be conſidered on, as matter of high praiſe. What if the LORD will bring famine upon the ſword, which, when we looke upon our ſins, we may expect? What if He bring us to a morſell of bread, to make us looke to our crumbs, which, in plenty we would not doe; nor regard His example, Who could have multiplied every crumb into a loafe, yet would have the fràgments gathered-up, that nothing be lost: What if they, who fare deliciouſly every day, be brought to The pooreſt mercies have the richeſt thanks. barley loaves, and two ſmall fiſhes; This was the LORD CHRISTS fare, and there is no mention of drinke, ſayes one, Baſil. Reg. tub. 18. likely that was water; yet for this poor fare, in our account, the LORD of the creatures gave thanks: Why ſhould the ſervant looke to fare better than his Maſter; its enough for him to fare as his Maſter, though his fare be courſe. So now, if the LORD ſhould cut ſhort our proviſions, yet if we can remember, and be humbled, that in the dayes of plenty, we forgat the giver of all bleſſings, then we may ſee cauſe enough, to be thankfull for our barley bread; and matter of aboundant praiſe, that we are like to have plenty of the word of God; Want of bread makes a famine, as the ſaying is: But the ſcarceneſſe of the word of GOD is the famine indeed. Browne bread and the Gospell is dainty fare, ſaid he, who could prize that uneſtimable gift. Gods people have the Goſpell, and like to have it in aboundance, and they have enough.

4. And ſo to conclude, the wayes of God have beene mercy and
truth towards thoſe that feare Him; His ſervants may ſay, nay they doe ſay, Whatever their Lord has taken from them of the earth, (of that, which is earthly) He has recompenced with Heaven, with that which is heavenly. A good exchange. Verily they can ſay, not a ſtroake the Lord has given, but it has been healing; not a wound He has made, but in mercy, and in meaſure: and if it has ſeemed deepe, and wide open, it has been to ſearch it to the bottome, and to expedite a perfect cure. Truly, the conſideration is admirable; If the frownes from the Lord be comfortable, what will His ſmiles be? If the ſtroakes from His hand be healing, what will the kiſſes from His mouth be! If His wounds be but a correction, and that in meaſure, what will the binding-up the breach be, and the healing of his ſtroake? how overſlowing will be the cup of His conſolation! If the way He has gone-in here before His people, be ſo full of grace; If the meanes He has uſed for the reſtauration of His Church, be ſo full of glory, what will the end be? An expected end ſure (that is) a glorious end, which the glorious God will make. No more is to be done now, by His poore ſervants, but doe their duty, and their worke, heartily, earneſtly, ſervently; waite for GOD patiently, depend on Him faithfully, ſix upon Him stedfaſtly, keepe cloſe to Him, and to the Covenant reſolvedly: Remember the LORD, Who is great and terrible; Neh 4. 14. and fight for your bretheren, your ſonnes and your daughters, your wives, and your houſes, We have entred into Covenant to doe ſo, to ſtand-up for God, and to ſtand to our Covenant, that is all we have to doe. I leave the Nation now, and come to the Man.

div.head: § VI. Entring into Covenant with God, a mighty meanes to posture a mans ſelfe;

argument.p: And to render him mighty, able to prevaile with God, and over men: he walketh as a man in Covenant with his God, both •• ome and abroad, above himſelfe and the world; he is of much uſe to his private wealth, but of more uſe to the publike.

div.p:
HE takes the ſame way ſtill to poſture himſelfe, which the Worthies have taken in poſturing the Kingdomes, he enters into Covenant too; But as hardly brought-up to it as the Kingdome
was, with much adoe, yet at length it is done; he had faſted, he had prayed, he had praiſed too, and the good word of GOOD was as a ſword in his hand to ſlay thoſe enemies, which would not have his Lord rule him: but till he had prayed and praiſed, I may adde and preached himſelf into Covenant with his God, his enemies, ſelf, ſelf-will, ſelf-reaſon, ſelf-ſeeking, ſelf-pleaſing, that accurſed perſon, and things returned upon him ſtill, would force a reentry: Thus I ſay it was untill he came-up to God fully and indeed, to enter Covenant with Him, & to keep unto Him, fully reſolved with full purpoſe of heart to amend his ways, and cleave unto God: til he was reſolved Acts 11. 23. as Joſhua was, who made his own heart the center of Reformation, till he had ſo done, he had done nothing to purpoſe. I cannot ſet down here how often this man aſſayed at this Covenanting-work, nor the warpings of his ſpirit; as I cannot ſet down his failings and fallings down, and up againe: So, nor can I ſet-down the mournings of his ſpirit, for all this, and more than I can name; We ſhall heare of this anon; This is to benoted hence; that this Covenanting work is not a work of a day or two, nor an eaſie work. We ſuppoſe now the work is done, he is in Covenant with his God, and reſolved with full purpoſe of heart to ſtand to it; he has laid his ſoule under ſacred bands: and becauſe his heart would ſtartle-aſide and draw-back, like an unruly heifer, he binds himſelf, as were the ſacrifices, to the horns of the Altar, with ſacred coards, faſter and faſter, with ſtrong purpoſes and reſolutions to hold faſt to his rule and cloſe to his God.
A. But is all peace with this man now; finds he no moleſtation or trouble from his adverlaries, the Devill, world or fleſh.

B. Never more than now; As it fares with the Kingdome now, now it is entred Covenant with God, now the Devill roares, and his angels rage, they proclaime war with it now, and vow to ſtorme it every houre: So the Devill, world and fleſh deale with this man now in Covenant with God, now Hell-gates are ſet wide open upon him: but through God, he ſhall be delivered from them all; his enemies would storme him and ſome ground they get upon him ſometimes, and downe he is, and when he getsup he is toſſed like a locust, rather like a Ship in a tempeſt; but this is his confidence, his Head is above, his Lord Chriſt is riſen, therefore though he be ſtricken into the place of dragons, yet, when he is himſelfe, and can conſider wiſely of Gods doings, he aſſureth himſelfe,
he ſhall riſe the higher, the lower he is fallen; and ſo we will behold the ſafety, the ſecurity, the peace of this man; peace, peace, perfect peace, In warre peace, in neceſſities and perſecutions, peace; in ſickneſſe peace, in death peace, peace; But of this anon: he is as a die, a cube, a ſquare body, throw him whether you will, into the place of dragons, if you can, you cannot-overthrow him, he ſtands ſtill, firme in his faith, and ſtrong in his God; This is he, that is as the chariots of Iſraell, and horſemen thereof; the chiefe Ammunition, the better part of a Kingdomes Artillery. This is he, that has chaſed a thouſand, nay he has put ten thouſand to flight, legions of Devils, all the Princes of darkneſſe, Principalities and powers, the Prince that ruleth in the ayre, and mightily in the children of diſobedience: All the fiery darts, from thoſe adverſaries, he has quenched; all that power, he has overpowred, in His ſtrength, through Whom, he can doe all things; And now for the world, he is at a point; the pleaſures and profits there, doe not take him, nor inſnare him; the changes of ſorrowes there, doe not greatly move him, not ſo as to put him off from his bottome; He is rooted and ſtabliſhed in Chriſt, nothing now can doe him hurt, nothing falls out unto him as a plague; the hurt from the ſword, the evill of the ſickneſſe, is taken away from him, he feeles it not; And for the furious rage of his adverſaries, he laughs at it, as he may doe, who maintaines his peace with God: They would ſtorme him every day, but they cannot; he has chambers to enter-into where he is ſafe till the indignation be over; The adverſary would cut off all ſuccours from him from all quarter̄s; he mocks at them, and rejoyceth in the Lord, the God of his ſalvation; he has done his duty, which is his worke, and is reſolved ſtill ſo to doe; for the reſt he is not carefull, he commits all to God, ſoule and all, in well-doing; and now can ſtand ſtill, waiting the ſalvation of God, with whom he is in covenant, to whom he has lifted-up the hand, and ſubſcribed his name: And for whom, the Lord now has lifted-up His hand, that He will make-out unto this man, all Himſelfe, (and all is in God) His Power for him, His Wiſedome for him, all for him; Gods Attributes all ſhall be laid-out for him, who will lay-out himſelfe, all he has, and all he is; his eſtate, and his life, for God: All in God, and all is God, ſhall be laid out for this man, that will expend himſelfe and be ſpent for God: the Angels alſo, theſe ſhall
be his guard; all the creatures for his uſe and ſervice; and for his head, an helmet of ſalvation now, and a crown of glory at the laſt; But this is reſerved till the laſt.

It may be ſaid, theſe are but words, talke only and no more; We muſt ſee this man ſpeake; he has lifted up his hand to the HIGH GOD we muſt ſee how he acteth with his hand; He hath ſpoken with his mouth, let us ſee how he fulfils with his hand; The meaning is, we muſt ſee how he lives: how lives he? Exactly according to Gods rule; the word of God, that is his rule, and he driveson mainly in all he does to the glory of God, that His God may be glorified, that is his end; he is not a talkative man, he is practicall; he is not for words but for power 1 Cor. 4. 19, 20. he ponders his ſtepps, then he walkes-on boldly, confidently, prov. 10. 9. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 It ſignifieth both the confidence or boldneſſe, which men have, truſting in God and walking in his wayes: and the ſafe and ſecure eſtate, wherein God ſetteth them from danger of evill. Mr. Ley. for he walkes uprightly, and does all things decently and in order: he ſpies narrowly into a Church way, for that is an holy way, and waites wiſely their determination, whom, he himſelfe amongſt others, have choſen, and appointed to conſult about that way: In the meane time he prayes, heartily, and does his worke earneſtly, and ſpieth narrowly into the way of his own ſpirit, how ſutable His ſpirit is to a Church-way, that holy way, and how becomming a Chriſtian: and ſo his maine worke is, while others are about the publike, with and about his own heart, that, it may be kept as the Temple of God, the Holy of Holies there; And about his own houſe, the ordering and ſetling of that in a Church way, that his houſe may be the Church there, which was the praiſe of them, whoſe praiſe is in the Goſpell. And now he is in a Church way indeed; and if none will goe along with him, he will goe alone, for he knowes he is in the right touching the ordering his own heart, and his own houſe in a Church way ſure, for he centers all, he has lifted-up his There is the neglect, the Lord diſcover it to Cities and Countries all the Land over. hand unto, in his own heart, which he makes the center of Reformation, and ſo goes on orderly, he with his houſhold, and then to the houſe of GOD, where, doubtleſſe, he can order things if he be called to it, even in a Church way as in his own houſe, decently and in order: but we looke upon him in his own houſe, where he is a chiefe Parliament man, the chiefe Ruler and Speaker therein; His care is to walke in a Church way there, he walks after inward gratious principles, he ſtrives not after outward priviledges: and ſo his example reproves many in theſe dayes, who neglect their owne
houſes altogether, and yet contend for a Church way; A notorious failing, and the leſſe excuſable, becauſe they are ſo forward for a Church way, and goe croſſe to it in their own houſes. This man not ſo he is preciſe and exact in his walking amidſt his houſe, as becommeth a man whoſe vowes are upon him; he fals to his work, and to his proper work, he hath an offic •
and he waits upon it: hee knowes his ſtation, and keeps to it; his Relation, and he anſwers it (a man is not good who is not good in his Relation) he walkes in 3 Joh 4. Truth, and he doth faithfully whatever he doth to them within, or thoſe without, to brethren or to ſtrangers; If he ruleth, he doth it ver. 5. with diligence, and with tenderneſſe, reſpecting not his but their good, whom he is ſet over, not yours but you, his ſtanding Rule. Rom. 12. 8. Whatever his relation is, he ſtands bowing himſelfe to it, and to anſwer it fully; if a Father, a faithfull father; if a maſter, a faithfull maſter; if a ſervant, as ſure enough he is, how high ſoever he is in the world, a faithfull ſervant; he giveth all diligence, he uſeth all faithfulneſſe; The ſumme is, he ſeeks not his own (as all doe, and ſo all goes to ruine) but the things, which are JESƲS CHRISTS Phil. 2. 22. he ſtands like a ſtock holding the ballance, which way the publike. weigheth he goes; his thoughts cannot ſtoope any other way; he is in his houſe as the ſhip Admirall to the other ſhips, he carries the lanthorno, he ſhines before his children, and ſervants, converſing gratiouſly with, and before them, holding out a light unto them by his converſation amidſt of them.

But what ſervice does he for the publike? A great deale; no one man in the world more than he, becauſe he is ſo much at home, and where ever he is, communing ſtill with his own heart; he is a great enemie to GODS enemies, the rebels now in the Land: But a greater enemie, if greater may be, to the Rebellion in his own heart, or that he meets with from thoſe God has made him Ruler over, and chiefe Over-ſeer; The Rebellion there vexeth him moſt, for that, he knowes, grieveth the Spirit of his God moſt of all. Therfore his chiefe care is now to ſearch his owne tent, his heart, his houſe; knowing very well, that if there he any ſtop in the Churches victories, the cauſe is, ſome accurſed things not diſcovered in the Churches Tents. And this he would have wiſely conſidered-on by the Commanders in chiefe and Leaders after them, and by every common ſouldier that followes them. That their chiefe enmitie
might be exerciſed againſt that enmity which is in their own hearts and tents, againſt God and His pure Worſhip: That they would contend moſt eagerly againſt the Rebellions there, for this will give the cleareſt teſtimony, whether their hatred of Rebels, and this (higheſt) Rebellion now in the land, be a right hatred; and whether the deſire of having the land purged of them be a right deſire. If a Mans ſpirit be not moſt lifted-up with indignation againſt the Rebellions in his own heart, whether thoughts or idols there; his boaſtings are vaine, and his attempts likely to be as vaine, touching the caſting-forth the Rebels out of the land. This is the way this good Souldier takes, his complaints are moſt againſt the rebellions within doores; and as his chiefe hatred is againſt them, ſo alſo his chiefe hatred, and firſt-borne of his ſtrength is againſt this or that, which is an offence to his GOD, and to caſt that out, and ſo he becomes a very publike perſon, a good part of the Kingdomes Militia, as the Chariots of Iſrael and the horſemen thereof, as was ſaid. Indeed he is all for the Publike, and no body for himſelfe; but yet, that it may fare well with the Publike, he deales and communes moſt with himſelfe, and his own heart, the rebellions there troubles him moſt; and if there be a diſcomfiture given to the Armies of the Lamb, or a check to the proceedings in the Church-affaires, and her concernments, he thinkes verily the rebellions within cauſed all this, Iſraels tents were not well ſearched, the accurſed thing is not found out, therefore this man prieth and ſpyeth moſt at home; and is not ſo deſirous to have the plagues removed (the ſword, famine, pestilence, Ezek. 14. 21. noyſome beaſts) as thoſe ſins removed, which fourbiſhed the ſword of God and Man, let looſe thoſe beaſts, gave them a commiſſion, and bade them ſlay and not ſpare, [Sa • bath-breaking, ſtrange vanities before the eyes, idols in the heart, daughters of a ſtrange god, the bloud of the innocent ſhed; and not required, bearing with thoſe that are evill, which a good Church cannot doe Rev. 2. • .;] theſe he would have removed. A wofull mercy to have a judgement removed from a land, and the ſin that brought it in to continue upon it. It is not a remove, it is but an exchange of a lighter judgement for an heavier; as it was with Sodome, the Sword was removed, Abraham delivered them from that, but fire from Heaven conſumed them after-wards, becauſe (that ſin) continued and encreaſed in them to a greater ſlame, ſo as they were conſumed in a proportionable puniſhment,
fire from Heaven conſumed them, and their citie, who were conſumed in the fire of their own luſts: If ſin, which cauſeth the judgement be not removed, there can be no remove of a Judgement, but an exchange only, and for the worſe ever, and more grievous to the body; or which is worſt of all, the judgement may be taken off from the body, and layed upon the heart and ſoule, and that is a judgement indeed, the neareſt on earth to the ſuburbs of hell; blindneſſe of mind, hardneſſe of heart: ſo as men commit ſin with greedineſſe, and are paſt feeling, can pretend a care of grieved conſciences, when their own are ſeared with an hot iron, and as hard as the nether Milſtone. I conclude, This man prayeth, Remove the judgement, good LORD, from off the Nation: but in mercy, remove our ſins firſt, elſe a worſe thing followes, which GOD forbid. We have ſeene what this man is at home in his Cloſet, and amidſt his houſhold; what abroad in the world; what in his private houſe; what in the houſe of God; what he is for his private wealth, what for the Common; he is good at all times, in all places; doe's good to all, what he can doe, hurt to none, though in the power of his hand ſo to doe: he proſpers in all things, for his ſoul proſpen, and ſo he would have all to proſper. Amen.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Miſtakes about a Parliament,

argument.p: That one is not a miſtake, but a blaſ • hemy; what our miſtakes or off n • es are, and how corrected; what a Pa • liaments Deſence is, what their worke, and what the miſtakes touching that worke.

div.p:
THe Parliament cannot riſe higher, nor doe more for themſelves and the Kingdomes than they have done, for they are come-up to GOD, they have made themſelves the LORDS Parliament; and the people the LORDS people by covenant. They have no more to doe but conſider well, what they have done; and to ſtand to it. We have read before how the holy Covenant is gainſaied, oppoſed, blaſphemed; now I come to the Covenanters; The chiefe and Leaders-on to this ſacred worke are the Parliament, and ſee what a miſtake there is about them, they are counted no Parliament
or but a pretended one, and that is as good as none. The Adverſaries and enemies are willingly and wilfully miſtaken ſure, (1). they take themſelves, an Aſſembly of Robbers in Oxford, for a Parliament: And the convention of Princes, Nobles and Worthies in Westminster, for a pretended Parliament: ſo they ſeeme to take it. A miſtake ſhall I call this? well, let it goe; But if it be a miſtake, it is as wilfull a miſtake as ever was heard of in the world, and as full of malice. For my part whatever I call it, a miſtake, or the like, I muſt thinke it to be, and it ſhall be proved to be, a blaſphemy, and that in an high degree, a blaſphemy againſt the Holy Ghost, for this is the caſe, and thus it is opened and cleared. The Parliament have put-to all their ſhoulders to exalt the Lord Chriſt upon His Throne in heaven (the Church:) and to ſet their King upon his His Throne on earth: never any Parliament have done like them, for they have endevoured their utmoſt to take away the wicked from before the King, Prov. 25. 5. to hold and to keep him in the Throne of God, that he might be a King for God, rule for Him, doe Juſtice and Judgement to all His people; and ſo to ſettle a Right Scepter in His hand, and Pſal. 45. 6. a Crowne upon his head, that it might ſtand faſt there, till the appointed time, and then but exchange it neither, a crowne of earth for a crowne of glory; And in ſo doing they have ſaid to their King Indeed and in Truth, O King live for ever; the eternall GOD bee thy Refuge, and underneath the everlasting Armes; Thruſt out the enemies from before thee, and deſtroy them: Thus have the Parliament wrought, and endeavoured for their King; God, Angels and men are witneſſes of this, the Parliament call all theſe to record with them touching this matter.

They in Oxford (an Anti-parliament indeed) have done all contrary, croſſe and againſt their KING in heaven, and their king on earth; Dethrone their LORD CHRIST they cannot; but they have dethroned their King on earth, they have caſt-him out of the Throne of God; They have driven him out from abiding in the in-heritance of the Lord; They have ſet him up a Throne at Oxford, put a reed into his hand, I ſay, a reed, (a Scepter of unrighteouſneſſe, which will pierce his hand and his heart:) and in truth, a crowne of thornes upon his head, which ſo vex and trouble him night and day, that he can have no quiet. It muſt be ſo, Every thing has reſt in its proper place, out of that place, and no reſt; The King
is out of his place, and now the Adverſarie drives him-on in the path of the deſtroyer up to the horſes bridle in bloud, ſo furiouſly, that the Adverſaries ſuffer him not to ſtand ſtill and conſider, that the Angels ſword is before him, for if they would ſuffer him to conſider, he would ſay as Balaam did, If it displeaſe Thee, LORD, I will get me back again. Numb. 22. 34. Diſpleaſe the Lord! The Lord is infinitely diſpleaſed with him, He is angry with him every day. And ſee now the Kings condition, how miſerable it is! He, that had GOD, and His Law for him, while he ſate in Gods Throne, has now all againſt him, GOD and all; his Anti-parliament has expoſed their king naked, and ſhelterleſſe to all the ſpouts of Gods indignation, and vials of His wrath: His perſon is indeed fallen into the hands of Theeves, and Robbers, they have taken him, from his God, and his God from him; They have taken from him his peoples hearts too, The Lord give him to ſee what his adverſaries have done againſt him, and diſcover this their iniquity to his ſoule.

2. The Parliament have done thoſe workes for God, for His Church, for the promoting of Gods Kingdome, which were not poſſible to be done by meer men, or men alone, not working with God all this time and God with them. The Anti-Parliament have done all they could doe, to promote Popery, to bring the land under an Anti-Chriſtian yoke and an Egyptian Tyranny, according to the effectuall working of Satan in them, and with them all this while. From theſe premiſes it is concluded frō the ſacred Scripture, that to Matt. 12. 24. Joh. 15. 24. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . ſil. Regul. hrevs. 273. Works live cleare Teſtimonie Joh. 10. 25, 37. Iſai. 30. 12. Pſal. 62. 3. call this no Parliament, or that in Oxford a Parl. is a blaſphemie againſt the holy Ghoſt. The Reaſon is, Becauſe it is To deny the fruits of the Spirit in men, the operations of Gods Hand with and toward His ſervants: and to attribute theſe to the Devill and His Angels. The ſervants of the Lord will leave this—to the Lord, let Him alone to puniſh this, They have committed themſelves, and their Righteous Cauſe unto the Righteous Lord; the Judge of all the world will doe right: The Adverſary ſhall proceed but a little farther, for their folly is maniſ • ſt unto all men. Doubt it not, Reader, thou ſhalt ſee with thy eyes this Anti-Parliament confounded in their own wayes, for they trvſt in oppr • ſſion and perverſneſſe, and ſtay thereon; Its ſtands now as a bowing wall and tottering ſence; its breach ſhall come ſuddenly at an inſtance, for the Lord ſhall break it as the breaking of the Potters veſſell, ſo he will breake it to Iſai. 30. 13.
pieces, and will not ſpare: The Lord is gratious; He has paſſedover mistakes, ſuch as we ſhall read of preſently, and corrected them; But this blaſphemy, &c. For now the Lords beſt ſervants and moſt loyall ſubjects are called Rebels, and Traitours: And they that are ſo indeed, Robbers and Murtherers, Mighty hunters before the Lord, theſe are called Marqueſſes, Earles, Lords, Knights, and Doctours of Divinity; The more vile and treacherous they are, the more honourable and dignified they are: The Lord has heard this blaſphemy, Hee looks upon it, He will require it. I will cloſe this with two conſectaries. The firſt is,

1. That the Covenant is of God, for Hell is moved at it, all the Iriſh Rebels, and Engliſh Monſters are grieved and have indignation against it: Therefore Holy, and of God, elſe their hearts could not abominate it.

2. For the Covenanters, they ſhall lift up their faces without ſpot, they ſhall be ſtedfaſt and ſhall not feare: The LORD ſhall cleare their innocency: their upright dealing ſhall ſhine forth as the morning. But the eyes of the wicked ſhall faile, and they ſhall not Job 11. 10. eſcape; and their hope ſhall be as the giving-up of the Ghoſt. Amen.

Sober men have been miſtaken and offended here alſo, almoſt as much about the Parliament, as the Barbarians were about Paul, (II.) now he was a murtherer, preſently after he was a god: It is an Acts 28. hard matter to keep a meane betwixt too much and too little; good men fall ſometimes upon the extreme; But it is upon ſome ſudden ſuggeſtion, they are quickly from-off-it again: we will ſee now what the miſtakes have been; what has cauſed them, and how corrected.

1. It has been ſome offence of heart unto ſome (for a little time) to ſee a rebellious, ſtiffe-necked people fighting themſelves into ſlavery, ſervants that will not be made free; then alſo (for I muſt huddle) to ſee a viperous generation of men ſticking faſt upon the hand of the Parliament: An offence indeed, to ſee the Worthies of the Lord waste out themſelves, their time, and their ſpirits (if I might call it a waste) to make us free-man, free in the Lord: and, us again ſo requiting the Lord and them: and to hang upon their hands ſome of us, as vipers upon Pauls hand. Setled and ſerious thoughts have corrected and removed this offence, conſidering

• . That this was the meaſure, which was meated forth unto the
Lord Chriſt Himſelfe; He came amongſt His owne, they received Him not; He wrought wonders amongſt them, they regarded them not; He would have made them free-men, they would not, they were free already, nor did they ſo much as thank Him; how high their wrath reached we all know: And that they quitted Barrabas and condemned Jeſus; there is nothing now that is new, I can give but an hint only, and more needs not. 2. Conſidering that it is the beſt ſigne of a good cauſe to ſee evill men, Papiſts and Atheiſts, all the Chriſtian world over, contending againſt it: And of a good Parliament to ſee a viperous generation, an Anti-Parliament, ſticking upon their hands, ſtinging of them, fighting with them, ſetting themſelves in a Diametricall oppoſition unto them. More conſiderations there are, but theſe may take off that miſtake.

2. It was an offence of heart at firſt, to ſee ſo many on the Kings ſide; to follow-on in a direct path to ruine; This offence was taken away by conſidering: 1. That when Leaders and Captaines drive-on furiouſly in the path of the Deſtroyer, others will drive after 2 Sam. 31. 5. as furiouſly as they; We know who fell upon his own ſword, which his Armour-bearer ſeeing, he fell likewiſe upon his ſword 2 Chron. 12. 1. and died with him; And that Rehoboam forſaking the Lord, all Iſrael forſooke the Lord with him. 2. It was remembred alſo, That not many nobles, not many wiſe ſtand on Gods-ſide, and up for Him; No, the feweſt and the pooreſt in the world: ſo it has been, and if it be ſo now, it ſhould be no offence; Saul, who perſecuted David with open face, and in a cleare light, had almoſt as many 3 Sam. 24. 2. thouſands with him, as David had hundreds, and thoſe choſen men out of all Iſrael (that is) valiant, ſtout, well-appointed, and fit for war: David, that ſtood up for his own defence againſt an enraged King, had but an handfull of men, and thoſe moſt of them in diſtreſſe, 4 Sam. 22. 2. and in debt, and diſcontented. This conſideration reſolves its ſelfe into this concluſion, That a murtherer may have thouſands on his ſide, all choiſe men (I meane, right and fit for war:) and a faithfull ſervant of the Lord may have few on his ſide, nay none that looke after him; This was Davids caſe, yea, the Churches caſe, juſt; her adverſary called her an Out-cast, ſaying, This is Zion whom no man ſeeketh after; No man: ſo it may be with the Church and Jer. 30. 17. people of God, and yet the Church ſtill, and a very cleare evidence that ſhe is the Church, whom God lookes after and ſeeketh after;
Therefore is ſhe called Sought out Iſa • . 62. 12.: It is not the Churches caſe now, the Lords Name be praiſed; many Noble, many wiſe, many learned are on the Churches ſide now; even all the truly noble, truly wiſe, and learned throughout the three Kingdomes doe now appeare on the Churches ſide, as they did for David after God had cleared His upright dealing as the noone day, and humbled him. But this is not the diſtinguiſhing marke; as not whereby to know Saul from David; ſo nor whereby to know which is the Parliament indeed; not by the number of nobles and worthies, [unleſſe (as now) toward the latter end, after God has cleared His Churches cauſe, emptyed His ſervants hearts, made them know (the difference betwixt) the ſervice of a Parliament, and the ſervice of an 2 Chro. 12. 8. Anti-parliament, as the Lord ſayes, in the like caſe:] but this is the infallible marke, obſerve to which Aſſembly or Parliament the Edomites, Adverſaries of Judah, all the Papiſts in the world joyn themſelves: This obſervation never failes. True it is, men in diſtreſſe, and in debt, may joyne themſelves to the Parliament (though not one for a hundred ſuch, who are joyned to the other ſide.) But theſe Edomites, Iriſh and Engliſh murtherers, never come-up to the Parliaments ſide, not one of them, unleſſe as Doeg came to the houſe of Abimelech, to get advantage againſt David, and to haſten deſtruction upon Iſrael: Obſerve then to which ſide theſe Edomites are joyned, Engliſh and Iriſh Monſters, and this will cleare that miſtake, none like it.

3. It was a great offence to heare both parties proteſt the ſame thing, To be for GOD, for the true Religion; for the Rights and liberties of the ſubject: And it is an offence of heart, and ſtaggers ſome at this day, To heare the King, ſeduced by his Anti-Parliament, proteſting and declaring all this, and commanding it to be read in all his Churches on the LORDS Day. What? That they ſeeke peace, and purſue it: and are ſtout and reſolute for the defence of the true Religion, Laws and Liberties of the Kingdome: and they ſay, hearken all ye people, for they will have their loyall and lawfull intendments, made knowne and declared to the people in that very place, where the Oracles of God ſhould be declared: Indeed this has beene an offence to ſome, and may ſtagger ſimple ones at this day. But the wiſe in heart were never offended at it, for they conſidered, firſt,

1. That truth was never oppoſed, Religion never perſecuted, but under the vizor of truth, and ſemblance of Religion: nor ever were the Lawes and liberties of the Kingdome, and of the Church of Chriſt oppreſſed, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , as we ſay, with a bare head, but under a Cap of Maintainance, (that is) under a pretext, To maintaine all Lawes, liberties, Religion, and all: In nomine Domini incipit omne malum, an old Proverb, and an old device of the Devill; his Pope began juſt ſo long agoe, By the grace of Almighty God, and His Authority intruſted to me, I will; what will he doe? or what did wiſe men expect would follow thoſe premiſes? Omne malum, all the miſchiefe that he could doe, an utter ſubverſion, as power was in his hand, of all the Lawes, Rights, liberties of Chriſts Kingdome. I could tell the reader, and aſſure him, that the moſt abominable hereſies, horrid iniquities, all theſe came-in under a Cap of Maintainance, to defend and maintaine their contraries. It muſt needs be ſo, elſe it were not poſſible that the adverſary could prevaile; he muſt not tell the people, that he will take away their Rights and liberties (Religion is the leaſt of the peoples thoughts,) and make them ſlaves: If the Devill ſhould ſay ſo, he would have no ſubjects; No, he muſt transforme himſelfe, and his miniſters into Angels of light; he muſt tell the people by the mouthes of his Miniſters in the Churches, as Abſal • m did, juſt ſo, ye ſhall have juſtice now 2 Sam. 1 • . 4, 7, 8.; and that they may be aſſured of it, he muſt tell them, he has vowed a vow unto the LORD, and he muſt pay it; and then Abſolom ſtruck at Davids Crowne. This is a prime conſideration, and of large uſe, the ſumme thereof is this; They, who will make worke for Fryers in England, ſet-up Popery here, muſt doe as the Fryar does, ſhave his head, but he puts on his cap, that all the world may not know him to be a bald—So he, who would make worke for Maſſe Prieſts, now muſt puton a Cap of Maintainance; he muſt ſeeme to maintaine all that he has a mind and full purpoſe to deſtroy; Rights, Lawes and liberties of the Kingdome, Religion and all: Let the wiſe in heart conſider;

2. That this profer of defence and ſemblance of maintainance, as aforeſaid, is old and rotten, it is become very unſavoury now; They remember very well, that the adverſaries of Judah and Benjamin offered faire this way, their ſervice to the builders, and
reformers, the Worthies in Parliament at Jeruſalem; Wee will build with you, ſaid they, for we ſeeke your God as ye doe; and we Compare Ezra 4. 2. with a King. 17. 29, 33. doe ſacrifice unto Him ever ſince the time; what time? If we compare Scripture with Scripture, we ſhall know what worſhippers they were, by their own confeſſion; ever ſince they could make gods of their own, feare the LORD and ſerve thoſe gods, ever ſince. There are the ſame offers tendred now to the Parliament, the ſame proteſtations made now; they are rejected with the ſame diſdaine now as then, you have nothing to doe with us to build, we our ſelves together will doe our worke, and ſerve the LORD. So theſe adverſaries were anſwered then, and ſo now; and then it followes as it now does, what the adverſaties of Judah ver. 3, 4. Pſal. 9. 16. Rem meditan dam ſumm • . did to weaken the hands of the people, and to trouble them in building. Higgaion Selah this, a matter that has been very much meditated upon, and now cleared.

True: The wiſe in heart may be reſolved here, and cleared, but how ſhall the common-people be reſolved at this point; When they heare theſe offers and undertakings for the defence of their Laws and liberties declared unto them in their Churches, they muſt needs think all this to be as true as the Goſpell: for nothing, they think, but truths are declared there, ſo they think, doe they not?

No; they cannot think ſo now; they have been uſed to ſuch Declarations; The King (ſo we were perſwaded) would have his Declaration touching the ſanctification of the LORDS Day, with Minſtrells and May-games, this he would have read in his Churches, and his legit ut Clericus, his Miniſters did reade it Clarke-like: But that all the Chriſtian world might know how abominable that Declaration was, which yet was declared to the people from the mouth of his Miniſters, in his Churches, the ſervants of the Lord adjudged it to the fire, to be put thereinto by the June, 1643. hands of the common Hangman, which was done.

There was another Declaration, and the King commanded it to be read in his Churches, by his Miniſters, to his people; And ſo it was, That the LORDS beſt ſervants and moſt loyall ſubjects were Traitours and Rebels all. But ſee the turnings and tides of things, that yeare, and the yeare after, [Indeed as wonderfull, as was the turning of Jordan back, for according to that tyme it muſt be ſaid, What has the LORD done?] The Tables were
turned, then, and the Images broken to pieces there; and the next yeare after, there, at the ſame Deske, and by the ſame Miniſter, theſe Traitours and Rebels before, muſt be declared to be, as indeed they are, the Kings moſt loyall and beſt ſubjects: The people cannot be deceived now, with the Kings Declarations, quaere peregrinos vicinia rauca reclamat; If the Kings Miniſters will have his Proteſtations and Declarations to be received and credited, they muſt ſend them over to the remotest Ilands, where the inhabitants are wholly ignorant, what ſervants, miniſters, inſtruments, the King has and works-by: where the people never heard, nor ſaw, nor felt what their—actions are. Indeed the people of England are ſottiſh and brutiſh enough, for the moſt-part our Paſtours are ſuch: But the Kings party muſt not think, that we have neither eyes, nor eares, nor any other faculty, whereby we underſtand the incoherence, inconſiſtency and diſagreement of things; we can heare what is ſpoken, and we doe ſee what is done: and we ſee, how contrary words and actions are one to the other. Nay though
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , &c. Baſil. Ep. • 2. the Devill has poſſeſſed ſome of us, made us blind and dumb, we can neither ſee, nor ſpeake, nor heare, yet we have one ſenſe which will never leave us till we dye; we can feele. And now, though we have no more ſenſe of Religion than our brutiſh Paſtours and vile Prieſts have, yet from this ſenſe we conclude, firſt, 1. That Papiſts openly ſo or in heart, will not maintaine the Proteſtant Cauſe, for they have burnt the Proteſtants in the fire: nor will they, at this time, edifie and build-up the houſe of GOD, whatever they will have declared to the walls there; for they have ſet our houſes on fire over our heads, and threaten us yet more. 2. That the adverſaries of Judah will not become friends now, unleſſe for advantage; that they, under colour and ſemblance, and ſhew of friendſhip, may worke-out the ſubverſion of Judah. 3. That robbers, ſpoilers, murtherers, will not defend our Laws, juſt rights and liberties, for we feel what they have done againſt us, like evening wolves, they have deſtroyed all where their foot could come, they have made our Eden, and garden of the LORD, as a wilderneſſe: Our ſenſe has told us, theſe men, rather beaſts-likemen, have done like themſelves, as ſaith the Proverbe of the antients, wickedneſſe proceedeth from the wicked man: And whatever 1 Sam. 24. 13. their Declarations are to the Churches and people there, yet
they will doe as alwayes they have done, who are men full of all ſubtilty, and all miſchiefe; children of the Devill; enemies of all righteouſneſſe, that will not ceaſe to pervert the right wayes of the Lord. Laſtly, As we are quick to feele where we are pinched, ſo we have a little underſtanding (ſo much as our children have, for that ſufficeth) to know, which party, the Kings or the Parliaments, does wrong us, does make us ſmart; we can judge of workes and of workes, what the Kings party does, and what the Parliaments party; what are the undertakings of the one, and what of the other: One ſcruple there is, and that troubles ſome of us, not a little.
A. The King, by his evill Councellours, hath forced an Oath upon us, and now we have taken it, we think we are bound to ſtand unto it, as you to your Covenant.

B. No, for ſo you are able to reſolve your ſelves. You have ſo much underſtanding, you ſay, as to judge betwixt works and works, what are agreeable and correſpond with Law and right reaſon, what are contrary to both. The judgement is as eaſie betwixt Oath and Oath, Covenant and Covenant: The Parliament have ſworn and muſt not repent to maintain the Rights of their LORD Chriſt, and of the Lord their King; The priviledges alſo and juſt liberties of their ſubjects all. The other ſide, a contrary party, have ſworn clean Salv. de gub: li. 4. 135, 136. Per Chriſtum, quia tollo illu • s per Chriſtum, quia o • oido illum. Rem ac ſubſtantiam. contrary to all the forementioned, and muſt repent or periſh for ever. Now judge you of your Oath, whether you muſt ſtand to it or not, after I have told you what Salvian tels me, which is this, There are ſome men ſuch ſinners, ſo abominable, That they will ſwear by the Lord Chriſt, that they will ſpoil & rob His ſubjects, yea, & kill them too. Ile tell you how I was anſwered th'other day, by a Lord-like oppreſſor, who had ground the face of a poor man, my neighbour, turned him (as the good Miniſters now adayes are turned) out of all, took from him all his livelihood. The poor man intreats me to entreat for him, I did; Sr, ſaid I, deal not ſo unjuſtly in taking away this poore mans livelihood, you have taken away, his life
Deut. 24. 5. Quicquid hominis vitam ex neceſſitate tolerat. Vibrant in os meum truces oculos juravi inquit. &c. Quid ampli •• ſacerem? Diſceſſi. This Lord bent his brow upon me, and looked fierce like a lion, then told me, He must do as he had done, and muſt not doe otherwiſe. Why muſt you not? I replyed; And he to me, By the Lord Chriſt Ile do it, for by Him I have ſworne. Ah Lord! The man is beſide himſelf, ſtarke mad. Ile ſpeake no more to him, ſo I
departed. Here is a cleare caſe, I have done: ſo much to remove the miſtakes about the Parliament, the taking off the offence, if any be, againſt their Perſons.

There is ſome miſtake about their defence, that that does conſiſt (III.) in numbers of men, and ſtrength of ammunition, wals, gates, and bars. Indeed this is a defence very conſiderable, and when the Lords time is come (it is at hand) and His ſervants cauſe fully tried (as Davids was) then the North ſhall give-in to His Churches help, and the South ſhall not keep-back; Eaſt and West will ſtandup; every man will ſtand upon his own guard, without taking gaine of money Judg. 5. 19.. But this we reckon not upon as a defence to be leaned upon; Theſe are but the ſmall feathers of Gods protection; the great out-ſpreadig wing, as the out-ſpread firmament of His Power, is the LORD GOD Himſelfe with His Twenty thouſand Pſal. 68. 17. 2 Kin. 6. 17. Charets, even thouſands of Angels, the Lord among His people, as in the holy place: He is the Defence of His people, even all thoſe that are, and ſeeke His Glory; the Lord is their Defence, or He creates a Defence upon His Aſſemblies, all the Glory Iſai. 4. 5.; His defence is a created defence; it defended His ſervants when their Soul lay among lions, amongſt thoſe, that Pſal. 57. 4. were ſet on fire with rage, yet defended; how they were defended they cannot tell, but they were defended, A created preſervation is above mans apprehenſion. But ſo the ſervants of the Lord may know themſelves to be the Glory, the Aſſemblies of the Lord; and therefore nothing can diſmay them; when it is ſaid, this ſtrong-hold is loſt, and that towne gone, yet the Parliaments ſtrength failes not, it is not gone, for GOD is not gone, that ſtrong-hold continues, even God in His holy place, an EVERLASTING Iſai. 26. 4. STRENGTH, and that is a ſure ground of EVERLASTING CONFIDENCE. God is all, and alwayes workes moſt gloriouſly then, when He workes alone, when the Creature is gone, and the proud helpers doe ſtoop under Him 1 Job 9. 13., then He works like a God. Never ſo for his adverſaries; (that is) He never wrought for them with an Arme made bare of fleſh: His Arme has wrought for His Adverſaries, but ſtill He hath clothed it with fleſh, and they have called fleſh their Arme; and given it all the glory. The concluſion is, the Adverſaries defence is of their own making, or but imagined. The Parliaments defence is created, ſo wonderfull, that it is above apprehenſion. God is called
their Defence, their ſtrong Tower, a Refuge for His Servants, therfore GOD with His people will anſwer all objections againſt them, Remember the Lord, who is great, there is the defence, none ſuch, Neh. 4. 14. the Rock, not like the adverſaries rock, the enemies themſelves being Judges; under this defence, the ſhadow of this great Rock, march you on-ward, Ye Worthies of the Lord, be not afraid of your adverſaries, Remember the Lord, who is great and terrible: and fighe for your brethren, your ſonnes, and your daughters; your wives, and your houſes. Spare them not, for they will not ſpare you, and feare that the Lord will not ſpare you neither, if you ſpare them; God has commanded, Be zealous for Him, as Phineas was, Numb. 24. 8. ſmite thoſe adverſaries as Phineas did, and then expect the plague will ceaſe: And ſo I come to the laſt thing in propoſition, the work of a Parliament, and to cleare the miſtakes about that work; what the work is firſt, though I thinke, the Malignants are not ſo brutiſh as to queſtion it.

1. Their work is, the ſetting-up every thing in its place; the IIII. LORD CHRIST upon His Throne above in His Church; His Deputy the King upon His Throne below; Religion in its place, and the Law in its place, (which muſt doe us Right when the King will not,) thats the worke, to give Inventae ſun • leges cum ab uno viro, &c. Cic. oſſic. the Kings of Heaven what belongs to Him, and His King on earth what belongs to him; his Prerogative its length, and the ſubjects Priviledge its Right, that the King and his good people may rejoyce together, and not, as it has been, when the King and his Favourites, ſate drinking, that is, rejoycing; the Citie of God, his people there were in perplexitie, (i. e.) ſate mourning: No, the Parliament muſt endeavour, as they can, that all may rejoyce together, or all mourn together; there is harmony, a good conſent and agreement, befitting ſtill a Chriſtian King, and a Chriſtian people. This is the work of a Parliament; they would have it underſtood of all, it is to reforme things out of order in Church and State, and ſet them to rights, that there be a good underſtanding betwixt the King and people. In a word, it is called a work of Reformation.

Sober men are miſtaken here alſo, and in an extreme ſtill; ſometimes they ſee obſtructions like mountaines in the way of Reformation, and then they thinke, It is a work will never be done, the child of Reformation will ſticke at the birth ſtill: Then again, they
ſee the mountaines made a plain, then they thinke the work will be done preſently: th • ſe are hasty thoughts, which men making haſte, are full-of. Sober men ſee the vanitie of theſe thoughts quickly, and as quickly correct themſelves and their roving thoughts with perfect and ſetled thoughts, as theſe, and ſo they come-off from the firſt extreme conſidering,

1. That we expect now a man-child to be borne (i. e.) a compleat Reformation: The ſober man muſt think now and ſettle upon the thought, that the production and bringing forth of a naturall birth into the world (whereto nature is ſo helpfull) is the wonderfull work of God, and aſcribed to His Hand. Nature indeed travels hard, and many throes ſhe makes, as if ſhe would throw-out all her ſpirits, and ſtrength, and breath at one caſt: And yet, when nature has done all ſhe can, to her utmoſt, ſhe cannot out-act her ſelfe, there the child ſticks at the birth, and there it muſt ſtick, till an Almighty Hand fetcheth it forth, not the mid-wives; No, Thou art He that tookest me out of my mothers wombe, ſayes David. That Deliverance he aſcribes to God; and it aſſures him for the time to come, that he ſhall be delivered in his greateſt ſtraits, for ſo he comforteth himſelfe (Ile note it by the way) againſt his jeering adverſaries, David truſted on the Lord, ſaid they, that Hee would deliver Pſal. 22. • . him let the Lord deliver his ſervant now, ſeeing He delights in him. So the Lord will, ſayes David, and he thinks his adverſaries are mad to think the contrary; But how is David aſſured, that the Lord will help him out of thoſe ſtraits? Yes, the Lord will deliver me, ſayes he, and he is aſſured, for the LORD delivered me in greater ſtraits than theſe, when I was in my mothers wombe, ſtraits indeed, He took me out thence, ſayes David; the ſober man conſiders this with all his heart, and

2. If ſuch an Agony, ſo much trouble, and ſo many throwes before a man-child be borne, he conſiders what an Agony there muſt be, what throwes, what contentions, what ſtrivings, before a NATION be borne, before Zion brings forth her children! Ah Lord! but I muſt ſuppreſſe my meditations, an hint muſt ſatisfie: Only the ſober man wiſely conſiders this with it,

3. That it is now as once it was, the adverſarie has ſtood before Rev. 12. • . the Church all this while ſhe has been in travell, and ready to be delivered, to devoure her children ſo ſoon as they be born; and now
that they are borne, and ſecured by the LORD Himſelfe, and carried as upon Eagles wings, ſtrongly, ſ • iftly out of his reach, yet the adverſary ſtands watching his advantage, and if his hands cannot reach theſe children, yet his mouth ſhall; for now alſo, as in former times, he has caſt-out of his mouth water as a ſtood after the ver. • 5. Church, that he might cauſe her to be carried away with the flood: thus the man conſiders, and

4. That the ſervants of the Lord have taken the readieſt way that could be taken (a way that never failed, it cannot faile now, whereof before) to mid-wife-forth this Birth; And how wonderfully they have wrought with God, and God with them, is now the wonder of all the Chriſtian world: We have had wonderfull Births, I have not a fitter word, for the Almighties Hand has brought them-forth, and the longer they ſtuck at the wombe, the more compleat they were. But it is ſaid, the MAN-CHILD is not borne yet, (i. e.) the worke is not compleated, though man has wrought with God all this while, and GOD with man, which made ſober men think that the worke would be ſpeedy, and ſudden. Theſe were as haſty thoughts as the other were diſtruſtfull, and in another extreme. Thus they are corrected by conſidering firſt.

1. The inſtruments or meanes God workes by; By men moſt times, I need not adde, weak, for man implies it; though he may ſtand for a thouſand in our choiſe, yet he muſt not ſtand ſo in our account; Man is but a Cypher indeed, and ſtanding alone he is nothing So one of the beſt and ableſt men of the world, has accounted himſelfe 2 Cor. 12. 1 • . nothing; not to be accounted of: And ſo are we to account of him alſo, Ceaſe from man, whoſe breath is in his nostrils, for wherein is he to b •
Iſai. 2. 22. accounted of? It would be well with us i • we of low degree could looke upon men of high degree, and they upon themſelves as Nothings, for then they and we would labour to bring-downe GOD unto men, and to carry-up our ſpirits unto God, to ſix upon Him ſtedfaſtly, and ſo our ſpirits would be more conſtant and ſetled, we ſhould be able to ſtand ſtill (which now we cannot doe,) and waite the ſalvation of God: As for men whether low or high, they are all the ſonnes of men (i. e) Nothings, vanity, No truſt to be put in them; God only is all, and does all, and as He lets forth Himſelfe to His creature, or with-holds His hand, ſo His creature is and acteth; If we thinke that men can
doe any thing of themſelves, then we thinke of them above what is meet: But if God will joyne himſelfe to men, (thoſe Cyphers,) as he has done, and is pleaſed to doe, then one man is an hundred quickly, and ten a thouſand.

You will ſay now, why are not things done ſuddenly as we expected? why is not Reformation compleated? There is mighty reaſon for that; though God joynes His hand to mans hand, yet He goes His creatures pace, ſlowly but ſurely: He works as a God, and His works are diſcerneable; But men work as men; though they goe GODS way, yet they walke their own pace. And ſee in paſſage the goodneſſe of their God, He does account of men as workers together with him; He will goe with them their pace, doe their work for them, and yet deale with them, as they with their little children, let them take the honour of the worke, which He has wrought: But wo • unto them now, if they ſo requite their LORD, not aſcribing to Him all the glory. Let us looke-over the regiſter of Gods works, which He has wrought by men, or which men have wrought, theſe three laſt yeares, working with God. I ſee my worke growes-bigge under my hand: ſeeing I have not •• e skill to leſſen it, and yet have ſhortened my meditations, let me greaten and heighten the worke with the great and high works of the Lord; who ever was the inſtrument, God wrought them; Ile be as quick, in recording them, almoſt, as is a thought; and yet the readers underſtanding ſhall goe along with me, if he has laid-up theſe works and pondered them in his heart.

The firſt work in ſight (after they had made their prayer and ſupplication to their God, to bring Him down to them and their work) was the opening the priſon doores to the righteous, and ſhutting them upon the ungodly ones. Then the wicked did •• ee as before an earthquake, for the wrath of the Lord purſued them. Then yoakes were taken off the necks, and burthens from off the ſhoulders. The Biſhops were choaked with their own Oath, the fire comming from themſelves conſumed them, and their own lips ſwallowed them up, as the lips of fooles: Then they were Eccleſ • 0. 1 • . heaved-at, as the ſtomack heaves at ſome indigeſted bitts, to caſtthem-forth, but nature was not yet ſtrong enough; Then there was an heaving againe and againe, and yet it would not doe: but they were heaved-off from their ſtrong foundation. Then a
trieniall Parliament; and a long Aſſize. Then a Proteſtation was entred into, for God wrought with men. Then a great Champion, that had ſet his foot upon Church and Common-wealth, was cutſhort by the head: Then the bloody Inquiſition, High-commiſſion and Star-chamber Courts were taken away, thoſe ſnares were broken. Then a breach was made-up, which the adverſary would have made wide as the ſea, and a Pacification, &c. Oh Lord! how wonderfull! Remember ſtill, God works like a God, though He goes mans pace. Then the Tragedy began in Ireland, to end in England; and oh how active the Biſhops were, to bring over the ſtage hither; to ſet it-up here: And while they were a working, they wrought themſelves out of the Lords Houſe; and ſhut themſelves faſt-up in priſon, with their own hands. Then the earth was moved, for it was ſmitten terribly, and ſwords now drawn, but could draw no blood, O wonderfull! Then every man to his ſtrong hold, but they were ſafe among Lyons, who made God their refuge. And now there was a kind of checker-worke all along, many ſtroakes of red, and ſome white; the Lord mingled judgements and mercies, but all was mercy and a fruit of love to His Church and people; things were ſo diſpenſed, that His people might know, that they had grieved their God: apparent tokens of Divine wrath towards the Land, and cleare manifeſtations of loving kindneſſes towards His people, for then the adverſary girded and girded himſelfe, and God brake him as often to pieces. Sometimes the Lord walkt contrary, and backward, we fooles thought ſo, but then He went forward, ſtrait-on to the white and butt, He tended to from all eternity: and all His way though croſſe to us, were very direct, we fooles can diſcerne it now: Sometimes His ſervants roſe high, then f • ll as low, but their falls were their advantage, and tended wonderfully to give them aſſurance of an expected end: Then the wiles and depths of Satan were diſcovered, a plot as deepe as hell, and as full of malice as the Devill: But from that ſowre this ſweet, for then a ſecond Covenant was entred into; And all this time (which muſt be remembred) the malignants palaces were then, as now they are, their priſons: So the beauty of the Biſhops excellency is ſtain'd, and the prophecy fulfilled, Wild beaſts of the deſart ſhall lye there, and their houſes Iſa. 13. •• . ſhall be full of dole full creatures. This turning the Biſhops palaces
into priſons muſt be remembred ſtill, and how their Curates ſpued themſelves out of their houſes, or their houſes ſpued them forth. Then Hell-gates were ſet wider open, if wider could be, and there iſſued forth an horrid Proclamation; Then a Kentiſh untimely birth, an helliſh Rebellion, which ran its ſelfe preſently-out of breath, and expired. But God wrought gloriouſly ſtill, for now He brought-up three Kingdomes into Covenant, and one Nation forth for our helpe. O wonderfull! I muſt now paſſe over the victories God gave His ſervants, and the diſcomfitures alſo; there was wonderfull mercy in all: But on this our thoughts muſt dwell, though I paſſe it lightly over. GODS Houſe, appointed by Him to be an houſe of prayer, but made a den of theeves, is now turned to the ſame uſe it was intended, made an houſe of prayer: and theſe merchants, with their ſervants, are caſt-out; when this is done all over the Land, then the work is compleated; but bleſſed be God for what is done, for ever praiſed be His Name, Amen.

And ſo we have ſeene what man can doe, when he ſtands alone by himſelfe, juſt nothing: for he is a cipher; But if God will worke by him, then he, that was nothing before, or but as a cake of barley bread, ſhall ſmite the hoſt of Midian, overturne their tents, Judg. 7. 13. and lay them along, as our worthies have done. Indeed the more contemptible the inſtrument is, the more glorious Gods hand is, as when He works with an Oxes goad, or jaw bone of an Aſſe; then heapes upon heapes, and the work is wonderfull. And if ſo when He works by His inſtruments, what manner of work, and how glorious, which He wrought alone, going His own pace; Then His work was as quick as His word, which ſayes the Pſalmiſt, went forth ſwiftly, witneſſe the Heavens and the Lights there, which we ſee but cannot apprehend: and the earth with the creatures there: All theſe He wrought alone, He ſpake the word and they were created. And what manner of ſalvation will that be, which, the LORD ſayes His own arme, He alone will bring? A created defence is above our apprehenſion, ſo will that ſalvation be.
Thus we have conſidered the workmen, they work as men; God works with them, and works as God; but goes His creatures pace. Sober men conſider.

3. That the promiſe touching this work, the compleating of it, is, de futuro, God will reſtore, He will build-up Zion, His Tabernacle,
after it is fallen; I know not how low, but not too low for His hand to raiſe-up again. But Ile paſſe over this; Bleſſed be God that his Promiſe is ſo near accompliſhed, that He has brought His ſervants ſo near unto an expected end.

Here is a Paralogiſme a now to be conſidered on, (for thereby Col. 2. 4. unſtable ſoules are infinitely beguiled) touching this worke, the eaſineſſe and facilitie of the ſame. Thus they reaſon; the meanes whereby this Poſturing, this Reforming work is effected, are very eaſie, Praying, Preaching, &c. theſe were no ſooner commanded but done; then why is not the work done? the meanes are eaſie, and quickly performed, therefore the work is an eaſie worke, and of quick diſpatch, whether you reſpect a Nation, or a Man onely; there is the deceit.

The Man ſhall make anſwer to this in the next Section, where he will tell you that fasting, and praying, and hearing, &c. are but out-works, bodily exerciſes, the out-ſide of Duty, which are of little uſe. The man will ſhew us the in-ſide, and truth of theſe duties, which doe the work indeed. Ile cloſe this Chapter with a pretti • ſtorie, which may not be impertinent to ſhew us the inſide of a dutie, and what it is that does the worke. It is thus related, That a poore mans field proved very fruitfull, it was likely to yeeld him a very rich encreaſe; his neighbours envied and reproached him, ſaying, he was a witch, and wrought with the Devill, and conjured Plin. lib. 18. cap. 6. ceu pelliceret veneſiciis. their corne into his ground; Nor did they onely ſay ſo, but they ſummoned the poor man to make his appearance before the Judge, there to anſwer his inditement for witchcraft. The man makes his appearance, brings with him a luſty and ſtrong Wench, his daughter well fed and clad, together with his oxen well fed too, and ſtrong to labour, with all his implements of husbandry, all theſe he preſented before the honourable Court: At which ſight the Court ſtood at amaze. At laſt the Judge queſtions the man, Fellow, ſaid the Judge, what meanes all this, what makes thy daughter, and thy oxen here, here is nothing will be ſaid againſt them. Like your Maſter-ſhip ſaid the poore man, a plain fellow, You muſt indite Veneſicia mea haec ſunt: nec poſſu • vo • is oſtendere luc •
brationes, vigilias, ſudores. theſe, for theſe are my witches, all the ſpirits in ſight, that have conjured my ground; This is my witchcraft. I have brought my daughter here, that I may tell your goodneſſe, I doe not truſt ſervants, nor her neither, no farther than I can ſee her. I doe my buſineſſe
neſſe my ſelfe, or ſee it done; But yet this is the leaſt part of my witchcraft, I cannot ſhew your learning what my watchings have been about my ground, when my neighbours were faſt in their beds or looſe in the Ale-houſe: nor what my carefull diligence was, early and late, to keep and maintain my fences about my ground; nor how ſweat has furrowed my brow, and how my ſpirits have waſted; but theſe are the ſpirits which make my ground fruitfull. The application is eaſie whether we reſpect the Nation, or a man This poſturing vvorke is more advanced in the Cloſſet than in the Court. only. Theſe out-works, bodily exerciſe, outward performance, ſomething they doe towards the ſtrengthening a Kingdome, whereof Ahab and the inhabitants of Niniveh are great examples: And ſomething they doe to make the field of the Church fruitfull. But it is the inward-works, the workings of the Spirit, the ſtrivings, the wraſtlings there, theſe doe the work. It will appeare now in the next Section, for now I am comming to the Good Souldier, to remove the miſtakes about his perſon, and worke, and I will goe along with him in his warfare to his worlds end.

div.head: § VII. How the Good Souldier beares-up himſelfe above his oppreſsions.

argument.p: This Good Souldier is miſtaken, his adverſaries oppreſſe him, and blaſpheme him daily; how be beares-up himſelfe; and what his conſolations are under their oppreſſions; and how he anſwers their blaſphemie. We miſtake him, and he miſtakes himſelfe: Some miſtake about his Armour: We and he are miſtaken in his poſturing work; he thought it an impoſſible work, we think it very poſſible, and eaſie; He rectifies our miſtakes touching the chiefeſt duties of a Chriſtian.

div.p:
THis man is a Good Souldier of Jeſus Chriſt; That is enough to tell you, What he is? he is Body, and goods, and life, and all he is for the Parliament; he has lifted-up his hand to the moſt High God, that ſo he will be, and he will ſtand to it; he will ſtand-up for God, ſure, he will ſpend himſelfe and be ſpent for his Lord Chriſt, who gave Himſelfe for him, waſhed him in the Laver or Bath of his Cauſe, his Truths, his Rights, the Priviledges of his Lords Kingdome: for that is the way, the onely way, to maintaine the Kings crowne, and the Kingdomes of this world from ſhattering
to pieces. And ſeeing his Lord Chriſt, and the Lord his King, and all the three Kingdomes are concerned here, the man thanks God heartily, that he has a body, and goods, and a life, all ſpared and lengthened out unto him untill this time, when he may offer all, powre out all, as his prayers, for ſuch a Cauſe as this, and for the Governours of Iſrael, the maintainers of this Cauſe; Oh, his heart is towards all them, and every one that offered themſelves willingly. This man is of the Martyrs mind, Shall I dye but once for Him, that dyed a curſed death for me, to make me bleſſed for ever? What no more ſtripes, no more ſhame for His ſake, who was put to open ſhame for me? What no more goods to loſe for Him who was made poore, that he might make me rich? Now you need not ſuppoſe that this man has enemies enough; the broken Ʋniverſitie of Oxford, and all the whole Anti-Parliament there, all theſe are his enemies, and will doe him all the miſchiefe they can; their Court-Rab ſhakeh blaſphemes him every week, whom he regards no more than the Moon does the barking of a Dog; he is not afraid of the Beaſts of the earth, not he. The Ʋniverſitie proteſteth againſt this man, that if he be a Divine, he ſhall never be a Doctour; This man regardeth their honours no more than Peter did the money, Their honours periſh with them. Act. 8. 20. they have no dignities for honeſt men; the higher his deſerts are, the lower his eſteeme ſhall be: And if he be a Gentleman, he ſhall never be a Knight, &c. for they can command the Kings Sword. Simple fellowes, Schollars and no more? Tell this man of honours, and of their beſtowing, whom God has honoured. A right Mordecai he, He came againe to the Kings gate, Eſth, 6. 12. the ſame man at the gate, on horſe-back, and on foot. A rock indeed, be the ſeas raging or be they calme; is there a pleaſant Sun-ſhine, or does that wind roare called Huroclydon, Acts 24, 14. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , &c. in cp. ad Col. ca. 4. Hom. 10. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , &c Ibid. Job 38. 31. this man is, as the rock is, ſtill the ſame. But the adverſaries have plundered his houſe, done him all the miſchiefe they can, he is on Gods ſide, and they threaten to burn his houſe too, and if they could they would dig-up the good mans grounds, put all his earth into baskets, and cart it to Oxford. This is the great offence now adayes; I pray you let me tell you from anothers mouth, how this man neglects all this: and then, how he comforts himſelfe under his preſſures. His adverſaries, ſayes Chryſostome, would lay load upon his loynes (for he is a Righteous man;) he runnes the faſter now, and beares-up the ſtronger. They would, by their hard dealing, hinder his courſe; they cannot doe it, it is impoſſible; why? his courſe is ſpirituall in heaven, there his converſation is; you cannot bind ſuch a Runner, no more than you can bind the ſweet inſluences of Pleiades: or looſe the bands of Orion. Indeed it is in vaine to ſtorme this man, or to threaten ſo to doe; for, as is ſaid of Joſeph, if the ſtorme increaſeth, and riſeth high, he
as a Pilot riſeth higher, and rideth ſecurely above all the floods of great waters: there is his ſecurity and his comfort. He has been at Chryſoft in Gen. a loſſe, becauſe he would be loyall and obedient; It is not a loſſe; if the world call it ſo, they are miſtaken, it brings in an infinite gaine. It is not poſſible to take a ſhorter way to be rich, than to be at a loſſe for Chriſt: none feele more ſweet experiences of the Lords compendious providences, than they, who are reſolute in their Compendia proviaentia. obedience: They may ſafely expect God in His admirable wayes of providence, when they will reſolvedly walke in his wayes of obedience, when the ſervants of the Lord have given glory to God in relying upon His wiſedome, power and truth, they ſhall find Him employing theſe for their direction, aſſiſtance, and bringingabout all things to their deſired iſſue: yea above whatever was looked for, or thought of. None of theſe things this man is now robbed of could yeeld him any comfort but from an influence, through them, from Heaven; This influence, the adverſaries cannot ſtop no more than they can bind the ſweet influences of the Pleiades or Sun beames; what comforts he had before from houſes, lands, friends, &c. the ſame the Lord now inſtills immediately from himſelfe: and the immediate comforts are the ſtrongeſt comforts.

That which (to a man unacquainted with Gods dealings) is a ground of utter deſpaire, the ſame, to a man acquainted with the wayes of God, is a riſe of exceeding comfort: for infinite power and goodneſſe can never be at a loſſe; neither can Faith, which looks to that, ever be at a ſtand: whence it is, that both GOD and Faith work beſt alone. There is enough in Religion (if practiſed in power) to beare-up the ſoule againſt all imputation layed upon it; It hath this ſingular grace and preheminence in it, that either it guardeth us as an heavenly ſhield from all calamities; or elſe conducteth us ſafe through them, and permitteth them not to be miſeries: It either giveth honours, promotions and wealth; or elſe more benefit by wanting them, than if we had them at will; It either filleth our houſes with plenty of all good things, or maketh a ſallet of greene herbes, more ſweet than all the ſacrifices of the ungodly. The man abides now with meckneſſe, and waites with patience the time when with his eyes he ſhall behold his redeemer, Who liveth and is Mighty,
Who will, in His appointed time, repaire and make-up all His Churches breaches; will reſtore unto them all thoſe yeares, the locuſts have conſumed, the canker-wormes and theſe caterpillars; will wipe all teares from their eyes; will cleare Jacobs face, ſo that he ſhall wax pale no more; will cheare up his heart, that it ſhall never droope againe. And this appointed time is at hand; when Jacob ſhall rejoyce, and Iſraell ſhall be right glad. And ſo much to the preſſures from the adverſaries hand: and how the ſervant of the Lord beares himſelfe-up under theſe preſſures: I thought it very uſefull for theſe hard and perilous times. I come now to their blaſphemy. What is this fellow? We need not queſtion it, he is on Gods-ſide, on the Parliaments ſide, then he is a Traitour and a Rebell; ſo his adverſaries belch-out their words, calling him by their own name:
Me de ſuo nomine vocat. Cic. parad. The man thankes them very heartily for that; he takes it for a greater honour than if they ſhould make him a Knight (of the poſt,) Lord, Earle, Marqueſſe or the like. A great honour to be vilified, miſcalled for Gods Cauſe, to be reproached for His ſake. So their fathers reproached all the Worthies of the Lord in all ages: If they were true builders in Gods account, then were they Rebels and Traitours in the enemies account: Their fathers ſaid as much againſt Chriſt Himſelfe, that the Devill was in Him, He was a Samaritan and had Joh. 8. 48. a Devill. Indeed this man glorieth very much in this, that he is as his Maſter was, ſo reproached, ſo perſecuted, ſo blaſpemed. What ſayes he now in way of anſwer to theſe blaſphemies? Nothing, he ſpreads this blaſphemy, as the King the letter, before the LORD; His Lord ſhall anſwer it, and ſo He will; He will anſwer it by Himſelfe: for God is blaſphemed, and not the man; His grace, His image upon the man, His actings in the man to and for his God; that, that is it, the butt and white, at which malice bends her bow, and ſhootes her arrowes, even devouring words: God muſt anſwer this by Himſelfe, for He is blaſphemed, the man will ſay nothing. The reproach is againſt his LORD and Maſter, He will require it; if there were nothing of GOD in the man, no more than is in his adverſaries, they could agree very well, for then Rebels and Traitours all, and no offence at all; but God and godlineſſe in the man, there is the butt and white, God will anſwer it. And now the man will ſit down and mourne for theſe his adverſaries in his ſpirit,
who, he is verily perſwaded, [conſidering the ſeaſon, and cleareneſſe of light, and malice ſo apparent in their reproaches, not againſt him, but God Himſelfe and His Image upon him, His actings in him) have blaſphemed the HOLY GHOST. He mournes for them, and ſo he comes off from that ſad and mournfull ſubject, the blaſphemer and his blaſphemy, And now I come to the miſtakes about this good man.
