We are miſtaken, and he both, and in extreames all. Sometimes we may think, that this man ſo magnified here, and ſo magnifying his office, is ſome goodly man to looke upon. No, it may be not, looke upon his outward viſage, and may be there is nothing to be deſired; he is made ſo conformable to his LORD once, that he may be but a contemptible out-ſide now. And ſo we are quickly corrected, for thinking of him above what is meet. And now we fall into the other extreame; though we have not ſo baſe and vile thoughts of him as his adverſaries have, ſuch as Goliah had of David, yet our thoughts are too meane concerning him. But let us remember, that his adverſaries conceits, and ours too, will be corrected one day: It is a point of wiſedome to correct them now, while there is time, and hope; for our conceits hold meerely by the tenure of ignorance, (The adverſaries conceit not ſo) There is councell enough in the ſift of Wiſedome Wiſd. 5. to correct us all, if we take it ſeaſonably, ponder and conſider well of it: The conſideration of thoſe words, will correct our miſtakes touching the man, or nothing will doe it, till our mouth come, and endleſſe paines reſt and abide upon us for ever. But whatever our conceits are of Laudanti • us facile credu • us etiam mentientibis, ſeu falſus honor • uvat, &c. Ilier. him, though they doe heighten and leſſen fooles, who hearken what others ſay of them, rather than what their own conſciences ſay, theſe our conceits of him, whether high or low, cannot make him conceited of himſelfe: As he doth, touching peace, ſo much talkedof, and hearkened after now adayes, he hearkens and liſſens what GOD ſayes, for He ſpeakes peace: So touching that we call praiſe, esteeme and account in the world; If he have it from GOD and good men, he has enough. It is a very ſmall thing with him to be 1 Cor. 4. 3. judged of mans judgement; He, that judgeth is the Lord: and all his labour or ambation is (for he labours as an ambitious man does after honours in the world) to be accepted of GOD: By the 2 Cor. 5. 9. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . grace of God he is what he is; in himſelfe nothing, but all in God;
wiſe in His wiſedome, ſtrong in his ſtrength: And he has nothing he can call properly his own, but ſin: what comelineſſe he has (his chiefeſt is as the Churches is, within Pſal. 44. 13., Glorious there) God put it upon him Ezech. 16. 14. Pro. 25. 11. Like apples of gold with pictures of ſilver; his zeal ſhines without, it burnes within. Rev. 4. 10. He receives all from God through Chriſt; his graces have their ſtrength and ſtability in Chriſt, and ſo his condition is more ſtable than Adams was. 2 Cor. 12. 7. Whatever grace he has he boaſteth not, but in GOD, for he has received it: and all his receits, he does caſt downe (as the Elders their Crownes) before Him that ſitteth upon the throne.

Yet we muſt note before we leave his perſon, That this man may be miſtaken about himſelfe; very poſſible, that his conceit of himſelfe may be too high, and ſometimes too low; too high and exalted above meaſure through the aboundance God has given him: but then God puts a thorne into his fleſh, ſome ſtrong maſterlike temptation, and downe he is brought upon his knees, as Paul was; then he ſees how weake he is, and how little cauſe of boaſting or exaltation in himſelfe; and now if he glory, he will glory in his infirmities, that the power of Chriſt may rest upon him: But he finds it hard to keep-up to his peg, for now he is too low, he ſpeakes too meanely of grace its ſelfe, and that he ſhould not doe of a cruſt of bread, for it comes from God, opening His hand: But he has aboundance out of Gods treaſury, and yet he ſpeakes murmuringly, as if he had received nothing, and then he cannot be thankfull; He has no grace, not he, no faith, no love, he has received nothing: nothing! he has the grace of humility, poverty of ſpirit, he is emptied of himſelfe, he ſees himſelfe to be nothing, and is this nothing? He feares God above many; loves God above all; and though he ſayes he has no faith (ſo low he is) yes, he has, for he clings to his Lord Chriſt, and cleaves unto Him; and, though he ſayes he has no intereſt in his Lord, yet, if you queſtion him at that point, he will tell you, he will not give away his interest he has in his Lord Christ (for He is his Heaven) for a thouſand worlds. An happy miſtake this, yea glorious A glorious grace humility, which layeth a foundation whereon to build a glorious Temple.: Yet let the man take heed he does not deale unkindly with his God, and render himſelfe unthankfull for ſuch grace. We know he is thankfull for a bit of bread, leſſer than ſuch a poore mercy; how much more for that grace, the grace of humility, if he has no more? (but where ever there is an emptying grace, there will be a filling grace,) for this makes the man honourable in Gods eſteeme, pretious and of high account: Heare what the Lord ſayes to him; Thou, preſſed with tribulation
and poverty, doſt ſay, Thou art poore; but I ſay, thou art rich, for thou poſſeſſest all things. Thou doſt want nothing, becauſe Rev. 2. 9. 2 Cor. 6. 10. thou knoweſt what thou wanteſt, and laboureſt after a ſupply, as after the moſt lovelieſt thing, more after grace, than glory, ſo God ſayes. Reade againe, This man has overcome the world; and is all for another world, where his Lord Chriſt is; Now he reades what followes, he ſhall inherit all things; and I will be his God and he ſhall be my ſonne: Here is enough to correct the miſtakes this man Rev. 117. has of himſelfe.

What his Armour is and the ſeverall pieces of the ſame, all the III. world knowes, that are not willingly ignorant. That Armour without is not deſpiſed by him, nor neglected: But that, which is not Epheſ. 6. in ſight, which David, comming againſt Goliah had put on, that makes the man like flint, and braſſe, and renders the ſhocks, and blaſts of the terrible ones againſt him, as fruitleſſe and harmleſſe, as a puff of wind againſt a mountaine of braſſe. It was ſpoken before, upon all the glory (and he is a great part of it,) there is a defence; even upon all thoſe, that are, and ſeeke Gods glory; And ſee now how confidently he walks, as bold as a Lyon; he laugh •
Job. 5. 22. at the ſword, and famine, neither the red horſe, nor the pale horſe, can affright him; His heart is fixed truſting in the Lord; And he walks accuratly, preciſely, exactly, according to the line of men, as becommeth a man ſo protected, ſo defended, that has a guard of Angels ſtill about him.
A. But makes his adverſary no offers upon him?

B. Yes, and more than offers, he buffets him oftentimes, and ſometimes, once or twice, the adverſary clubbed him downe: but he was quickly up againe, and ſtood more ſtrongly and kept his watch, and his Armour about him, more carefully for ever after.
A. But does the man never ſtraggle out of his way, and ſo from under the eye of his guard, the Angels of God?

B. No never; I doe not meane, that the man keeps ſtill in the ſame walk; that he makes no fault, nor turnings at no time; The man has wandrings, and like a ſheepe ſtraggles ſometimes; but his ſheapheard overlookes all this, and lookes him-out; his Lord God beholds him in the way, wherein he walks moſt conſtantly, and would walk ſtedfaſtly for ever; He pittieth His ſervant in his by paths, and his ſervant loathes himſelfe becauſe of his wandrings,
and ſcatterings that way: It is the high way, that this mans ſoule deſireth to keep unto, and the high way of the upright, is to depart from evill; that is his way, and he keepeth his way, and preſerveth Prov. 16. 17. his ſoul, and ſo he is preſerved. A well poſtured man indeed: how he came to be ſo well armed, ſo meet for defence, and offence; what a labour and work this is comes now to be conſidered.

The man was miſtaken about this worke himſelfe, he was in an IIII. extreame; he thought it could never be done. We are in another extreame, we think it is a work quickly done. I intended to be large here, as the matter and work does require, preſuming I might make this the moſt uſefull of any thing in the book: But becauſe it has ſo much exceeded its proportion, and the common rates, ile ſuppreſſe a good part of my meditations, and lay thoſe, I ſhall expreſſe, as cloſe together as poſſibly I can, In the order I propoſed. 1. This good ſouldier thought, that this his poſturing worke would never be done; he may think ſo ſtill, you may ſay: for, as was ſaid, it is a work ſtill doing, and never done, not compleated till he dies, as we ſhall heare afterwards. But his meaning is, and his thoughts were, that he ſhould never ſee the work brought on-ward to that perfection, as now he ſees it, conſidering what a work it is: The exalting the Lord Chriſt in his heart, as Lord there (where He is He will be a Lord) Thruſting-out or caſting-down all the luſts-like-lords there) he had many lords there till he had one LORD there a: The ſetting-up the law of God in his mind, and bringingup his mind thereunto: In two words, the work and labour is, Multos domiuos habet qui unem non habet. Animae ſexum non haben • . to deny himſelfe, and to take-up his croſſe, and follow the LAMB wherever he goes. I ſhall never be able to doe this thought he (this ſonne or daughter, for neither ſoules nor Heaven has ſexes,) And truly, though this was an haſty thought, yet very excuſable. The man could not tell where to begin his work, and he can but tell when he ſhall make an end, whereof anon. At length he underſtood by reading; that he muſt begin with God, ſeeke Him by faſting and praying, ſo to bring Him down to him, and his worke. This was another worke: oh! how high the worke, and how low his ſpirit! yet that was the way, he muſt not leave off following-on to ſeeke the Lord; he muſt uſe the meanes heartily, and ſo he did, yet the work was not done. Done! The great worke was behind, the engaging work; the engaging his hand, and heart, and ſpirit to
the Lord, and againſt His adverſaries, though beloved luſts, as his right eye and arme, yet he muſt ſay to them all, and every one (his own iniquity, and that within his houſe or tabernacle Job 11. 14.) get ye hence Iſa. 30. 22.: I have engaged my heart, eſpouſed my ſoul and ſpirit to my LORD CHRIST, He muſt have it, get you hence, what have I any more to doe with Idols Hoſea 14. 8.? (The Lord heard him ſpeaking this, and obſerved him) oh how hardly was he brought-up to this engaging work? The way of the righteous is on-high indeed, a bringing back the heart from the earth, whereunto it is fallen flat, (and made all earth till Heaven came into it) and up to God: But up it was brought, and, like a ſtone indeed, downe againe it falls with its own weight. The man can tell you better than I what ſtops and pauſes he made in this work, what backſlidings (not in heart,) what ſtartings aſide (not in ſpirit,) what warpings, what declinings! A great while before he could attaine to aconſtancy, a fixedneſſe of ſpirit; And this he attained-to, not before he diſcerned plainly, that his canning his ability was nothing; his ſtrength was to ſit ſtill (that is) ſeeke GOD and His ſtrength, and depend thereon in Gods way, and never forſake that confidence, for God watcheth over ſuch a worke, ſo pleaſing in His ſight; and He hearkeneth to the deſire of them that feare Him: So that all the ſtopps, pauſes, obſtructions, walls, mountaines in his way to this work, did but ſerve to make this man alſo more carefull, watchfull, prayerfull, spiritfull, hopefull, joyfull: For though his warfare be not yet compleated, nor never will be in this world, though all is in expectation, de futuro, and ſo runs the promiſe (my ſervant ſhall eate, and drinke, and rejoyce) yet Gods grace Iſa. 6 • . 13, • 4. is ſufficient all this while; He is the Ʋndertaker to compleat the man and his work. And now the man has a good portion in hand, as an earneſt-penny, or as a bunch of grapes, to aſſure him, the full vintage and harveſt in Heaven, where is a length of eternity, which his thoughts, at the largeſt extent, cannot meaſure: And all that length of—eternity, the man ſhall have a full fruition; of what? that cannot be expreſſed. But ſo he has cleared his own miſtakes touching the impoſſibility of this work. Now if we will • earken to him, he will cleare our miſtakes on the left hand, touching the eaſineſſe of this work: for our conceit is, that the meanes, (prayer, hearing, reading, &c.) this man has uſed to
poſture himſelfe, are eaſie. But he will tell us, it is but a conceit; we are infinitly miſtaken: He will ſhew us our miſtakes in order, and correct them, firſt our miſtake touching Prayer.

1. Prayer is no eaſie work, unleſſe you meane the Biſhops work, their Common-prayer, which they called Divine ſervice. This man cannot acknowledge any common-prayers; nor can he conceive, there is any divinity in theſe prayers, that are ſo called; for firſt, we muſt not come before God with common hands, then not preſent unto Him common-prayers; We dare not preſent ſuch prayers to our governours Mal. 1. 8.. 2. We expect no common-mercies, but ſuch as GOD, Who beſtowes as a God, uſeth to give to His peculiar people: we muſt not then petition after a common manner. 3. Common-prayer at the beſt, can have but a common acceptance: but we muſt pray, and labour
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . in prayer, that we may be accepted of Him. 4. As the Cenſer without fire was never inſtrumentall to remove a plague: ſo, nor was this common-prayer efficacious for that purpoſe: for it has no divinity in it; they that looke for divinity in thoſe prayers (theſe words, in no ſober mans conſtruction, can reflect upon them, that made the prayers; there was, we doubt not, much of God in them:) but to looke for Divinity in this Divine ſervice, argues as much ignorance as was in thoſe people, who looked for the Moone in the Aſſes-belly; Thus it is related, Cum noſtra memoria ſit populus qui lunam ab aſino epotam crediderit, Ludov. Vives comment. in Aug cap. 16. lib. 10. de Civit. The reflex and ſhadow of the Moon was in the water while the Aſſe was drinking; preſently a cloud over-ſhadowed the Moon, then the people thought, the Aſſe had ſwallowed-up the Moon; And after they had indited the Aſſe, (as the Papiſts did the Rats and Mice, for eating their breaden gods) they rippedup the Aſſes belly expecting to find the Moon there: He that tels the ſtory aſſureth us, that he could remember, that ſuch a brutiſh people there were in his dayes, an hundred yeares agoe: And ſo it might be, for we have Paſtours and people more brutiſh in our dayes, who think, that the Spirit and power of God, is in their Common-prayer, which they call Divine ſervice, and make it an Idoll; as ridiculous every whit as to think, that the Moone was in the Aſſes belly. Having cleared that rubb in the way, he proceeds to tell us; That indeed, reading of prayer is an eaſie work, for there is no fervency, no power from Heaven; but praying in prayer, that is labour and work both, a fervent, an hot worke, like
the working in mettals, and there is power in it, a power from Heaven, even the spirit of power. I doe not ſay now, that no prayer is a prayer, that has not all this heate and power in it; I know there are degrees of heat: And as there were degrees of Pſalmes, or Pſalmes of degrees: So there are degrees of Prayers, and prayers of degrees, ſome higher, than ſome; ſome more fervent than ſome, ſome fuller of ſpirit than ſome: But every true prayer has an height in it, an heat and fervency in it, a power in it, which comes down from Heaven, and raiſeth the prayer to Heaven, to the boſome of God, elſe it is not properly a praying, but a ſaying (for I date not call it a prating or babling) nor will I ſay, that ſuch • liveleſſe ſaying of prayers has no acceptance with Him, who heareth the Ravens, but I will ſay, that ſuch a ſaying of prayer, is not a praying in prayer. But ſo the man prayed, he prayed in prayer, before he could remove the accurſed things: But firſt of all, which ſhould be noted firſt, when firſt he prepared his heart, and ſtretchedout his hands, he put iniquity farre away; he cleanſed his heart
• ob 11. 13, 15. from loving and liking of ſinne: and, what he could, he cleanſed his houſe, he ſuffered not wickedneſſe to dwell there; then he liftedup his face without ſpot, he is ſtedfaſt and does not feare. So little to rectifie our miſtakes touching prayer, no eaſie work. Praiſing is the higheſt, the moſt refined work of a Chriſtian: I cannot ſpeake a little of it, therefore ile ſay nothing.

2. Nor is Faſting an eaſie work, I meane to ſanctifie a faſt. To afflict, not the body only, but the ſoule with faſting. What is that? To charge upon the ſoule all the nationall and his perſonall grievances, his ſins the cauſe of all this, with the circumſtances and aggravations of theſe ſins; to charge them upon himſelfe, the (Cauſam ſociam) the helping cauſe of this bloodſhed, &c. I and of the ſhedding of the Lord Chriſt His blood too; his ſin pierced his Saviours ſides; This is to ſanctifie a faſt; and not to hangdown the head like a bulruſh for a day, that is no faſt. 3. Nor to reſt and ceaſe from labour: ſo the Oxe can doe, and the Aſſe; but this is not to ſanctifie the LORDS Day: This is it, To keepe a day to the Lord ſo, as to be in the spirit all that day, having his fellowſhip with the Father and the Son: not by our will to doe our own wills, nor ſpeake our own words, nor think our own thoughts; to keepe as on the mount, in meditation upon the
glorious work of Creation by the Father; and thoſe admirable wayes of Redemption by GOD the SON; this is to ſanctifie a Rest; and ſo our miſtake is rectified touching that matter; That that is no eaſie work.

4. To heare at home and at Church is an eaſie work, for it is but the forme and ſhell of duty, now to heare, and preſently as ſoon as the word has been ſounding in our eares, to talke of our Oxen, and making of furrowes, or to aske what newes? this is not hearing, this is provoking the Lord; It is to turne His Grace into wantonneſſe, not improving the light, not hearkning to the voice of nature; this is an eaſie work. But to heare with an hearing eare, nay an hearing heart 1 King. • . 0., to heare ſo as to chew upon it, conſider on it, and to make it ſinke downe, this is hearing, and an hard work: ſo to Read with care and endeavour to underſtand (elſe reading is nothing, or as the Parrats prating, but ridiculous.) To Heare and Read and to profit, there is the Power. Theſe are diſtinct things, no eaſie work. To carry a Library in your braine is no great matter. But to have, as one had Lectione aſſiduâ & meditatione diuturnâ pectus ſuum bibliothecam fecerat Chriſt. Hieron. li. 2 • Ep. 22., a Library in your heart, full of Chriſt, His Word dwelling there richly, that is the praiſe; The head may be full, and the heart emptie. You may read and heare good bookes, good Sermons, and you may be never the better, the worſe rather: To heare will render you as uncleane as thoſe beaſts, which did not chow the Cud; much reading and much hearing without chooing upon it, and whetting of it upon your heart, is but like much eating and drinking, no digeſting; it clogs the ſtomack and cauſeth ſore ſickneſſes; I might have been more briefe in ſo cleare a matter, but yet it is a great matter wherein we are infinitely miſtaken; Therefore I will adde this alſo to be conſidered-on, that every thing muſt be done to edification; that muſt be the end of our Reading, hearing, ſinging, ſpeaking, praying; But ſo to heare, read and ſing, that I may be built-up by it in my moſt holy Faith, is no eaſie worke: To read, to heare, ſo as bring-up my heart to cloſe with it, to yeeld-up its ſtrong holds, to ſubmit to the law and obedience of it in every thing the word commands or forbids, even to the cutting off the right arme, or plucking-out the right eye, the parting with the deareſt and ſweeteſt luſts: So to heare as to obey (for that is hearing indeed) ſo to heare as to let the Word ſinke down into the heart to abide and ingraft its ſelfe there; ſo to heare as to conclude my
ſoul under it, this is Reading, this Hearing: this is to profit by both.

A. Why but God teacheth to profit, and ſo he ſayes, and you ſay the man muſt doe this and that, he muſt cloſe with the Word, and ſubmit to the Word, and let it ſinke down; and I know not what; theſe are but words, he can doe none of all this, God muſt work in him the will and the deed.

B. That is true, but it does not follow; Therefore man muſt do nothing; man muſt be doing to, he muſt ſtir-up himſelfe to meet the Lord: he muſt keep himſelfe in the way and walk of the Spirit, he muſt raiſe up his ſpirit, put forth all the activitie of his ſoule; when he comes to read and to heare Gods Word, he muſt turne every Word he heares or reads into a Prayer, that God may bleſſe it to him, and turn every word into Grace; that ſtrength and light of nature, and reaſon and conſcience, that God has given him, he muſt uſe and improve to the utmoſt as a faithfull ſteward of that little. I know that man is nothing, and without Chriſt he can do nothing; And yet I thinke I may ſay, that man ſhall not be comdemned for what he cannot doe, but for what he could and did not doe, not doe, not improving the talent he had. Man is not meerly paſſive in receiving of the word; a fond conceit, which makes a man lie-ſtill and ſit-ſtill at home and at Church, and turn over the leaves there as a naturall foole does, or as a doore turnes upon its hinges; Man, I ſay, is not meerly paſſive, the Word worketh upon him, not as Phyſick in a Baſon, or Glaſſe, but as Phyſick drunk down, and in his body. The Word is as raine drunk into the earth, or as meat taken into the body; let the man look what kind of ground he is, and how his meat does digeſt; for if not a drop of rain fals in vain, nor a bit of bread given us in vain, then nor the Word of God ſure; it does the work wherefore it was ſent, and therefore the Good Souldier puts forth all the Activitie of his ſoule, all his power; he reads and he heares to profit; he reads and heares that he may be an infinite gainer; he has taken in all the Word of God, and it is a dweller with him, that was his end, therefore he reads and heares, that the Word of God may dwell with him and richly in all wiſedome. And Col. 3. 18. as his riches are great that way, ſo he layes them out as liberally teaching and admoniſhing others as he has occaſion; He is one of the plain • ſt Commentaries upon the Scriptures that is in the world; • he plaineſt, I ſay, for others comment upon it by writing, he by
living; he expounds it by his feet, and teacheth it by his fingers ends, the beſt Expoſition, the beſt teaching in the world, for he teacheth by Example. A lively Text man, for the Word of God is legible in Text letters all his life over I pray you read Mr Caryls Expoſition upon Job, pag. 3.; A bleſſed thing when our Miniſters can ſee our Hearings, and behold our Readings in our walkings and converſations amongſt them! But this they ſhall never ſee till they have perſwaded with us, their hearers, to goe home and meditate on what we have heard, and ſo to whet it upon our ſelves, and ours: for if ſo be we doe after our manner, ſo ſoone as we goe forth the Church doores, we talk of Oxen, and making of furrowes, or asking after newes, we thinke not of what we heard, then there is a morall impoſſibilitie Our Miniſters knowing what our manner is, what a Liberty our Biſhops gave us; and the terrour of the Lord, will preſſe this upon us, and endeavour mightily to prevail with us touching this matter. that ever we ſhould profit by what we have heard or read.

A. You have well adviſed us touching Hearing and Reading; but indeed we know not whom to heare, nor what to read: for beſides our own obſervation, A loyall Convert (turned over lately out of Litchfields preſſe in Oxford) has told us that moſt of our Teachers and people to, are Anabaptists, Brownists, Separatists, Atheists, Antinomians, Turks.

B. Doe not you know that the Schollars of Oxford are paſt all ſhame? Let the world judge, if there be Atheists in the world, Antinomians (men that ſet themſelves againſt the law) or Turks in England, whether theſe are not in Oxford on that ſide: and whether that poore-Schollar be not one of them, hoping to get preferment that way, let all the world judge. Yet we doe grant that we have Atheists amongſt us, for we have ſome here that ſtand for the Anti-Parliament there. And Antinomians alſo: for, if againſt the Parliament, they are againſt all laws too. Indeed ſome there are that are called by that name amongſt us, who, I am verity perſwaded, underſtand the Law and Goſpell better then he or I doe; a • d then they cannot but approve the one, and embrace the other heartily: ſome alſo there are, that are honoured with that name, and yet are very ignorant of both Law and Goſpel; But we hope, not willingly, much leſſe wilfully, ignorant: and therefore there is hope, they will ſee their errour, and amend it ſhortly, now that ſo cleare lights ſhine forth before them.

And now we have but three Sectaries remaining with us; But grant him his ſaying, that there be ſix, nay, ſixteene, yet this is no
wonder. Epiphanius, ſayes Mr Jewell, rehearſeth-up foureſcore ſundry hereſies; and Auguſtine many more, which ſprang-up even together with the Goſpel: what then ſayes he, was the Goſpel Apol. 3. p. Cap. 2. d. 1. therefore not the Goſpel, becauſe hereſies ſprang up withall? or was Chriſt therefore not Chriſt? or was Chriſt and His Goſpel the cauſe of theſe hereſies? No ſober man will ſay ſo, this rather, that this is a great argument of our Part, that this ſame doctrine, which we teach, is the very Truth of the Goſpel of Chriſt: for neither is cockle wont to grow without the wheat; nor yet the chaffe without the corne: Ile read on in Mr Jewels words, for ſo he anſwered his adverſaries then, ſo we now, the objection is the ſame, the anſwer muſt be the ſame, That the world ſeeth now right well, thanks be given to our God, that we have neither bred, nor taught, nor kept-up theſe monſters: And you muſt beleeve us in all this, if you will read our bookes (thoſe that goe with licence to the Preſſe) or heare our Sermons. I ſhould ſay more, but this may ſuffice and ſatisfie every ſober man; yet the admonition is good, Take heed what you heare Mark 4. 24.; Take heed how you heare Luke 8. 18.. And let all your gaines and In-comes by your Hearing and Reading be expended and laid forth in your life and converſation. Amen. I proceed.

5. It is an eaſie matter to doe after our manner, throng-in to the Table of the Lord, there to partake of thoſe Tremenda myſteria, the ſignes of the Body and Blood of the Lord: But ſo to come as the Good Souldier comes, To receive vertue thence, To take and eat by Faith, this commands a great worke of examination before hand, what brokenneſſe of heart I bring thither? what ſtrength of love? what life of Faith?

6. In the laſt place, to covenant with the Lord, to lift up the hand, to ſubſcribe our name, it is but the out-ſide, the carcaſe, the bodily exerciſe of the duty and profiteth little, and is eaſily done; But to lay the ſoul under ſacred bands, to engage the heart to God, that the man will be wholly the Lords, wholly for His work, His ſervice, All his actings ſhall be to His Lord, and for Him, doe any thing, ſuffer any thing, be any thing or nothing, ſo his LORD may have the glory; Liberty nothing to this man; Riches nothing; life not accounted of, for the man is nothing, he is not his own; he is wholly for and laid-out for his God: An hard work to bring-up the heart to this. To what? why to live in another, to ſpeake and to
act in another, and for another; to be all for another and nothing for himſelf, to referre all to God, to receive all from God, and to be in a mans ſelfe nothing at all: It is a coſtly worke, but he has ſworn to it, he has lifted-up the hand; and ſubſcribed the name: As the beaſt to the hornes of the Altar, he has bound himſelf to God with full purpoſe of heart, that he will be his LORDS ſervant, all for his LORD. Amen. And this may ſuffice to ſhew the nature of theſe works.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.

argument.p: S • c • neſſe, Deaths H • rbinger and Death its ſelfe are knowne enemies to nature, and the Conquer • urs of this world: yet this Good Souldier is more than conquerour over both, which is m • d • plaine by a diſtinction the Sacred Scripture makes betwixt ſickneſſe, Death and Death.

div.p:
THis man has brought God downe to his ſoule, and he has brought-up his ſoule to God, engaged to Him: And he has, (and he has all things, for he has God
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
(i. e.) All things, Gen. 33. 11.,) he has in his Lord Chriſts, there is his confidence, and the ſtabilitie of his graces: And all he has, he layes-out for Chriſt, that is his duty: as all his actings are to Him, ſo are they for Him; An happy man indeed! he is out of the reach of his Adverſaries, the evill of ſickneſſe, the Power of death cannot reach him, is not able to hurt him. We ſuppoſe now, and yet that we need not doe, for it is an uncontroleable Truth, That weakneſſe, wearineſſe, and faintneſſe is that SQVIRE of the Body, which ſtill attendeth nature: And this man, though he may beare it out for a time, and think to wraſtle with this Squire, yet he muſt yeeld to it anon, take-his-bed, as we commonly ſay, lye-down there, tumble-upon it, turning-on this ſide towards his friends, they cannot help him; then on the other ſide towards the wall, as the good King before him, and prayed 2 King. • 0. 2 • .. But all this while, this man is not ſick. It is a Paradox againſt all conceit and reaſon, a very riddle, I know, but we ſhall eaſily read it, if we will read the Scriptures, and as theſe direct us, diſtinguiſh of ſickneſſe; There is ſickneſſe full of wrath: A ſickneſſe full of comfort. This is very conſiderable; of infinite uſe, therefore I muſt infiſt upon it.

There is a ſickneſſe full of wrath, And wrath with his ſickneſſe Eccleſ. 5. 17.
Ah Lord! now it is a ſickneſſe indeed: The Lord deliver us from that ſickneſſe wherein is wrath, for that is to be delivered from al • evill. Wrath makes it a ſickneſſe, a pure ſickneſſe, for therein is wrath; It is not the pain of the head, nor of the ſtomack, nor of the heart, which makes it a ſickneſſe: No, no; It is wrath that makes it a ſickneſſe; Wrath! The Lord deliver us from it, for it makes health a ſickneſſe, eating, drinking, playing, ſporting, but a ſickneſſe, all theſe; Marke the words, All his dayes alſo he eateth in darkneſſe. Darkneſſe! what is that? It followes, Much ſorrow. The man indeed feeles not the ſorrow, he is jocund and merry, but the more ſigne of more wrath, which he ſhall feele anon in his moneth Jer. 2. 24., when paines come upon him, then he ſhall ſay, I am ſick; for he feeles wrath with his ſickneſſe; Wrath was upon him before, when he was eating, drinking, ſleeping, God was angry with him every day, (all his dayes, he did eat in darkneſſe, ſayes the Text) Pſal. 7. 11. he was not ſenſible of this till now his day, and moneth is come, now he is ſick indeed, for he has wrath with his ſickneſſe. Indeed we ſhould not paſſe over this lightly, but I muſt proceed when I have given the ſumme only of what I ſhould have ſpoken, which is this, 1. Wrath with a mercy, be it health, peace, all outward proſperitie, makes all but a ſickneſſe: 2. Love, the will of a heavenly Father with ſickneſſe, wearineſſe, faintueſſe, with warre, and all outward molestations, and inward troubles, makes all healthy, ſound and well. That is the ſumme, the uſe is this, To put every man upon this work in the conſcionable uſe of all means, while health is, and yet his moneth is not come, whereby to pacifie wrath: if he be not carefull this way with all his care, then thus it will be when his moneth comes, and his eyes be open; then not only every griping in his ſickneſſe, but all that he called health, and all he did in his health, will come unto his remembrance with a ſenſe, and reliſh of wrath: Therefore uſe all meanes to pacifie wrath. And ſo I come to the other ſickneſſe full of comfort, this good mans ſickneſſe the Love of God, the face of God upon this man fils his heart top full with comfort: Though paines be upon him, and a ſore ſickneſſe, yet he will not ſay, I am ſick.
A. But may not God withdraw His face from this man, even at ſuch a needfull time?

B. Yes, that he may, for a night, and the man may apprehend
wrath in it, and that apprehenſion makes it a long night: but joy comes in the morning, abundantly recompencing that nights ſorrow. God will not plead againſt his ſervant with His great power: No, but He will put ſtrength in him Job 23. 6..
A. May not this man have a great diſtemper upon him, ſuch as may make him watch his opportunity to knock his head againſt the bed • ſted? ſo I think I have obſerved it.

B. Poſſible ſo, and ſuch may be the diſtemper of his diſeaſe; but yet the ſpirit is not out of frame; And now his friends will looke to him ſure; and ſuddenly the fit will be over, and then the man is himſelfe, and asketh his friends, (jealons of his behaviour) whether he did ſpeake unadviſedly with his lips? No ſaid they, and they ſaid very true, for it was his diſeaſe, not the man. And the man is very joyfull at this. Oh ſaid he, for ſo I have knowne it to be, I would ſay nothing that might diſhonour my God.

A. I but the man may be ground to pieces with a keen and cutting ſtone in his reines.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Chryſoſt. in Cap. 18. Matth.
B. May be ſo, and yet no wrath in this. It is the will of his GOD, the love of his heavenly Father, ſo to exerciſe His ſon or daughter for a minute; the love of a Father, no wrath in all this.

A. But the man has a loathſome diſeaſe upon him, that we call Seeming mercies are plagues when they come from wrath: And ſeeming plagues are mercies when they come from love: ſaid the Preacher, who gives forth the whole mind of God in the Scriptures, and his words by weight. Mr Marſhall. Text Numb. 25. 11. April 22 the plague.

B. True, but not a plague to him, no plague in that houſe, whatever we ſee upon his doore, or tokens upon his body, yet no plague there, if wrath be not there. Put it downe and conclude thy ſoule under this truth, That where is, there is a plague; Where no wrath, no plague: If wrath be pacified, the plague is gone; If wrath be not pacified, the plague remaines, be it ſword, famine, peſtilence, or wilde beaſts: from hence this is the reſult, Talke ye of Peace till your tongues are wearied, there can be no peace ſo long as wrath is not appeaſed; but appeaſe wrath, and then peace indeed, Peace, peace, whether you reſpect a nation or a man only.
A. But this mans acquaintance may be removed from him; Becauſe of his ſore diſeaſe, like a leproſie, a ſeparating ſickneſſe, he may be alone, and none • o comfort him.

B. Not poſſible, granting ſtill, that there is no wrath. None to comfort him! ſaid you; God ſpeakes comfortably to him, never ſo comfortably as now, now all are gone from him; now he feeles
the greateſt comforts, the ſtrongeſt conſolations: God comforts Iſa. 66. 13. him now, as one, whom his mother comforteth (oh how does a mother comfort her ſick child!) ſo will I comfort you, and you ſhall be comforted. Ai, for his God undertakes for His ſervant; his God will comfort him, it is not poſſible he ſhould ſay now; I am ſick •
A. Not ſick! his head akes, and ſtomack akes, and back akes, and his heart akes, and yet ſay's he not, I am ſick!

B. No; The Inhabitants ſhall not ſay, I am ſick, for his iniquity is forgiven Iſa. 33. 24.: There is the point, wrath is gone, ſin, that cauſeth wrath, that is forgiven; his fleſh and his heart, thoſe faile him, but God does not faile, He is the ſtrength of his heart, and
• ſal. 73. 26. his portion for ever. And now I come to that we muſt all come to, death; we can pull-out the ſting of it quickly, if it be as quickly done as ſaid; Then we muſt diſtinguiſh of deaths alſo, There is a killing death; and there is a quickening death.

A killing death; wherein a man at once, dies twice, dies a ſecond death; dies once, and dies ever; ever dying and never dead, a killing death. The ſacred Scripture aſſureth us it is ſo; They are dead, they ſhall not live Iſa. 26. 14.: they are deceaſed, they ſhall not riſe. What is this? I cannot expreſſe how terrible it is, It is a dying for ever, or a living for ever in the mouth and jawes of death; A living in death for ever, a continuing not in the ſhadow, but in the darkneſſe of death for ever, for the morning Starre ſhall dawne upon him, nor the Sun ariſe: A darkneſſe, where he ſhall never ſee the day, a perpetuall, an everlaſting night. There is another Scripture as terrible, I will kill her children with death Rev. 2. 23., who ſhall be ſo killed? is cleared from the context, that woman Jezabell, as miſchievous to the Chriſtian Church as ſhe was to Iſraell; That woman, and her children, her and her diſciples, who have drunk-in the wine of her ſornications, ſhe and they ſhall be Killed with Death; Killed. with Death! It is very terrible, God may open upon the mother and her children His Armory Jer. 50. 25. • Hoſe. 9. 13. Cruent is caedi
••• . Jun., ſhe may bring forth her children to the ſword, to be eaten-up with famine, conſumed with the peſtilence; devoured with wild beaſts, as now a dayes, and yet not killed with death. To be killed with death, is, when death ſeizeth upon the woman and her children, gnawes on them for ever, they ſhall dye and never dye; periſh utterly, and never periſh, they ſhall fall
by death into an ocean of miſery, like a milſtone, and there be killed with death, ſuch paines as are unconceiveable; and, which is the killing indeed, the Hell indeed, everlaſting paines, which makes every day of paine (if there were any day in Hell) an eternall night of miſery. It is a killing death, when every minutes paines, has the ſenſe of eternity in them.

2. There is a quickening death; Thy dead men ſhall live Iſa. 26. •• .: death is no death to them, life rather; It comes unto the godly ſwallowed-up in Chriſt his death (I think I may apply it ſo) that they may have life, and have it in aboundance Job. 10. 10.. There is a ſhort controverſie marvellouſly carried in a full contrariety of words, but meeting in a point of an eternall truth; The controverſie was concerning the Rulers daughter: The LORD CHRIST ſaid of her, ſhee is not dead Mat. • . 24.: The ſtanders by laughed Him to ſcorne, for ſaith St Luke, they knew ſhee was dead Luk. 8. 53.: dead and yet not dead, a truth in both; ſhe was dead to nature, alive to Chriſt, Who is the reſurrection and the life: the body is not dead to Him.

There are two other expreſlions very notable; He ſhall not ſee death, nor taſt death; he ſees it not as a conquerour, a king of tenrours, but conquered, unſtinged, ſpoiled, and led-captive: he looks upon as old Jacob upon his ſons wagons; or the Prophet upon his fiery chariot, ſo he looks upon death. He taſteth not of death, no wrath there; It is wrath, the killing with death, that is the gall of Aſpes; but now the wrath is gone; The man ſaid before, I am not ſick, for my fin is pardoned, and all wrath taken away; And now he is ſick indeed, Sick of Love; It is the will of his heavenly Father, that his ſickneſſe muſt unto death, and a fruit of His rich and aboundant love through his Lord Chriſt, by His Spirit, that he ſhould neither ſee death, nor taſt it, but ſee death ſwallowed-up in Iſa. 38. 17. Chaſhak •• . life and immortality; Indeed he is ſick of love, for the Lord has loved his ſoule from the pit: His loving kindneſſe was better than life to this man all his life long; what it is unto him now at his death cannot be expreſſed; but you ſhall heare his Song of Loves.

div.head: § VIII. The good Souldiers Triumphant Song.
div.p:
THis man is (ſuppoſed) now ready to breath out his ſoul into the boſome of his Father; the time of his departure is at hand; his work is done; he has fought a good fight, he has finiſhed his
• Tim. 4. 6. courſe, kept the faith: He has nothing to doe now, but to die. And that was his care all his life long, To ſet all his houſe, and goods there, body and ſoul and all in that order, that he might have no cumber, nothing at all to trouble him, in that houre of temptation, no other work to doe then but to dye. He has but one Song to ſing now, which, though his body be weake he can ſing in the ſpirit: When he had ſtrength of body, he ſang all Davids Maſchills, Pſalmes to give inſtruction; all his mictams, thoſe pretious ſongs therein recording the rich mercies, and the abundant loving kindneſſe of his God: And then he asked his ſoul, what wilt thou render unto the LORD for all theſe? And then he reſolved upon it, to praiſe his God while hee had any being: Then he ſang the Pſalmes, to call to remembrance; then when he was lively and Pſal. 38. 70. ſtrong he chanted-forth the 30, 31, 32, 103, and 116, 120, and ſo to the end of the book of Pſalmes; all theſe he has ſung with rejoycing: Now he has but one Pſalme to ſing, and it muſt be very ſhort, he will lengthen it out in Heaven, as long as eternity is long, for ever. Now he lifteth up his body, if it be not too ſtiffe, and heavy; and his eyes, if he can, if he cannot, his ſpirit is willing, and the ſpirit carrieth forth the voice, when the tongue moves not; O my ſoule, exalt, magnifie the Lord thy God, He remembred thee, when thou waſt nothing; regarded thee in thy low estate; when thou waſt in thy blood, worſe than nothing, then He called thee, ſaid to thee, live, live; then He waſhed thee with cleane waters, a dorned thee, took a way thine iniquity, tranſgreſſon and ſin, forgave all thine iniquities, healed all thy diſeaſes; redeemed thee out of all adverſity; held thee in life, kept thy feet from falling. Come Lord Jeſu, faithfull and true, whom I have truſted; I have committed my ſoul into thy hands, for thou haſt red • emed it LORD God of truth. His laſt words. And now his warfare is ended, and he compleated; In the very point of his diſſolution, he is made perfect.
Now he is where he converſed on earth, and delighted to be even where his love, his joy is, with His Lord Chriſt bleſſed for ever, Rev. 22. (He was his Heaven upon earth, and is his Heaven now;) and with the Saints of light, ſinging together the ſong of Moſes, and the Lamb, Hallelujah for ever and ever.
Let my way be as this mans way; my courſe as his courſe, my life as his life; then my end ſhall be like his, and the recompence of reward the ſame, Amen. So be it. Amen and Amen.

div.head: A Poſtſcript to the honeſt hearted Reader.
div.p:
THree ſheetes of paper (for I must not call it a Booke, that has neither truth nor reaſon for its patrons) were this very houre put into my hand, called A Loyall Convert. The ſcrible is stuffed with the higheſt Treaſon, horrible treachery, abominable blaſphemy, the baſeſt flattery, vileſt compliancy, with willing and wilfull ignoranc • , all theſe, all throughout. Take it apart; The Epiſtle first is proud, lofty and inſolent; his own, who knowes nothing as he ought to know, and his own heart worst of all. The following papers have attained their ſcope; To gain-ſay reaſon; To croſſe ſenſe. To blaſpheme God and His Scriptures, His King and His people, all the Kingdome over. The Malignants applaud it, every one ſayes; No doubt of that, and the faireſt Argument that the ſcribble and the ſcribe is as brutiſh as themſelves are, I call God to record upon my ſoul, That the Epiſtle and the ſcope of the following pages, is as I have in ſhort declared it to be: And that
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Epheſ. 4. 14. I have ſo done for this only reaſon, That unſtable ſoules, who are carried with every wind, like ſtrawes or leaves in Autumne, (many, every where) may not be beguiled with Paralogiſmes, Oxfords wild Sophiſtry now adayes,
A. But here is no Anſwer you will ſay, where as the ſilly Scholl • r has Ob. and An. all along his papers.

B. He has indeed, but his Objections are as ſilly and ridiculous
as are his Anſwers: Yet while was any hope, by braying she fooles, to get out their folly, theſe their Arguments, ſuch as they are, has anſwer after anſwer from Scripture and Reaſon both; But ſeeing he will be a foole ſtill; will bring old and worne Arguments, with blaſphemies to boote, we have our command doubled, anſwer him not: To what purpoſe ſhould they be anſwered, who will acknowledge no other God, but their King; no other wor •• ip • but what is in their Service Booke: who will not ſee the right hand of the Lord lifted-up now [though never more gloriouſly ſince the day He was lifted-up from the earth, as it is now, and all theſe yeares, ſince the Parliament ſate:] And can ſee nothing • all, with all their eyes, wrought by the contrary party, but through the depths of Satan, and treacheries of his Angels, right men for Peſſimum eſt qutoquid agitur a desperantibus. P • in.
〈…〉
honour, unleſſe they can overcome God himſelfe, and thruſt the Lord Chriſt out of his throne: no anſwer to theſe men. But one word more to the honest hearted reader; who may be taken w •• ſuch ſilly ſtuffe, he met with in the forement •• ned; he may b •• little transported beyond his own principles of nature and right reaſon: Hardly poſſible, yet poſſible; Then let him reade Allegeance not Impeached; I aſſure him upon the word of a Chriſtian if he be not willingly ignorant, The reading that booke, will 〈◊〉 the man to his right mind againe, and keepe him cloſe to right principles for ever.
